I was disappointed that Microsoft removed the Media Center functionality. A dvr for tv recording would have been nice. I won't be getting rid of my Xbox 360 anytime soon, though.

title: Great Console with great features
comment: Microsoft has done a phenomenal job on its new console I am just disappointed with the voice commands. The voices do work but I can not get my xbox to power on by the "xbox on" command. Very frustrating!

title: Huge, Needs Polish
comment:
The XBox One has a lot of promise but isn't for everyone -- yet. The UI is fast and responsive, multitasking works well, and the games look good. Titles developed exclusively for the One (Forza, Ryse) are much better looking than multi-gen titles like Assassin's Creed and Call of Duty.

But it doesn't feel finished. Kinect voice controls work most of the time. The times they don't work, though, are really frustrating. Kinect also misreads my feet as hands when I kick them up to watch a movie. Sometimes Kinect thinks I'm trying to pause or give some other command while watching a movie when I'm just shifting my weight around.

I'm sure the Kinect features will improve with time, but they're not whiz bang space age stuff that screams "Buy Me Now!" At least not for the time being. Bottom line: a fun experience for early adopters but probably not worth $500 for most gamers at this point. Re-consider once the library has grown and the Kinect has more spit and polish.

title: The Next Generation is Here!

title: Great system, but the 360's not dead.
comment: The Xbox One has not been a disappointment in any way. I firmly believe the One will earn its position as the 360's successor, yet the 360's massive game library and low price will keep it connected to my TV for still some time. My biggest complaint would be the lack of backwards-compatibility. Overall, I would recommend the system without hesitation, but there isn't any reason to pay above-retail prices right now.

title: Great entertainment consol
comment: Microsoft really hit a new market with the making of this console. You are able to do more than you ever could before and it still has potential. You are able to exit the game you are playing without really exiting and losing it. The xbox one will automatically save at points so that if you come across a problem and just think you lost what you did, you will be surprised. You are also able to multi-task when playing a game or watching t.v through the xbox one. It is just a great console.

title: Xbox One Wouldn't Turn On
comment: Brought the Xbox One home and plug it in. The orange light lit up on the power supply cable but the console would not start. I would hit the power button and it would make the start-up sound, then shuts off. It would be powered up for probably only 2 seconds. I continued to troubleshoot the problem and check online. I plugged it into an outlet, let the power cable reset (unplugged it for over 30 minutes), unplugged the Kinect before powering it on. I even worked with Microsoft support for over 2 hours, getting handed off from one technician to another and no one knew what the problem was. I eventually had to send it through FedEx back to Microsoft for a new one. They paid for shipping but not the super specific packing instructions that cost me $35 (on top of the $500 system). It was a two day rush delivery, but now it's just sitting in their "repair center" in Texas....just sitting. All they have to do is swap out a new one but I have no idea what's taking so long. So much for standing in line at midnight only to get the worst fate for a Xbox supporter of 8 years. Good job, Microsoft.

title: A fantastic product with a 'meh' launch lineup
comment:
What I like:
+ I always was surprised that through the entire life of the Xbox 360 (including the 360 S and 360 E), there was an unacceptable amount of lag on many core dashboard functions. Something as basic as showing your list of games, or list of gamerpics to change to, or achievement lists, or loading marketplace screens, would often take several seconds or waiting to populate. The Xbox One's startup is acceptably fast, but could still be improved on, but basic things like loading marketplace content or my list of installed apps, achievements, etc, is very quick. Switching between game and dashboard is no longer the slow annoyance it used to be, but rather is nearly instantaneous.

+ Dashboard Layout: The Xbox 360 dashboard was too cluttered and poorly organized, in my opinion. There were many different 'sections' to scroll through with LB and RB that made it take longer than necessary to get around. The Xbox One dashboard only has three now, it's much cleaner and simpler. Your pinned games/apps, main section to switch back to currently in-use game/app or browse your other apps, etc, and the third section is for browsing/downloading new games/apps. Very easy to navigate. I also like the notification and achievement changes. You can earn 0-point achievements in random apps, like for watching videos and such. It's admittedly pretty pointless, but if you don't like the idea of pointless achievements, you can easily ignore their existence.

+ Built-in game DVR. Very cool feature that removes the need for external recording equipment for anyone interested in that. Even if you don't plan on using this feature, it could still benefit you in the form of more & better guide videos from other people that will likely be swarming onto YouTube.

+ The controller. Controller design has come a long way since the old Atari joysticks or uncomfortable NES gamepads. I have used Sony's Dual Shock 3, Nintendo's Wii U Pro controller, Xbox 360 controller and Xbox One controller. They are all fantastic. But I must say I always liked the 360 controller the best. The Xbox One controller is simply an improvement upon that one. The only downside to the 360 controller was the mediocre D-pad, which has definitely experienced a massive improvement in the XBO update. They also moved the guide/dashboard button higher, which I like since I used to accidentally hit that when I meant to hit Start/Back. I even like how they redesigned the battery to go inside the controller. It takes slightly longer to swap a battery out, but since I use the USB cable to charge instead of swapping batteries (no Quick Charge Kit yet exists for the One like the 360 has), that doesn't matter at this point. The only thing I don't like is renaming the Start and Back buttons. "Press Menu" sounds way less cool than "Press Start" you're used to on any game's splash screen.

+ Noise levels and cooling/reliability. Anyone who had a launch Xbox 360 or launch PlayStation 3 (I have both) knows what I'm talking about. Those things were LOUD. Distractingly loud. Even over my high-end surround speakers. The Xbox One's internal fan is very large compared to the launch 360 (google photos if its internals). Large fans can move more air and are not as loud as small fans. This also helps with its reliability, as the Xbox 360's biggest launch issues were overheating problems. Microsoft learned from this and I guarantee that will not be an issue here. I wanted to make sure of this, so I have literally had my Xbox One powered on almost 24 hours a day for the last week since launch day. This is because if it's going to overheat, I want to know now rather than down the line after the warranty is up. And I'm killing two birds with one stone because Killer Instinct has some goals related to how long you are in practice mode, so I leave it idling in practice mode while at work. Yeah, call me crazy. But anyway, so far, it has handled being constantly on for days at a time with not a single issue.

+ I obviously can't speak for everyone else, but my Xbox One console, disc drive, controller, and Kinect, all function flawlessly and had absolutely no issues.

What I'm not thrilled about:
- Launch line-up. If you are on the fence about buying the console and you're not immediately sure what game(s) to even get for it, you could easily wait it out a while longer. Forza 5 and some of the multi-platform releases are pretty cool, but I'm not sure they're $60 cool. If you are buying the Xbox One now, you're doing it for the novelty of being among the first to have a cutting-edge system. This is true with the PS4 as well. Anybody who swears by any of the launch game is just a fanboy drone. There are a handful of *pretty good* games for both systems, but I see them as more of $30-40 titles. Honestly, I've enjoyed the downloadable Xbox One games the most, such as Killer Instinct, or the free Kinect Sports trial. Big disappointment is that digital versions of full retail games cost MSRP. Until Microsoft shares some of the cost reduction from going all-digital (no marketing, manufacturing, shipping, middle-man retailers, etc), I will ALWAYS buy my games in the form of the retail disc version. A $60 retail game should be $40-50 tops from the Xbox Live Store.

- No backwards compatibility. This would have been an even more important feature now than it was on the Xbox 360. We've now had eight years to build up a game library on our Xbox 360s. Mine is quite large. Not being able to use that collection as a buffer between Xbox One launch, and when all the great XBO exclusives hit, is very disappointing. The original Xbox only had four years to amass its game library, and since it was the first of Microsoft's consoles, there were far less owners with far less games than now exists with the Xbox 360. A lot of the same sentiments apply to the PlayStation 4. Both consoles could have benefited greatly from a backwards compatibility feature, since neither of their game libraries will be very expansive for at least a year or so.

- USB Ports. All three versions of the Xbox 360, including the launch version, had 2 USB ports in the front of the console. My 360 S also has 3 in the back. I like never running out of USB ports. But the Xbox One has zero USB ports in the front. So my Play and Charge cable has to plug into the side of the Xbox, meaning the cable can't reach as far, and someone tripping over the cable is more likely to result in damage to the console and/or cable. I'm also disappointed that external storage via USB isn't supported at launch, though it sounds like that is coming later on.

The bottom line is this: It's a great console with great potential, but as with most launch consoles, the games just aren't quite there to back it up, YET. If you are on the fence over the console because of the 360's launch reliability, I would honestly not let that hold you back on this one since Microsoft learned a very painful & expensive lesson from that, and designed a much more reliable console this time around. If you are waiting because you're unsure of the game library, you may be justified in continuing to wait. I honestly just got it because I knew for sure I would eventually get it anyway when Halo 5 comes out. But it the price is holding you back, you may have to wait YEARS for this to become affordable. So if you are okay waiting that long, great. But otherwise you might as well get it now so you can actually use it while you wait for the game library to improve. Chances are, there won't be any price cuts on it for at least a couple years, and the price cuts aren't usually anything significant until around 4-5 years after launch. So if you have the patience (I didn't), definitely wait. But since I am 98.4% sure the price will still be $499 when Halo 5 comes out, I figured I may as well get it now along with the extra pre-order perks.

A solid system; I definitely do not regret my purchase.

title: Way better than ps4
comment:
Xbox one is awesome. You can connect your tv to the back as an input and then display tv side by side with your game by saying xbox watch tv. I have purchased a ps4 and an Xbox and found the Xbox to be something new. Something I needed to complete my entertainment center. It is a media hub. Ps4 has many great apps and the new interface is good, but it isn't anything close to what you get with Xbox Dashboard. Xbox live has beeen working well on all games that I bought for it. Psn is still down three weeks after launch. Now you are paying for the same garbage online service that used to be free. Since I normally am playing online, this was huge for me. The controllers are both better than the last gen and I can't say I like one more than the other. I do like that by saying Xbox off my xbox turns off my television, the Xbox, and my receiver. The ps camera doesn't even compete with new kinect. If you buy the ps4 camera to compete with the bundled kinect, you are almost at the same price. If you are deciding what console to get, you can choose the cheap less fun ps4 or something that you will use for way more than just games, and is more than any smart tv, or gaming console before could offer.

The graphics are barely better than Xbox 360. Ps4 graphics are also the same proportion to the ps3. This could have been improved. My nvidia Titan blows these out of the water. The refresh rate on Xbox makes games look very smooth in fast motion...BUY IT. Even if your child wants a ps4. Ge them this and you and them will both be happier.

title: Much Much better than I Expected
comment:
Overall, I love my Xbox One. Neither a fan boy nor an electronic extremist, I truly feel the Xbox One is the console that everyone has under estimated.

Despite it's public follies during its original revealling, I think M.S. did a great job to write their wrongs and taylor the console to better suite the needs of the masses.

Bear in mind that this review is truly unbiased, in that I also picked up a PS4 on launch date. As much as the PS4 is smaller and looks sweeter, the launch titles are slim to none. Furthermore, PS+ has been having connection issues lately. (Probably due to the flood of new account activations post-Black Friday)

In the end, I say BOTH consoles are equally matched in graphics and performance. (Comparing Battlefield 4 on both)

Xbox One is a good choice if you want to have other launch titles to choose from (ie. Dead Rising 3 or Forza). Plus the new kinect features are a must with this console, hense validating its $500 price point compared to the PS4. Only main drawback for now is that it's a HUGE console and it's heavy. (Maybe a concern if you have a glass entertainment center)

PS4 is still equally just as good, but the slim selection of launch titles and connection issues with PS+ are all that drop this console a little lesser than the Xbox One... (For now)

title: Amazing system.
comment: I bought my xbox one at the midnight opening. I've been playing assassins creed so far and it's amazing. Blue ray is great, the tv feature is really cool. Still getting use to it but in a month or so it will all be second nature. The snap feature is great for additional apps. I have used NFL and Game DVR the most and so far they work great. The kinect sensor is working great but it does have trouble hearing some commands. But I read it should adapt and learn as you keep using it. I don't know if this is true but I hope so. The controller felt cheap to me at first but after playing for the past week it's way better than the 360. It is very comfortable and battery life is really good so far.

title: Amazing system with it's expected quirks....
comment: Bought on Day One, and it has not disappointed (for the most part). When I bought the system, I also bought CoD: Ghost as well as Ryse. Let me first say that Ryse truly displays the beautiful graphics the next-gen system has to offer. Ghost is also an improvement from the 360 version. Since we bought it, my wife and I have enjoyed many hours of Netflix and it has been a breeze to use. The only aspect I dislike so far is the party function. Compared to the 360, the XBONE has really taken a step back in this area. It is a bit of a pain to use and was difficult to figure out at first. Now Microsoft has already noted that they are working on a patch to make this better, and once it updates hopefully everything will be as it should. Other than that, one amazing piece of all-in-one entertainment!

title: great next-gen system
comment:
Waited in line for midnight release and boy was it worth it, haven't seen anymore in stock for a week. So far I have played COD ghosts, Forza 5 LE, Dead Rising 3 and I've been extremely happy with all three. The graphics are really good and are a major improvement over the 360 which is too be expected, when I played the display at a Microsoft store it was like looking through a window and in makes my 4 year old sony lcd 46" look like our new Samsung led 55" we got in 2012. The controller has some nice features, no protruding battery, the IR sensors are cool, the smaller thumbsticks & large triggers feel great but the LB/RB buttons feel harder to reach than before and the texture is slippery with dry hands. Kinect 2.0 works very well once you learn the commands & remember to say xbox first. The old kinect was frustrating & could never hear me unless I yelled, but the new kinect can hear just your everyday normal voice. I'm amazed at the features the Xbox one can do, I had know idea it could automatically turn my TV & DirecTv box on & off as well as control volume/mute, change channels via Kinect, play/pause recorded shows, record gameplay, and much more. And when I saw in the settings it could control TVs & Sat boxes I didn't think it would work with my 4 year old tv that has no smart features and a new but basic second room Satellite box but it connected & worked with both easily. I charged the rechargeable battery twice after two 6-10 hour gaming sessions but have since played at least 24 hrs without charging and the controller has showed no signs of dying anytime soon, but there is no more battery meter in the menu so you really have no clue when it will die. Xbox live appearance could be refined some more. I hope Microsoft has a remote in the works, it would come in handy when I want to watch TV at nite or just turn everything off but don't won't to use the controller and can't talk cause others are sleeping . Other people seem to be having a bunch of different issues but I haven't experienced anything major. My only problem has been that it stopped turning my TV/Sat box on and wouldn't pass through a sat signal after being on for 6 days, all I had to do was a hard reset/reboot and its been working fine since. For $500 a extra controller and a bigger hard drive would have been nice, but I'll take what's offered since we really don't have any say so. Xbox 360 was a way better console than PS3 (especially after sony started making them cheap) but this time around the hardware specs and price are making the
PS4 the better choice, and while I don't regret purchasing the XBOX ONE I might just have to get a PS4 too so that I'll have them both.

title: Love it

The new voice commands that is used with kinect work better than I thought, also the tracking works a lot better than the first. The tv pass through, is not really pass through. The xbox needs to be on to watch tv when connected through it. But it does work well. If you have an AVR that is in use you can plug it that in to the hdmi and pass everything through it. I don't recommend that setup because of lag that might be induced. Also at this time, optical out only passes stereo and not surround sound, but that is not a big deal. It will come as an update. Another issue that will be remedied soon is that none of the existing headsets that work for the 360 will work for the one, this will be corrected with and add on after the first of the year. Again this is a solid device that will make any gamer happy.

comment: the Kinect what you expected to be much better does not always respond and never responds to xbox on. other than that the device works well the graphics are excellent. installation was basically sample TV throughput working well.

title: Great gaming console

The TV is a new purchase for me and really brings out the best in the Xbox (the colors are amazing). On a negative note, for some reason the Blue-Ray player studders between frames and often becomes blotchy.

title: Love the xbox
comment: Love the games graphics and entertainment features

title: XBOX ONE.
comment: I recommend is great sistem for a lot of things games movies you see you internet speed apps games record by voice many things.

title: Live it!
comment: I was so happy to purchase this item. My kids absolutely love it!!!

title: Best gaming console ever!
comment: Looks great easy to hook up and set up controller fits my hand perfectly. Voice commands work and the connect sensor is much improved.

title: Great Next Step
comment: Overall have had a great experience thus far. The games are great, and theres something for everyone in my family. I love the SNAP feature as I can watch TV while my son plays games. I also like the new XBOX store it is very friendly and easy to navigate. I am very happy with my purchase so far and look forward to the upcoming games.

title: Solid Home Entertainment System
comment:
I was one of the crazy people who stood in line to get an Xbox One on launch night. I was so tired and had to work the next day, I didn't even open it up until the next evening. When I did, however, I really did feel liek I was unleashing the nex generation of not just game consoles, but whole home entertainment systems.

Setup was easy and guided. The single game, Call of Duty: Ghosts, that I had purchased to play on it downlaoded quickly (digital download) and installed in a trickle. As promised, I was able to begin playing when it was approximately half-way installed so I didn't have to wait for the whole thing.

Continued use has been great. I use Amazon Instant Video for streaming and that app was available immediately.

The only app that was hard to find and was pre-installed was Internet Explorer. For some reason you have to Bing it on the system (ironic) and then pin it to the home screen for quicker access int he future. Strange.

In all, it has been a great experience and I am excited to see how Microsoft continues to improve upon such a great launch product.

title: Great upgrade from xbox 360
comment: I had a xbox 360 for many years and was impressed with how much better the graphics are on the xbox one. It also has a great user interface.

title: lots of early bugs
comment: I bought this and a PS4. There are no great launch games from either system. The X-Box One has been pretty buggy when trying to use all the extra features outside of games. The PS4 has been flawless for me. I'm sure the X-Box One will eventually get patched and run a lot smoother at some point in the future. As it stands at this moment, I would tell people to wait until that point so you don't have to worry about sending in a broken system and having to wait several months to use your system again.

title: Good Console
comment: Xbox One console is a good console with innovative TV features. Needs some system patches for the operating system to run like it was intended. I would like the system to get more Xbox only games but it's early in the console cycle. The console is much more bulky than ps4, I wish it was a little more compact. The controller feels good in your hands, Xbox has finally removed the bulky back battery. The Xbox One no longer runs loud like the xbox 360. I like the tv features like watching tv as I play games but I wish that you could control the volume of each. Overall a good system needs some patches but it's a huge step up from the xbox 360.

title: It is exactly as presented. AWESOME
comment: Impressive!! Setup was fast and easy. Easy to navigate through the home page. Love the new smaller more agile controller. Fantastic voice recognition. Love It!!

title: Love the new Xbox but still lots to explore
comment: Still have lots to understand on the new Xbox but what I see so far I really like. The new Kinect is the best. Price is still a little high but will see if it is worth it over time.

title: Excellent graphics and features for gamers
comment: Overall the new xbox one is vast upgrade to the old systems. The kinect makes your entertainment system a synch to use and control. The game selection for it so far are awesome. Ryse is my favorite game to play in a long time!

title: Great Idea and Will be a Great product soon!
comment: This system is amazing and its possibilities could go anywhere. Yes, there are bugs. Ive read reports of disc errors, firmware update problems and other things but i havent experienced any of those. And if you do, microsoft has you covered so just be patient. The voice recognition software is much better then i thought it would be right out of the box. All the commands listed work well for me. the only issue i have is if the volume is up you have to speak louder then the tv for the kinect to hear you which makes sense but if you like it loud it wont hear you. The app system is just like your phone so in time there will be an app for everything. the early apps cover you're basic needs and work well but there is room for improvement and they will over time. And thats probably the biggest issue for this system. Everything works to a point and sort of feels rushed. If microsoft had another year it might come out of the box perfect but it needed to compete with sony so it needs some updates and bugs worked out. It just a matter of time, but this is the console to have for a complete system integration. A lot of fun!

title: Great!!
comment: Overall quality. Games that are available at release weren't amazing but how you can connect the cable box was awesome.

title: Great Console
comment: The Xbox one is a great console that is easy to set up, has great games and the Xbox live service provides the best online gaming experience.

title: Great new Console
comment:
Despite some negative reviews I have had little to no problems with my xbox One console. Upon installing initial update it does seem to freeze with the xbox logo but you just have to wait 10 min. The new kinect works amazingly well. Voice commands all seem to work seemlessly except for the initial command to turn everything on. Sometimes I have to say that twice. It works well with my cable and as far as gaming the graphics speed and detail are significantly improved. It needs DLNA for those of us with existing media servers. Skydrive works but requires to much effort to switch over my existing media server and I'm not sure how much storage skydrive offers for free. DLNA is much more efficient. The console makes no noise from what I can tell. And works well to integrate my whole living room entertainment into one piece with the exception of lack of proper DLNA. Because of that I'm hanging on to my ps3 for the time being.
Skype was really fun to use. No matter where I moved in my living room the camera followed me and always made me center stage.
All in all I'm very happy with the Xbox One. Just hope they will add proper DLNA.

title: Good update
comment: They did good on this new update to consoles and the new kinect that comes with it is now very useful. With the kinect now coming with it the upcoming games and what you can do with it will be interesting to see.

title: Great for all around entertainment

title: XBox One is everything thats its advertised to be.

title: Great system as usual!

title: First Mac, very impressed
comment: I have never owned a Mac and I work on PC's for my job. I looked at all current laptops out on the market and I wanted something thin, light, and a backlit keyboard. I couldn't find anything I was happy with and this was actually cheaper than the HP option with similar options I was looking for. I had a HP Spectre for work and it claims 8 hours battery life abd after one month it was down to 3 hours hours and their support said it is a "hardware issue they are trying to figure out". So I went went this and I have been blown away by the ease of use and the battery life, amazing. I forum I read daily said with the new OS installed, Mavericks, this will get up to 15 hours with normal use...and I have gotten just about that and all I use it is everyday internet and email use. If you want to spend a little extra money on a laptop that will last and has great quality, this is the way to go.

title: XBOX ONE
comment:
2 things I like and 2 things I don't like.
Don't: Seems like online gameplay with COD ghosts is lagging. I'm not entirely sure if this is due to my older Plasma Screen
Don't: Xbox has to be on to watch TV if using HDMI Passthrough and Cable box attached. It also seemed to be add problems to my viewing experience on Cable.

Liked: Graphics. and Kinect, Wow what an improvement.

Liked: Easy Setup better battery planning on the controller. Bing search is also really neat and I sure have enjoyed the OneGuide aid. It found my shows right away and added them to my favorite shows list. Cool. Tried Skype and that worked very very well.

The downside.... Game launch delays will slow sales on both next gen consoles . Less online friends to enjoy gaming with this. Keep your old Xbox 360 plugged in and switch back when you want to socialize with those who are not able to obtain the console yet.

title: Console for everyone
comment:
If you think an xbox is just for teenagers who don't have dates on Friday night you're wrong. The xbox one bridges the gap between tv, movies, games, and web. Almost semlessly takes you to a disired destination just by voice command. For the gamer in you the next step in graphics and gaming realism, like in FIFA 14 ignite engine, show what pervious systems could only half resemble.
My only poor remarks would be that because of the fact that it's so new and limited console numbers released the games available are few and people online few too. Even the xbox's legendary game, debatably the game that breathed life into xbox, halo isn't even available. Not asking for halo 5 but come on, release halo4 at least! Couple that with the fact that only a lucky number get to own the system at this moment playing online can sometimes seem like you're the only one who got an xbox on release day. Hardware wise speaking the voice commands can sometimes make you feel like you're yelling at your xbox.
All things considered, more xbox games will come out, more xbox one's will become available for sale, so while these issues I've brought up Might seem major, a little bit of patience will return years of happiness with your new system. Welcome to the new way we look at our TV and gaming consoles.

title: Xbox one
comment: The Xbox One is amazing. Games look great, online is ok, having issues with the party chat option. The kinect makes the Xbox experience that much more enjoyable.

title: Great system
comment: Xbox live is even better & the graphics look amazing. Controller feels great. Voice commands take some practice but do work! Switching from games to music to video are a breeze. Setup wasn't bad either

title: Excellent for games, TV - better than PS4
comment:
I bought a PS4 and owned it for one week. Played two games - BattleField 4 and Killzone. They were okay. PS4 was faster to setup and get going but I found it very limited in terms of what else can it do besides play games. I bought the Xbox One a week later and it's a far superior machine for my lifestyle.

The voice function of Kinect is awesome. I was hesitant at first but it gets the commands right 90% of the time. I use it to flip between watching shows on DirecTV to games back to TV. You can even tell it to change the channel or bring up the channel guide. I use this feature all the time. Xbox One plays Blu ray DVD's in perfect clarity. Also it plays audio CD's, which I found out the PS4 does not do.

As for resolution wars between PS4 and Xbox One, it's complete BS. My TV is a Panasonic 65" ST series and has arguably the best screen resolution of any TV on the market that isn't a 4K model. While BattleField 4 and Killzone looked really good on the PS4, neither could hold a candle to Ryse Son of Rome on the Xbox One. The best two looking games of any next gen console that are out are Ryse and Forza and it's not even close.

title: Worth the wait or worth waiting a bit more?
comment:
Well, here we have it, after long awaiting for the current gen cycle of consoles to end, the next generation of gaming has arrived. With the Xbox One, Microsoft has thrown down their iteration of the console wars.
Was it worth the wait and the price of admission? Well yes and no.

For 499+tax
The console is sleek and squared as an Xbox should be. The kinect is a bit bigger than expected as I don't have a ton of room for peripherals like that. You also get the power cord and brick, HDMI cable, headset and one controller.
The first big positive I want to mention is the controller, it is awesome! It feels great in your hands and the buttons and sticks are easily accessible and very ergonomic in nature. They're sensitive to the right motions so you don't have to over compensate. The drawback here is that out of the box it has AA batteries. You can buy the plug and play separately.

The interface is where Microsoft shines with this sucker. For those of you familiar with the Windows 8 metro, you will likely feel right at home here with the xbox one. Getting around menus and different areas is pretty easy, pinning things to your home screen and quickly accessing them is simple. You can do all of this with the controller, but ah! They touted all the voice features before launch right? Well let me tell you that I've already been using them a lot more than expected. They as of right now are not 100% accurate. The commands you have to speak are also very specific in nature and sometimes it takes one or two tries for the xbox to recognize. I think this has more to do with my voice or how I speak at times. I have found myself yelling at the box more than once because it won't listen.
I personally love the HDMI pass through on the back that allows you to hook up your TV cable box to it. This makes your entire entertainment experience quite streamlined. You can set it up so saying XBOX ON turns on your console, cable box, and TV all at once. You can navigate all menus and your entire TV guide with voice commands, change the channel, turn the volume up or down, add favorite channels to their own list, etc. This itself is a pretty cool feature for us TV watching couch potatoes. It is especially awesome for me to be able to change the channel while holding a newborn.

The games and their appearances are fantastic. I play a lot of Forza 5 and Battlefield 4 and they are simply stunning, even on my bottom of the bucket 32 inch TV. You will not be disappointed at how your games look, especially if you have a larger TV setup.

One of the biggest launch drawbacks was the games available. There just wasn't a whole lot of choices. And there really wasn't anything NEW. Dead Rising THREE, Forza FIVE, Battlefield FOUR. Pretty much all launch titles were sequels or sports games. No new IP's came out that you really were looking forward to. I guess there was RYSE but that didn't get reviewed all that great.

I guess I could go on but to sum it up.

I'm glad I bought the Xbox One. Could it have waited until there were more games out there to play? Absolutely, but I wasn't willing to try and hunt one down any closer to the holidays.

title: A lot of Potential
comment:
The Xbox One has a lot of potential for the future. Being able to control my cable box, and sound bar with voice controls is pretty cool. Not to mention I can do some skip forward, ff, etc with the actual xbox one controller as well. Jumping from cable to Netflix and back again is great, as well as being able to snap TV while I play games. In case a football/basketball game is boring but then suddenly gets interesting.
I haven't fully played with all the settings and snap features but it works pretty well (double tapping the xbox button on the controller switches between what is snapped and what isn't would have been nice to know and not have to figure out).

As for games, there aren't a whole lot of the launch titles that I want to play but the future looks pretty great. The controller feels great as it is definitely improved over the 360 version. The only downside is that games require installs (regardless of being disc based or downloaded from the store) and COD ghosts took up 40 GB of the 500 GB HD. Which means that I've probably used 10% of my memory for 1 game. Microsoft does plan to support external HD and use Cloud storage to make this a non-issue, but It'd be nicer if the internal one was bigger or upgrade-able. I await Destiny and Halo 5 as these games will actually have had time to use the system before release.

Some people have experienced buggy software issues but I personally haven't had any issues.

It currently doesn't support Xbox 360 games yet, Microsoft says they are working on that as well.

title: Great media features, and excellent gaming
comment:
I bought the Xbox One knowing it has a lot of built in media control, but not expecting to use or like the voice controls. I have been very pleasantly surprised by how well they work, and how fast and useful they are.

Setup
Setup is very simple, plug in the power brick, Kinect, and plug in an HDMI cable and you are set. If you want to use the Xbox to control your cable/satellite box, plug its HDMI out into the Xbox One's HDMI in connection. After that, power it on and it will walk you through the software setup.

Kinect/Voice Command
Once you are setup (and here's a tip, make sure when it says to turn your speakers loud for the Kinect setup, turn them as loud as you can), you can start playing games or just playing with the voice controls and dashboard. Try saying "Xbox select" and it will show you all the voice commands you can use on that particular screen. If you just say "Xbox" and wait, it will bring up a list of voice commands, if you then say "more shortcuts" it will bring up a list of all voice commands. It may feel weird at first, but it is handy and fast to use the voice commands once you get used to them. It is also very "I'm living in the future, now".

Dashboard
The dashboard should look familiar to anyone coming from the 360 or Windows 8. Lots of tiles. You can pin your favorites, and they will be in the left pane of the dashboard. The home section will contain your last 5 apps used, whatever is in the disk drive, and your profile and friends list. If you look at your profile, you will see a feed of all your friends' activities including any 360 friends you have. There is also an achievement section for all of your achievements, though this is not very well organized to look through. In the right pane is the store. You can buy games, movies, TV shows, and music from there and they will download right to the drive for you.

A few minor annoyances, I am unaware of how to view your download queue, and I am unaware of how you can manage your space on the included 500 GB drive. I know you can delete games if you like and re-download them when you want, but I haven't seen a way to view how much free space you have.

Apps
There are quite a few apps available right away. I've installed the usuals like Netflix, YouTube, Xbox video, the Blu-ray player, and many others to try out. They all work as you expect, and have a little different interface than the old Xbox 360. They also launch pretty fast.

Games
I've been playing Forza a bit, and it is beautiful. The cars look incredible, and the tracks are great.

Dead Rising 3 is a very fun game as well. It doesn't necessarily scream next-gen like Forza does, but with the numbers of zombies on the screen and the huge open world, it sure plays like a next-gen game.

Ryse is another beautiful game. In my opinion, it plays a bit like Assassin's Creed, but with a shorter story. I feel this is a game that deserves better than most of the reviewers are giving it credit for.

Powerstar Golf is fun, it is like a next-gen Hot Shots Golf if you played those. It is also a download only game from the Xbox Store.

Lego Marvel Super Heroes is another good one, this time for the kids. I bought this for my kids and they love it. The graphics are what you expect, but the gameplay is a lot of fun. An open world with over 100 super heroes to play, just a lot of fun to be had.

Overall
Overall, I think this is a great start for the "next-gen". There is a good selection of games out, and some great looking titles coming. And the system itself is great. I did not expect to like or use the voice commands, but they are integrated so well that I have found myself using them. I am excited to see what Microsoft does with updates as there are some annoyances that would be great to see fixed. I am also excited to see what kind of additional features they add in (thinking about the 360 launch, it didn't handle Netflix or any of those apps, they were all added features later on).

title: Lots of Potential
comment:
So far, the Xbox One has been an interesting addition to my home theater setup. I'm new to the Xbox world, so backwards compatibility is not an issue for me, but I can see where this would be quite problematic for those with 360's.

While the Xbox One is still very new and there are very few games currently available for it, it does seem to have a great deal of potential. However, as with most Microsoft products upon initial release, it is still a bit buggy. I've had several problems with the audio on the optical output becoming garbled upon startup of the system. I can generally fix this by restarting the Xbox, but once I had to reboot it twice before the audio got straightened out. And that leads me to one thing that seems quite strange to me. There doesn't seem to be a way to force the console to reboot other than simply pulling the power plug. The menus allow you to turn it off, but not to restart it.

Finding where things are located in the menus is also a bit difficult as there is no real documentation. One example of this is the setting to enable surround sound. I had to find it by going online and searching for it as it is disabled by default. It is located in the troubleshooting section (of all places) of the audio settings and it is listed as a beta function. I'm not even sure that it is working as the sound coming through the Xbox One still seems to be just stereo enhanced by my surround sound amplifier. Hopefully this will be addressed soon. In over a week of regular use, the system has only crashed once, causing it to automatically restart.

So, I think that many good things will eventually come to the Xbox One, but there doesn't seem to be much here yet that would cause me to run out and buy one immediately. I'd suggest waiting for it to mature a bit further before seriously considering purchasing one.

title: Magical!
comment:
Let me just say that I am very impressed with how well Kinect and Voice Control works. There's something absolutely magical about saying "Xbox On" as I enter the room and being signed in and ready to play a game or watch TV by the time I'm sitting down on the couch. And "Xbox Turn Off" to shut things down when I'm done. No looking for the remote control. It's amazing how much better something as simple as this makes my entertainment experience.

From a gaming perspective, I'm completely immersed in Forza Motorsport 5 at the moment. Amazing graphics. Fast, fluid action. A great online community. A "Drivatar" that learns the way I drive and races for me while I'm away. This is what next generation gaming is all about. I'm looking forward to other games in the future, but I want to make sure I give Forza its due time before moving on.

Lending to the great gaming experience is the controller. It's a refined version of the Xbox 360 controller. The vibration feedback in the triggers is perhaps what I like best about the new controller. It's subtle, but it really adds to the experience, e.g. in Forza 5, where the triggers now provide feedback when you're loosing traction due to braking or accelerating too hard.

From a media experience, Xbox One has it figured out. The experience with Netflix and Amazon Instant is already good. With additional apps coming in the future the media experience is only going to get better. Microsoft truly has built a media platform for the future.

The only issue I have with Xbox One is the $500 starting price. This is tremendously expensive from a consumer standpoint. For me it was worth getting the console on Day One, but not everyone will feel the same way. To those people I say, give it a year. Xbox One will only get better with software updates and new apps over time. And the hardware price will come down over the life of the console. You can choose to wait, but eventually you owe it to yourself to try this thing out. It's amazing!

title: Awesome new system

title: Ok but buggy
comment: It's ok is the best I can say. The device it self has a lot of potential but it is plagued with bugs. It might be very nice if ms gets the bugs worked out.

I am a gamer at heart and didn't care for the extra entertainment overview, but once I said "Xbox On" and the entire television turned on, I loved it. There are still some issues with different voice controls on the kinect, but the kinect recognizes your voice better each time you use it. I bought Battlefield 4 with the Xbox One and there are many issues with the game such as my campaign restarting, but it is a launch console and a launch game so these problems were expected and they are not horrible. Overall, it is a great entertainment system, but if you are looking for only a gaming console, this still does the job. 4 stars

As per my google search, if you load the games when you're not signed into your xbox live account, should fix the issue. For a first gen console, I believe little bugs should be expected. Other than that, system is awesome, graphics are great and it's so quiet that you don't even know it's running! Only wish we could play folks on xbox 360 (e.g. Ghosts)...

title: Great all around system

I still not a huge fan on the that, but the power of switching from app to app on the fly and the complete integration with my AV is great. I tell it to turn on and it brings my tv and audio system. Battery life is great on the new controller and it feels great as well. I am not impressed with the loading times for games, but until we get a pure XBOX ONE game, I won't judge to harsh.

title: Great console with lots of future potential
comment:
This is a great all around console as it is not just for gaming but aims to be your main media console in your living room.
The Kinect voice recognition works well at times and other times it takes multiple attempts to get the box to recognize what you are saying. I am hoping this can get better as I use the console more.
The games I have played on it have all been gorgeous and very smooth to play. Pausing to watch TV and come back to the game is very quick.
It does take a bit for games to load initially, but you can start loading a game, watch TV using the TV app, and it will notify you when the game is ready to play. This is only for the initial install of the game, not after it has already been installed.

title: Awesome system
comment: I bought this system for my son for Christmas. I haven't actually unboxed the one I bought but from seeing it in the store and checking out the features, it seems like it's going to be a lot of fun.

title: Great console
comment: Awesome gaming system waited in line for midnight release, it was worth it.checkout was very smooth with no problems.

title: Fun System

comment: The transition from XBOX 360 to XBOX ONE was easy to setup. A few adjustments and calibrations for the new Kinect Sensor and I was gaming within the hour.

It does not have the code for the system I have. Sound system is connected to the TV for now, so no issues there.

comment:
Day 3, the TV integration got flakey. Delays when changing channels, scrambled picture etc. Found similar comments posted on web sites. Microsoft's adivice is to "check hdmi cables". Replaced cables. Poor picture quality continued and on day 7, the cable box was no longer being recognized. Hooked cable box directy to TV, no problems....

Returned for refund that day.

title: OMG! I love it!
comment: I have been using Apple Products for years and this has to be one of their best. They have outdone themselves in every area! It is so light, easy to use and beautiful! I transferred ALL my old files from my Mac Book Pro seamlessly! The extended battery life is unbelievable!

comment:
The last game I had was an Atari - now I'm an obvious newbie to real gaming - so the game controller has been tough getting use to.

Nonetheless, I'm loving the xBox One! I purchased Forza 5 (amazing!) and Just Dance (lots of fun for all the family!) and I'm having the time of my life. Also, the free Kinect Sports Rivals game is fun and I'm getting so much from all the free Xbox Fitness exercises that I've just cancelled my gym membership.

There are too many violent games but I know that's true for the other game consoles, so it's not a complaint against Xbox just gaming as a whole.

Anyway, I'm truly loving my Xbox One!

title: Great system for gamers who like variety in games.
comment: This system has been great since the moment I got it on release day. It's almost completely silent when running, doesn't produce a lot of heat, and gives a great all around gaming experience. Xbox One makes it easy and natural to keep up with what your online friends are doing. I've already recommended that my friends purchase one.

title: Great console

title: Awesome Product - Exactly as Imagined

The diff between the Xbox and Xbox 360 I noticed most was much brighter everything was. The same is true with the Xbox One over the 360 - the images are so bright and clear and the Kinect is 10x more precise than the last one (which was still good). Great purchase for the family!

title: The Xbox One has lived up to the hype

EST 4 Life

Downloading games is a bit slow but my internet isn't very good either. I like being able to play a game before it fully downloads. The selection of launch titles is a bit limited but both RYSE and Forza 5 have been extremely fun. Both games look great and play smoothly. Can't wait for Titan Fall and Minecraft on the XB1!

Microsoft loves their money though and still require you to buy a rechargable battery pack for controllers and the cord for the headset is just flat out annoying and always getting in the way and will require you to purchase a seperate headset if you want wireless.

The games are good, graphics don't blow me away though. Still getting used to the home screen, but does have alot of useful apps. I'm not a big fan of the controller, it feels like the left/right bumpers are up too high and I have to extend my fingers too far up to hit them. Despite all the negative, still enjoy this console WAY more than the ps4. Good investment.

title: I'm very happy with my new XBOX ONE
comment: I set it up the night I got it and play daily. It is so much fun!!

comment: The Xbox One is just what my family and I are looking for to meet all of our digital needs. All my music, videos, and pictures can be stored or streamed through the xbox.

title: Very pleased
comment: I am happy with my new Xbox one because it has amazing graphics and Blu-ray finally. However not to impressed with the pricing of the new console as it is $100 more than then competing PS3. I am sure over time it will come down.

title: Fun system w/ lots more possibilities to come

title: Loving my $500 paperweight (not!)
comment:
Unfortunately I too was carried away with all the launch hype and got the xbox one... Everything worked great for a week and the whole family was enjoying the integration with the tv/cable box... (sure some people made a little fun out of "being so lazy that you'd talk to your tv, instead of using the remote" but that was part of the fun) but then one day I go to turn it on and it wouldn't respond to the voice command "Xbox On"... so I tried to "manually" turn it on but it would immediately shut off... Long story short Microsoft is sending me a new one, but I'll be without one for a week :(
I should have listened to myself and I would wait for all the new HW bugs to be worked out before buying one. Without this issue I would make it a 4 star item and would recommend the buy... There are a couple of other nuances that will need to be worked out (and I'm sure they can in the future with firmware updates) before I'd make this a 5 star item... but I won't get into these now given the circumstances.

title: It can only get better
comment:
Out of the box the Xbox ONE does do all the things Microsoft said it would do. It Plays games it controls my TV (And DVR) it searches the web and feeds me all sorts of info about media and friends activities.

Some of the launch titles are a bit lackluster, and this glut of complaints about 720p vs 1080p certain IS a concern - But things WILL get better. Xbox 360 had a LOT of issues in the beginning - way more than XBO is having.

For those who love the 360 this is a no-brainer. If you are a hardcore Xbox fan this will not disappoint (eventually). If you're a hardcore Playstation fan, well this won't win you over. Basically PS3 folks; get a PS4, and 360 folks, get a ONE.

There is no console war, just more of the same with some improvements. Jump in and enjoy the ride as things get better!

title: The new wave of video gaming & home entertainment
comment: If your into video gaming, then the future is here for you. Top line graphics and video game interaction. The games are only going to get better as time goes on and the programmers figure out the real power behind this processor. This will take you thru the next 6-7 years of video gaming and home entertainment!

title: Great New Technology!!!
comment:
The Xbox 1 is great! I love it! I can play games, watch TV, and control it all verbally. It's easy to snap a NetFlix program on the screen while waiting for the next match of COD to start. I can connect my PC to the HDMI passthrough and mirror my computer to my TV, Snap it! For another amazing feature you can control everything from your phone with the Smart Glass app. All these features create an awesome experience.
The not so great is that the software is buggy and at times there is lag and disconnects. The voice control is iffy but works when silent. Once all the kinks get worked out it will good.
One thought, why is the 360 market place so much more robust? I understand the game situation, but how about black Friday deals on the X1 for videos and possible arcade action. Let me play my old arcade games on the X1. Overall, I Love it.

comment: Gamer or not it's pretty cool to be able to have voice command of your entire TV setup. Decent game launch titles and after it adds some of the missing pieces it will be well worth the investment.

title: Great Gaming system

title: Awesome new gaming and entertainment system
comment: We bought this for our kids ages 10 and 7 since it seems to have more games for kids than Playstation. Really like how it is more than just a gaming platform - no issues yet but have heard some units have kinks. Hopefully Microsoft has updates to fix any problems that arise.

title: Overall, great entertainment all-in-one system
comment: All in all, I enjoy my Xbox One. I've been using voice controls for whatever I am able, and it works great. I do have issues occasionally when requesting specific channels, especially if it's my first time selecting that channel. For example, I may say "Watch CNBC" and Xbox takes me to AMC. But once I have selected CNBC through the controler it remembers that I like that channel and now recognizes my request. The only major issue I have with the system is the inability to access and control my DVR. Hopefully that is just a near-future software upgrade away.

title: Great System
comment: This system was easy to setup and has a ton of new features compared to the 360. kinect has a better view of the area without needing a zoom in small spaces. Gameplay graphics are amazing highly recommend!

title: Great entertainment center
comment: I was torn between the PS4 and the XBOX 1. I chose the XBOX because it is designed more as an entertainment center than just a game system. After a couple weeks, I think I made the right choice. Very quite in it's operation, that was important to me. Plays Blue Ray discs now, that was one of the turning point features. The ability to add pretty much any App I wanted, very important because I am one of the "cut the cord" people. Overall, very satisfied, so far.

title: Great Gaming System
comment: This system is leaps and bounds over the previous Xbox 360. It loads tremendously faster and the graphics are very lifelike. I am very pleased with the system even with the hefty price tag. I am hoping that more games are available soon as not many games are available thus far for the release. It also kind of stinks that the Xbox One is not backwards compatible with previous games. You can also not play the same game online with someone with an xbox 360. They must also have an xbox one to play online together with. Those are my only complaints!

title: Overall a very powerful gaming console
comment:
I got the Xbox one when it was first released and its been great so far. The gaming is flawless, integration with NFL, ESPN, and Skype are a definite plus. Not to mention the fact that you can record gameplay on the fly to show off your skills. Its also stupendous that I no longer need a remote to change my tv channel. As if it wasn't hard enough to find the remote and change the channel eh?

The only downside to this system that I can find aside from an old school VCR appearance is that the kinect sometimes has trouble hearing your voice which in turn leads to poor execution of some commands. I find myself yelling things out just to change the channel. Its fine its 2PM, but not too comforting to neighbors or family members if its 2am. However this is not ALWAYS the case as other times it works without an issue.

With new technology comes new challenges and I am sure MS will keep improving in its beloved kinect. If you are looking for something that brings together all of your components (TV, Cable Box, Audio Receiver, and Gaming) in harmony then the Xbox One should be your #1 choice here hands down.

title: Good, kinect voice needs some improvements.
comment: It is overall worth the money! The game play is amazing and quick. I love that I can switch from watching TV to my game in a flash! I would recommend this product!

title: Long battery life.
comment: Definitely a plus when it came to long lasting battery life. Is one of my needs and it deliver fast reboot speed. I would give it a 4/5.

title: Great Gaming System
comment: I think this is a great system and glad I bought it. I knew it was "all-in-one" but I thought that simply meant not having to switch TV inputs. I didn't realize this means the system will actually control your TV, cable/satellite box, and the home theater receiver. Kinect works a lot better than expected even when volume is turned up loud. I would definitely recommend rechargeable batteries as I went through the included controller batteries in just a few days. At launch, there is no way to manually manage save files (I believe an intended anti-piracy/modding measure), so it's weird you can't tell how much space you have left on your hard drive versus how much is actually stored in the online cloud. But this means you can sign on to other consoles without having to bring your memory stick which is a plus.

title: Love the Xbox one

title: Good, but not great

title: the unit is ok you can play both ps4 and xbox
comment: the xbox can be used like a dvr and eliminates remotes. the ps4 can also be plugged in and played at the same time as the xbox!

title: Next-gen is everything I hoped for and some
comment: Awesome graphics, awesome launch titles, better controller, and a better Kinect ... I don't miss my Xbox 360 at all. Definitely a step in the right direction for Microsoft.

title: Great console for everyone
comment: The Xbox co. Out did themselves this time. From gaming to entertainment this console delivers.

title: best gaming console out there
comment:
From the start the ease of setting up was great. The 2 games I have played so far, Ghost and Forza are incredible. The graphics and game speeds are terrific. It is as if it is real life and you are basically living a dream as you play. I cannot tell you how happy I am so far with the console that you can do so many more things with other than play games!!! It is truly the best console to have if you are a gamer or computer geek..... :)
Thanks --- looking forward to 2014 with my Xbox1........

title: Very pleased!
comment: I went from an I pad mini to this because I didn't like the size. I am happy now and it works great.

title: GREAT PRODUCT
comment: MY CHILDREN LOVE THE GAME.. BUT ITS NOT JUST A GAME. COMPUTER & ETC. A MUST HAVE

title: Changes livingroom experience!
comment: Slowing starting to prefer XBOX over Playstation, we will see!

title: Very impressive media center
comment: I have to say, I'm more impressed with the Xbox One than I expected to be. I knew when I bought it that it would play games, but I didn't realize the extent of the full media control that was available. Being able to control our TV and movie watching, hands-free, is one of my favorite features. And when we're done, a simple voice command turns everything off. I almost never have to touch a remote control.

title: awesome content.
comment: I love the Skype ability and the ability to give the xbox one commands. The graphics are fantastic. I also love the fact I can do things with the internet without having to leave my xbox.

title: My Son Loves the New Xbox One
comment: My son loves his new Xbox one. It was easy to set up and he hasn't had any problems with it. He likes that you can tell the Xbox to change to the TV using voice commands. The only major problem with the new Xbox is that all the old Xbox games we have don't work on the new system. I think it is ridiculous that you have to buy all new games considering the money we have already spent on games. They will allow you to exchange some of the games and pay a $10 upgrade fee which is nice since several of the games we had were brand new. Still, they should make the games backwards compatible (hence 4 out of 5 stars).

title: love the touch features
comment: Light weight. big screen, good price and organizer

title: The NEXT GEN IS HERE!!!
comment: Xbox One Really feels New, New dashboard easy to get use to and the Games look amazing compare to the Xbox 360 it really is a next step on Gaming. the apps are all there but the downfall on Xbox One right now not as much games as you would wish it could have and the Kinect Voice command tends to lag at times but not worry because software updates are bound to be release later on. Other then that the Xbox One is a must have for old and New gamers.

title: A solid foundation for a full entertainment system
comment:
A great system, nothing currently compares. The XBOX One is what they say it is, a complete entertainment system. It seamlessly integrates into social media, TV (through my FIOS box) web browsing, Bluray and DVD watching, netflix and other streaming media apps... and don't forget the games are far superior to what's been available so far.

This is designed for the person who doesn't necessarily focus on gameplay, but wants to integrate all their media into one location, that can be controlled through motion, remote or voice.

The motion is leaves a lot to be desired as I spend a lot of my time trying to land "perfectly" on the right icon of effect, so I've decided not to use it. I control all my media components by voice and I haven't really had a problem yet.

title: Slow Load times But good unit
comment: Fired up my Xbox one and went through all the day one updates that took really long due to overloaded servers. Then I popped in my Forza disk and waited and waited and waited over 10 minutes to even "START" to play. I played for over 30 minute only to find that the game was still not fully installed. Let the console sit installing for ~15 minutes and the game was only at 80% installed. If everytime you get a new game you have to wait 30 minutes just to play it that will stink. You can pop a disk in a PS4 and play in ~30 seconds.. For having the disk local you think in game load times would be short.. Not the case 2-3 minutes between races to load. Kinect is not without issues but the real value will be determined in games that utilize the features. When Sports comes out I will re-update on the kinect as of right now not impressed.

title: Great phone
comment: I like the larger screen without having a larger phone. It is easy to use.

title: Excellent video game player with mutiple fuctions!
comment: Excellent video game player with mutiple fuctions!

I didn't think I would use it that much other than for gaming but I have it hooked up to my cable box and it works awesome for watching tv.
