comment: The Xbox One is a great new gaming console. It is a little bulky (about the size of a VCR) but seems to be built very well. Easy to set up. Best feature is the ability to use Kinect to control your cable box (eg. change channels by swiping your hand)

title: Next Gen game play and entertainment.
comment: This black box is the ultimate in entertainment. It can control your Tv and cable/satellite box. You can play a game and watch TV on the same screen. The voice commands and motion controls are spot on with the kinect (which is optional). It now has a Bluray player and it's super quiet when playing games. The controller feels much better than the 360's controller because the battery pack is now inside the controller instead of protruding out of the back. I honestly can't think of anything bad to say about the xbox one, even when compared to the PS4. I'd comfortably recommend this to anyone.

title: Great console. User friendly.
comment: The Xbox One is everything I hoped for. Fun for the whole family. Great content, graphics and easy to use. Can't wait for more games!

title: Great new console!
comment:
I've had a Xbox One and PS4 pre-ordered since their announcement on June 10th and so far I am loving every second of it! Great piece of hardware, and the new games looks AWESOME! The kinect is extremely accurate and a lot of fun as well.

The TV functionality is the only downside currently. It DOES work for controlling your TV, Cable/Satellite box, Audio receiver ETC but it doesn't have any DVR controls currently. Hopefully that gets added soon. You can of course use the remote for your satellite/cable box for DVR functions for the time-being to get around that issue.

Overall, great system and fun to use!

title: Graphics = WOW!
comment: Been playing the new Dead Rising and some sports ... all I can say is wow. What an improvement in game play speed, graphics, and sound. Can't wait to see new titles coming out.

title: Lots of features
comment: I bought this in store on day of release. I took it out of the box and set it up. I got stuck on the home screen and couldn't originally figure out how to get into the system. I finally figured out to hit the home button. I haven't had a chance to use all features, but it does appear as though you have to download all games before playing. So far the gameplay seems more realistic and I know the features once I figure them out will be great, but initially it is difficult to figure out.

title: greatest counsel ever
comment: Awesome gaming counsel. I bought one for me and one for my son!

title: Amazing Game Play
comment: Amazing graphic for game play and video. I like the fact that the xbox one now include blu-ray player.

title: Next gen console is pretty freaking cool!
comment: I picked up my One on launch day and set it up the next day. After a few minutes setting everything up, I was amazed at how intuitive many of the functions were. Voice commands are awesome, the apps are really cool and the games I've played have been incredible. I am very pleased with my purchase to date!

title: Awesome Console
comment: Everything is nice and what you would expect from a next gen console. Voice recognition doesn't work very well for me but I don't know if that is me or the Xbox. I often have to say commands 2-3 times for the Xbox to recognize anything.

title: Fun System, Not Enough to do Yet
comment: Xbox One is a really great system. I just wish they had more items online like the Xbox Arcade titles. There really isn't that much available yet and only a handful of games.

title: Fantastic product for the money
comment: i would recommend this to anyone who loves gaming, video games or blu rays.

title: Great product, but too soon?
comment: Overall, this product is great. The graphics are much better than previous generations...as they should be. The controllers feel great and are even more responsive than the 360's. The only downfall to this console is the new headset port and the fact that we are all waiting on Dolby surround support out of the optical cable. Thus is huge if you own a high end gaming headset like I do. Until they release an adapter for the talking portion and the software update to include Dolby surround support, this product is not complete for me.

title: The technology behind this product is incredible!
comment: Okay love this product! We are all happy with this console it's to best hands down. Far exceeding my expectations and fun for everyone I the family.

title: Great Console
comment: Love the new xbox, I love being able to talk to it!

title: Cool product
comment: It was extremely disappointing not to be able to play after we stayed up for the midnight purchase. Not sure if it is worth the price yet.

title: Love this system
comment: Love this gaming system, amazing games, great graphics,My son and I love playing it. Highly recommend it.

title: Excellent for Everyone!
comment: The Xbox One is excellent, and makes a great gift for anyone who has never owned a video game console.

title: Great System
comment: The system is great! Voice command and the skype is my new bestfriend. The graphics and gameplay is phenomenal.

title: Nice device
comment: This was purchased as a gift for a 22 yr old female user. She loves it! It has good call quality, takes nice photos, and has the Android apps needed.

title: Great computer for anyone
comment:
My previous laptop had a short life of 2-3 years. My dad ended up going to get me a Toshiba Touch Screen last weekend, and that was a nightmare for the last week. We went back last night and returned that and purchased the MacBook Air. It is on the higher level of an amount of money, but it is worth every penny. If you don't have the money now for one, save up, do not waste it on any other computer/laptop.

This computer is fast and easy to set up, it's quick, has a long battery life, and is perfect for a student or professional.

I have had use of Apple products before with a local school I work for, and everything is going to Apple for students and staff to use. So, I had to jump on the band wagon, and I do not regret it at all.

I am very happy with this purchase, it is an investment.

title: Aw
comment: It's a great item easy to use and light I love apple products

title: More than enough apps and uses for daily use
comment: It's a little overwhelming for my use, but I'm learning to use a lot of options I wasn't aware of.

title: Best Console Out Right Now!
comment: Best console out right now. Great controller, great exclusives, kinect, and great graphics. I had PS1 and PS2 when Xbox came out i switched over and have not looked back. Xbox, Xbox 360 and now Xbox One i am team Xbox for life.

title: Great entertainment center
comment: The new Xbox is a good entertainment center, I can change channels or play games seamlessly.

title: Love it! Great fun!
comment: Really love it! The first game I got for it was Assassins Creed: Black Flag. And it looks amazing on the Xbox One! The Kinect is really fun too.

title: Xbox one is #1
comment: I highly recommend getting the Xbox one for anyone who is an avid gamer. Great games, visuals and tv controls. Plus, a whole lot more!

title: Amazing system!!! Incredible media device!
comment: The Xbox one over all is an amaIng machine. It's all in one media capabilities make it around out against the ps4. The hardware and graphics might not be as impressive as the ps4 but the exclusive title are definitely much better than Sony's! I am looking forward to the future of this generation to see what the Xbox one is truly capable of!

title: Thanks to fate!!
comment: Well kind of let fate decide which next gen I'll buy....... sure glad it was Xbox. Started with all Xbox and then went to ps3 due to Blu-ray, glad I'm back to Xbox. The HDMI in is great for me and the TV feature is nice once they finish working out the bugs. LIVE is way ahead of PlayStations network and achievements on Xbox are like crack to me, Playstion's trophies system is horrid. Looking for a next gen, go XBOX!

title: Great Potential!!
comment: This system will be very awesome once more software becomes available. Do notice a graphics improvement from 360 titles of same game though. Kinect voice commands and gestures right now are alittle sketchy, hopefully a software update will improve them. I also did not like that I had to download the blu-ray player before I could watch a movie.(not sure how that works if you don't have internet)

title: Great entertain system
comment: Great all in one entertainment system. I would absolutely recommend

title: great system with lots of features
comment: System is good although not a lot of games for it. The ones that are out are pretty cool

title: Great cutting edge piece of hardware
comment:
Great console with lots of positives and a couple of issues in need of an update. Overall performance is very good and the quality of launch games is decent...if not great...with a little of something for everyone.

The interactivity of the console is really cool...and something that anyone can set up and use in a matter of minutes.

It does have a couple of flaws..but they are things that were similar issues on early 360s..and can easily be remedied thru downloadable updates. One is..the controller has amazing battery life..something like 20+ hrs..but no way to gauge it. The other is...there is no way to see or manage your HD storage..except to look at individual items and add or remove them individually.

Also, there is a learning curve with the system and virtually no manual to explain how things work.

All that aside...both the console and controller are of superb quality..and performance is nothing short of fantastic.

Another hidden value is the availability of 300000 cloud servers, and dedicated servers for all Xbox One games. That is something that is not available on any other console, and is worth the price difference alone over the PS4..in my opinion.

Being an owner of both a 360 and a PS3..I actually pre purchased both consoles months ago. After trying and comparing both..the X1 is the only one still in my possession...and I think that's saying a lot! The build quality..overall performance..and availability of launch titles makes it a no brainer. The Xbox One is the console to own...now..and for the forseeable future.

title: xbox one is a have to have
comment: It is better then PS4. It helps my husband with his PTSD from War.. It is a have to have.

title: great game system
comment: brought it for my son for X-mas so have not played it yet, but he will be happy.

title: X box
comment: Bought for christmas present for a teenager wanted only this for christmas easy choice

title: Another Great Apple
comment: Been a long time Mac user as always easy set up, love the light weight and stream line design of this computer. The screen graphics are crystal clear the processor is really fast.

title: Xbox One
comment: I haven't had the system long enough to really put it through its paces but so far so good. I wish they had more games available but know it's just a matter of time.

title: One great console to cater for my family's needs
comment: So far I am extremely excited with the Xbox One, new controller with impulse triggers and the much improved Kinect 2.0. The launch titles are not that great to showcase the horse power under the console's hood but they will evolve over time. Currently I'm player Battlefield 4 and FIFA14 which I'm hooked on to. The kinect sensor is magical and recognizes me and my wife in an instant everytime, more so it recognizes my wife quicker than me ;-/ She has been enjoying the Kinect sports and most importantly Kinect fitness with daily challengers and tons of great fat burner and kickboxing routines that are a great workout. So far I'm having a blast with the new Xbox One console and looking forward to play some great titles.

title: Much more than just a console.
comment: The Xbox One and PS4 are both stellar consoles. I have played both and to be honest the Xbox One is the game system I highly recommend. I love gadgets and apps and TV and to be able able to flow easily from one to another using one device is amazing. If you like to interact with online friends, play with the family, entertainment along with video games the Xbox One was made for you. PS4 is great as well but one thing that kept me from purchasing one for myself was the PS Network $49.99/year membership they now charge it's users. No way am I going to pay for two online accounts.

title: great console
comment: great for a present for anyone great graphics and controls

title: Great gaming system
comment: This is the best Xbox system to date. I've owned them all. The kinect has been greatly improved from the last version. I like the exclusive games that can only be found on the XBOX console like Ryse and I believe Titan Fall. Overall, I love how you can now play blu ray movies, one quick app download and you're ready to go. I would highly recommend this to anyone looking for some entertainment at home.

title: The best console ever!
comment: It can control your TV and surround sound turning all on or off at the same time! Features an IR blaster on the rear for future functionality... can't wait to see what! The new kinect is really great! With Xbox live subscription you get the fitness app which basically turns your xbox into a personal trainer for workouts! Super fast and responsive system. Games are great for 1st gen.... nothing special yet but the potential is there for some great games next year! If you want more than a game machine (PS4) this is definitely for you! If you only want a game system and none of the other multimedia junk then go with the PS4. Personally I like the multimedia functions and find it to be much better than just a game system.

title: interactive and great games
comment: this machine is amazing! great controller, awesome graphics, runs so seamlessly my only dislike is that it can take forever to install a game before you can even play it. but otherwise its a great entertainment system

title: XBox One
comment: I love the many features this console has. Everything from playing games to browsing the internet and watching movies! This is a great console for the whole family to use!

title: An Intriguing High-Tech Entertainment Device
comment: I purchased the Xbox One mainly because of the PS4's lack of multimedia features (DLNA, etc.# although I'm sure a firmware update will add that functionality later. Both systems are pretty much equal in terms of hardware with the exception of the ability of the Xbox One to process incoming video/audio via its HDMI In port. I'm excited by the ability to watch sports with realtime information superimposed over the games I'm watching along with the ability to perform multiple tasks concurrently #play a game and have a web session open looking for strategies for said videogame). Overall I'm very impressed with what Microsoft has created. BTW I also purchased a Playstation 4 as I feel it too has its own distinct advantages. You can't go wrong with either system!

title: Worht the wait
comment: Really enjoying my first couple of weeks playing my new sytem. there is a need for some more games available. Price should be more in line with PS4

title: Little BIG but i made space
comment: Sure it's huge and there is a seperate power supply, which is pretty big too. System plays great, very smooth responsive. Controller almost like the old version(360) but much needed upgrade. Buttons feel better, over all very familiar controller. The whole smart tv type interface is ok, seems to work. Voice commands, well works most of the time but needs more work.

title: Awesome Gaming System
comment: I am sure the technology and the components that makes it so pricey, are well worth every dollar.

title: I don't like it
comment: I think it's a good console but when you compare it to the ps4 it's more expensive and less powerful. Then when you compare it to the Wiiu it's more powerful but all its games are pretty much the same, and the Wiiu is better for playing with family. I just don't see the point in getting this where its price is at now.

title: If you are on the fence, buy this system.
comment: When I got this home I couldn't wait to play. I was not let down. This system can perform many tasks at the click of a button or by voice control. The exclusive games I picked up are great. Forza, Killer Instinct, Ryse, Dead Rising 3 and soon Titan Fall. The line up of games coming is great. I'm glad Xbox decided to take a chance and push up the bar. This system has many great years ahead and it can only get better. I love that I can watch a NFL game, play a game, while tracking my fantasy football. The tv functionality is great, However make sure you have surround sound to lip sync your tv. This is normal, as I had to do this with my surround sound in the first place. So fare Xbox live has been smooth and very attractive. It runs very quit. I think Xbox has made a very special product, Kinect 2.0 is great to use, I can record in game actions with a simple voice command. Great to upload and let other Xbox friends see your domination of a game. Can't wait for Kinect Sports to launch.

title: omg
comment: I've had it for 2 weeks ..it has a bit of a learning curve. once you get over the hump..be ready for some great entertainment and multi tasking..you will be doing stuff not because you need too but because you can..yes feel the power...I do wish I had access to my xbox arcade at launch.. called to inquire coming in a future update...omg..xbox by choice..gamer for life...

title: Xbox One is a solid machine for the future
comment:
Before purchasing, I wanted to see some reviews and try both the xbone and ps4. I went with the xbone because I think xbox live is a better user interface than PSN. Another big reason is the Microsoft cloud support,. I wasn't crazy about having to pay for the kinect because I didn't think I'd ever use it. However, the more I use the kinect, the more I like it. What I like best about it is it can be used interactively in game.

An example is while playing BF4 I can say "medic" or "I need ammo" to the kinect and my soldier will repeat it in game.....pretty cool. I'm sure this will only get more innovative and supported as games continue to evolve. This is something that the ps4 can't do right now.

I do think the ps4 has slightly better graphics but it's very slight. If you play on a tv smaller than 50" I don't think you'll even notice. It's not near enough to overcome the user experience that the xbone provides. It's just a more advanced system for the future and the gap will only widen over time. With the cloud support dedicated servers are going to be abundant for just about every game.

title: I love the MAC and all it's products.
comment: Okay the sound, clarity, and lit keypad is dope! The only thing I am only thing that takes time to get use to is there is no HOME/END key for help with movement (I used tab, and shift, and control keys a lot from my PC and it's taking time to get used to those keys not being there). Also, no 10 key pad buts it's still numbers at the top. From a Toshiba for almost 6 years I decided that it was time to upgrade. I am hoping to not buy a computer again for at least 3-5 years. I now have an Apple collection. iPad, iPhone, and now the MacBook Air. Great price on Black Friday for $950. And I felt is was worth the extra $600 for a 3 year warranty. I am careful but you just never know what will happen.

title: Awesome
comment: def the all-in-one entertainment console!!!! only downside is its not backwards compatible.....yet.

title: Amazing system!
comment: I strongly recommend this Xbox One console. The debate between Microsoft and Sony will forever stand, but the Xbox One holds its ground.

title: Awesome
comment: Love EVERYTHING about it. Love the ruble triggers. Kinect recognizes who to log in automatically. Xb1 can control cable box and tv. Apps are awesome especially NFL.

title: not a good system
comment: I Bought an xbox an xbox one but it was a waste of money. I recomend you guys the ps4.

title: Good but could be great...
comment: I am glad that I have it but I am upset that it is not backwards compatible and the fact I cannot play with friends that have the 360. Setting up a party with friends is tough and party invites are a pain. The voice control is tough and the use of the controller can be a pain. All these things can and I am sure will get better with updates other than the LB and RB button on the controller.

title: Great system
comment: The Xbox One is great for gamers and casual people too. Being able to have all my devices go through one input on tv is convenient and efficient. The controller is great and the subtle upgrades from 360 controller are nice. Being able to use my Xbox as universal remote is great. The downside is occasionally not every device turns on and off properly but just minor hiccup that happens rarely. The battery life of controllers is good. Overall a very nice system.

title: Just what I expected
comment: Really solid console, just one step down on graphics, but I'm sure game developers are working on it. Great browsing experience much better than PS4, voice command yet to be improved, but really cool.

title: Great system
comment: I purchased both systems (ps4 & x one) I fine myself playing the xbox more than the ps4. It's feature of watching tv and playing the game is great. The xbox also turns on all of your equipment for you as well. All you do is say "xbox on" and my tv, surround sound, and cable box goes on. Say xbox off and everything goes off. Of course you must program these settings. The kinect is Awsome you can use it in complete darkness because of the infrared camera.

title: It's a great entertainment center
comment: Xbox One seems to be great so far. The only negative is the amount of time it takes to install the xbox games (hours) for one game.

title: Xbox One Rocks!
comment: Ive owned both the X1 and PS4 and I love the Xbox 1 great features very innovative the PS4 bored me in a day nothing new its like they're not even trying. Xbox is hooked to my cable box turns my tv, cable box, audio, on/off with no hiccups voice commands work great, controller is sleek and comfortable happy with my purchase!

title: Will be the One, eventually
comment: While the graphics of the heretofore small library are outstanding, the functionality and the look-and-feel of the Xbox One show little deviation from its predecessor, the Xbox 360. Not all the services promised are available (i.e. old game streaming service), and with such a small library of games at launch, there is no rush to buy this system. In about 6 months, this system may be worth it's value and this reviewer might consider adding an extra star, but for now, stick to the 360's massive library of games and similar functionality.

title: Great Next Gen Console
comment:
I love my new console. The graphics of the next gen games are fantastic. I highly recommend NBA 2K14, it's not just a slight upgrade from the 360 version, its like a brand new game. One of the best examples of the new graphics. Don't bother with COD:Ghosts if you've played it for 360, there's no real difference. Highly recommend Ryse: Son of Rome as well, very short, but very good.

I didn't think I would use the voice commands as much as I do, but they're great. Really easy to get used to. I would have liked a list of commands out of the box because its kind of tough to navigate if you don't know what to say. Highly recommend using the training they provide you with on the console. Helps with some of the basic commands. Definitely research some commands online, some of the features need the voice commands or are much easier with them. (Hint: one voice command they don't teach you in the training that is very useful, when you snap an app and you want to control the main screen again, say "Xbox Switch") The new Kinect features are awesome, my roommate will walk in my room to play games and it recognizes him immediately.

One issue I do have is that when I bring my Xbox One without the Kinect sensor to a friends house (and lets be honest, you shouldn't bring one anyway, two Kinect sensors on two consoles trying to process one voice command....bad idea!), you have to manually sign in by typing in your credentials, you can't save your credentials because they are linked to the Kinect sign in. That's weird, but only a small annoyance. Another problem with playing with out Kinect is it kind of renders the in game dvr features unusable. Again, small annoyance that will not occur while you have the Kinect plugged in.

The cloud storage for game saves is a cool new feature. My buddy restored his whole console but when he put in the games after setting up the console again they just loaded up his saves (he had some issues with his Kinect setup, it can be finicky during the setup, mine had no issues but i have heard online about a few people having Kinect issues).

Highly recommend the Xbox One.

title: Not much of a "Media Center" that Microsoft boasts
comment:
Ok, I picked up the Xbox one and I consider myself a casual gamer at best. My previous console is the PS3 which was great. Prior to that, was the monstrosity 360 which I was a 3 time victim of the RROD. After the warranty expired, my 3rd RROD, Microsoft basically said tough.

So, that's why I went to the PS3. But, the ALL IN ONE NEDIA CENTER that the One is tinkering with lured me back. So, the visuals on the game seem great for my one game (Battlefield 4) and I'm confident as the years pass by. That the PS4's graphics will not BLOW OUT the Ones.....though I'm sure it will be slightly better as it has more graphics horsepower.

Voice control on the kinect is about 75%. Seems like I'm finding myself reaching for the controller more often than not. This is because the Kinect doesn't seem to understand me the 1st or 2nd time. So I find it quicker to use the controller. Hopefully this will be improved as it's a major part of the ALL IN ONE thing Microsoft is touting.

Sometimes the ONE won't even turn on my system (game and TV) or it takes 4 times to do it. When it does turn on, I find it VERY annoying that it goes right to the HOME screen as opposed to full screen TV. I'd rather it go right to full TV than the home screen. This is because I use my TV primarily for TV rather than gaming. It would be nice if Microsoft gave the user this option. I find myself annoyed that I'm forced to switch to full TV screen mode with the controller....because it's easier than using the voice control at this point.

Only other option to keep my TV in full screen mode is to keep my ONE always on and waste electricity. So, if Microsoft improves on the Kinect and the other annoying issues that keep the Kinect and main box from feeling like its ONE PERFECTLY INTIGRATED machine...I think it would be a fantastic success. Right now, it feels like the Kinect and the main box DO NOT mesh very well.

Update 12/17/13

Voice control will NOT turn on system via "Xbox On" voice command and TV picture freezes which you need to do a hard reboot to correct. This all started after the first update xbox just recently put out. Unacceptable for this to happen to a system that boasts being a media center machine. ONE STAR until they fix this.

title: Great System!
comment:
I purchased the Xbox One on it's release day and now that I've had some time to play around with it, I decided to write my review. I'm quite impressed by the system, especially that it lets you instantly stop one thing and flip to another, like going from a game to TV. Microsoft finally put a Blu-Ray player in the system too, which is an added bonus.

It's a bit unfortunate they basically got rid of the Arcade, as I thought that was the 360's best option. While there is still a place to download games, it's just not the same and a bit confusing to navigate at first.

While I have all three new systems, Wii U, Xbox and PS4, I would recommend the Xbox to someone that wants more of a Media Center system.

title: Awesome all-in-one system!
comment:
For the record, I'm just an ordinary guy who likes playing games. I'm not a techie, I don't do this for a living, just your everyday, run of the mill gamer.

Overall it's a great system! The games are beautiful, even at high speeds. The Windows 8 OS looks brilliant and makes things easy to find. The pinning is a very nice touch, it allows a player to truly make the system their own.

Hardware: I'm not going to get into the specs, but the actual hardware is beautiful. It is a very low profile piece of machinery, the black with white lighted accents adds to any decor. It is no bigger than your average cable box from your satellite or cable provider. The controls have a unique feeling to them, that can only be described as "nice"! And the controller's rumble triggers really bring games to life! The kinect uses some impressive tech, to take your gaming experience to the next level, with it's facial recognition to sign in and the ability to use you voice to do an array of things! The Xbox One is pretty quiet, if not for the lights, you could forget it's even on, which is a plus. None of the power buttons are raised, they all flush with the system and powering on resembles using a touch screen device. It was a breeze to set up, 2 cables, power and one to the TV. The power source is still rather bulky, but they have made it lighter, smaller, and a joy to look at.

Software: As I said earlier, it uses the Windows 8 OS, and the windows explorer makes use of the much needed flashplayer. I will not discuss the specifics, as I am no computer science, or software major. It comes with an impressive 500GB of memory, which will be needed once you start buying games, because the Xbox One downloads the entire game to your console, however, you still need the actual disc to play. The store on the Xbox One is great, music, TV shows, and games, all at the push of a button. There are really cool apps to download, pretty much all of the major apps are available, such as Hulu plus, netflix, redbox, FOX, the CW and soooooooo many more! It comes stock with some very useful apps, such as snap, where you can have a type of picture in picture, where you can do two things at once, be it watch TV and play a game, or surf the web and watch TV, or whatever combination you can think of. I was a little disappointed in the functionality of the OneGuide and TV viewing. You can plug your cable box in and it automatically detects what it is, until it doesn't. I believe my box was manufactured in 2008, which is older, granted, but it works perfectly, just not with the Xbox One. I couldn't the console to operate my box, or television, as promised. I was quite frustrated. But I just decided not to use my box and console in tango until either I update to a new box, or Microsoft pushes out a new update to make older items work. But the things the Xbox One could do with my television and cable box SOUND awesome, if you are fortunate to make these items works in concert, then I would recommend it! Using the kinect and the stock app Upload, you can record game clips with your voice or with the in game DVR, and then share it, which is very cool!

Highlights: Voice Control
Facial Recognition
Beautful Graphics and Beautuful Design
Awesome Functionality
Great Apps
Hours Upon Hours of Fun
A Joy to Have For Any and Everyone

Shortcomings: Compatibility with any and all televisions as well as cable/satellite boxes
I shouldn't have to wait long for a game to load when the entire game is saved to the console.
You would think that such a futuristic system that acts like a computer would be able to not only recognize, but view, extract, play, and add things to an external hard drive. And oh by the way, the Xbox One is made by Microsoft, a computer software/hardware giant!

Quite the piece of machinery if you ask me, I am very pleased with my purchase and wouldn't even think of taking it back or getting rid if it. The good definetly overshadows the bad in my opinion. I hope this was helpful! Now get the Xbox One and get gaming! You'll thank yourself later, and others will thank you as well.

title: So much FUn
comment: I was so excited for the new console to come out. Had a hard time finding the console. But since I've got it I have loved it. I haven't had any complains about it so far other than lack of games.

title: Love this Xbox
comment: Overall a great product I would rate it a 9 out of 10 would definitely recommend

title: Good, potentially great.
comment:
Potentially, this has the ability to be a game changer.

As of right now, it is clear that MS wants to nose its way into your living room, and it wants to step right in between the path of your DirecTV/cable box and and your TV...literally. I'll get more into that shortly...

The box itself is not entirely different than the Xbox consoles of the past. Kind of big, kind of bulky, but it's really not that big of a deal. Yes, there is a power brick, but again, I'm not going to let that keep me from buying a console. The console, when on, makes no sound what so ever. I've been very impressed with the length of time it takes to turn itself on and my other components. The IR blaster generally does what it's supposed to do - turn on the Xbox One along with the Kinect, the TV, the Onkyo receiver, and the DirecTV DVR. You enter the model numbers for your components when you first set up your console, and you shouldn't have to do it again. "Xbox On" and "Xbox Turn off" do the job for all of your components.

The item that has been making all the news has been the live TV integration. This aspect is the most impressive and maddening all at the same time. It is very cool to be able to have your friends come over, and you just use your voice to say, "Xbox volume up," "Xbox watch ESPN," "Xbox Turn Off," etc., it have your guests' jaws drop. It's also maddening that you can give some of the same commands and occasionally just get ignored, at which point, your wife just shakes her head and wonders aloud, "what's so great about this again?" It's also mildly frustrating that some channels like "ESPN U" and "Disney Junior" cannot be accessed by voice; so that means that your DirecTV/Cable remote cannot go that far away. Let the record indicate that I just found out last night after having had this for since "Day One" that the d-pad on the controller can be used to go channel up or channel down. That certainly lessens the need for the DirecTV/Cable remote to be around at all times. The "Xbox One Guide" is a glorified alternative to your existing on-screen guide. I don't know exactly yet how to use my voice to tell it to tune to a particular channel from the guide, but the page up/page down commands work very well through the "One Guide."

A second question I had about TV integration was going to be the picture quality when passing through the Xbox One. It turns out that it looks really good, and 99% of the time, it's flawless. The only time I notice anything amiss is when I'm paying attention to the "ESPN Bottom Line" - the scroll bar at the bottom of any ESPN channel. Every once in a blue moon I notice a little judder effect on the text as it scrolls. It's still very readable, and after a few seconds, it corrects itself, but it's occasionally noticeable. The actual TV content is excellent in terms of picture quality. One tip for you if you have a cable/satellite box that allows you to alter your resolution from 720p to 1080i or vice versa, then go ahead a pick one that you think is best and avoid a "native" mode at all costs. (Personally, I like 1080i the most between the two, but your opinion may vary). The reason I say that is because the Xbox takes a few seconds to go from one resolution to the other, and it's noticeably longer than it is when the signal is going directly from cable/satellite box to TV. The good news is that the signal, regardless of the resolution you choose, is getting upconverted to 1080p anyway. For the record 3D signals do not pass through from the DirecTV DVR through the Xbox and to the TV. The TV will now give you the "Your TV does not support 3D" message if you pass through the Xbox. Either have a second HDMI connection directly from your cable/satellite box to your TV, or give Microsoft some time to correct this issue. We never use 3D, much like most of America; so I suspect this will not impact you at all.

One negative that does affect me slightly is that, at this moment, Dolby 5.1/7.1 is not supported output via optical cable, only DTS. I have HDMI connected, and Dolby 5.1/7.1 is supported via HDMI, but my audio receiver is slightly older, and it only passes through the video signal, not audio, thus my having to use optical. Many of you will not have to worry about this at all, but my rear speakers go unused in regular TV watching for 7.1. There is supposed to be an Xbox update coming soon that will address this issue. If your HDMI carries both audio and video for you, then you can ignore this paragraph. If you rely on optical, then know that audio during gameplay is 7.1 (stunningly good, by the way), but TV watching is DTS (soon to be updated/upgraded).

The Kinect sensor is really cool as far as I can tell in gameplay. The only games I have are Battlefield 4, Madden NFL 25, NBA 2k14, and Forza 5. I don't have any full-blown motion games that really take advantage of being able to detect your movements. In gameplay, the only real tests I've given the Kinect have been to audible in Madden (very accurate), holler "throw grenade" in Battlefield (excellent), and use profanity in NBA 2K14 (which appropriately gets you T'd up!). I do know the Kinect camera is very clear, and it does a pretty good job of picking up people in the room and associating their gamer pic with them. I get the customary "Hi, Sarfdawg" every time it sees me.

On to the reason you bought this...the actual gameplay...

Graphically, it is noticeably improved over the Xbox 360 for Battlefield, Forza, and NBA 2k14. If fact, those three games are stunningly good. The attention to detail on all of those games is remarkable, particularly in Forza and NBA 2K14. I think Battlefield was already amazing on the 360 version because it was made at the tail end of the life cycle for the 360 and on the front end of the Xbox One life cycle.

This doesn't have a whole lot to do with the Xbox One console itself, but EA should be embarrassed by the Madden product they produced for the Xbox One. I had the 360 version of Madden and traded up to get the Xbox One version, and to say that it's a direct port from the 360 version would be an insult to the 360 version. Many of the cool things about the 360 version were mysteriously left out of the Xbox One version, particularly the pregame intro videos that were on the 360. Beyond that, the best thing that can be said about the Xbox One Madden is that it's the only football game going on Xbox One. I presume that subsequent year's versions will be better as EA figures out how to utilize the graphical power of the Xbox One. Forza and NBA 2K14 need to be automatic purchases as they are clearly made for this console and show off it's power. I'm not even a big NBA fan, and I strongly recommend it just for showing off the console itself.

If you owned the 360 version from its inception (2005 or 2006, I can't remember), then you know the games got much better as its life cycle got longer. I suspect that a year, two years from now, the games on the Xbox One will be out of this world. I'm not at all a PC gamer, so you folks may just snicker at that comment. But, for me as an occasional console gamer, I think the Xbox One has its best days in front of them for a long while.

Microsoft has promised many updates to fix some of the issues that are cropping up, and I have no reason to doubt them. They made good on many of the issues that plagued the 360, and they have not been passed on to the Xbox One. As minor as the issues are on the Xbox One, I have no reason to believe that they won't address them as they did on the Xbox 360. I've read Cnet and others say that you should wait to get the Xbox One and the PS4 for that matter. I'm not entirely sure why you should punish yourself and wait. The updates are all streamed down through the internet, and there is no talk of improving hardware in future iterations at all. If you want one now, get one. Be patient and enjoy it for what it is. You will enjoy it straight out of the box, and I feel certain you can rest assured this will only get better.

If I think of anything else that would be pertinent, I will update as we go. Feel free to ask questions as you wish. Hopefully, you have found this helpful. Merry Christmas, all.

title: Pricey, but worth the leap to next-gen gaming
comment:
It's been 8 years since the release of the Xbox 360. The wait has been the longest in the industry for a new generation of hardware and now that it's finally here, the decision as to whether you should commit to that shiny new console can seem a bit overwhelming.

The first thing to understand is the Xbox One's launch software has more in common with the previous generation because many of the cross-platform games like Battlefield 4 and Call of Duty Ghosts were developed with the lowest system requirements in mind (read: PS3 and Xbox360). Many of the games don't show the true potential of the system just yet, but there are still a number of factors that should sway you to make that leap to getting the console.

The Xbox One offers some features never attempted in console gaming before. Integration of television services, streaming of digital content, DVR for game sessions, Skype from your living room and the comfort of your couch. All of these features are part of what makes the Xbox One different from the rest of the console gaming crowd. The Kinect 2.0 camera is another feature that sets the system apart from consoles like the PS4 since it is standard with the console and makes up a large part of the additional $100 over the price of the PS4. The extra $100 is easily justified since the Kinect integrates everything unlike any other gaming console before it and you have to see it in action to appreciate it.

As mentioned above, the first wave of software is not as impressive as many would have liked, but there are still some shining examples of next-gen quality graphics in Forza Motorsport 5, Killer Instinct and Ryse: Son of Rome, which is hands-down the best looking game on any console! Rest assured, as we enter the new year, the justification for getting that new console will become more apparent with developers shifting to making their games specifically for the Xbox One and they learn to code games more efficiently for the console to make them look and play better than ever before.

If you are looking for that next-generation system, and if you are looking for a console that breaks tradition and does something a bit different, then the Xbox One is the console you should be considering right now!

title: This is a great notebook!
comment:
I converted to a Mac last year when my company started offering us a choice that included Macs. My first Mac is a MacBook Air and here are reasons why I would recommend the Air:

1. Battery life is incredible! I can easily get 12-14 hours of actual usage before it needs to be charged. Plus the charging is also very quick. I am getting better battery use out of the Air than most tablets out there.

2. The machine is fast and silent! I love the instant on and off. This has more to do with how the Mac OS works, but still it makes a difference. It literally is as fast to turn on and off as a tablet, but you have all the power of a 13 inch laptop.

3. The keyboard and mouse are simply great. There is no other notebook or tablet keyboard that can come close. The mouse on this is incredible and the multiple touch works flawlessly.

4. I really like the Mac OS. I like how easy everything is and there are no annoying pop ups asking me to update this and that on a continuous basis. Plus unlike my windows laptops it doesn't slow down and I don't need to do any maintenance on the software to make it run smoothly all the time.

5. Love the design and build quality. Very minimalist and classy looking.

Bug and other issues:

1. As someone has pointed out, the laptop can randomly go to sleep and requires a hard reset to wake. It's happened to me a couple of time. But in both cases no info was lost and it takes only around 30 seconds to wake from a full reset (if not less). My guess is that this is a bug due to the aggressive battery savings built in. It only happens when you are not connected.

Others:

2. The screen isn't retina so the MacBook Pro with retina may appeal more to some. However, the screen quality is pretty good since it has sub pixel smoothing and other enhancements that make text look sharper. This sort of optimization can only be done on a fixed orientation display (not a tablet), therefore a laptop with lower resolution can actually have a better display than a tablet with a higher pixel density display because the laptop display can be optimized.

3. This isn't a touch screen laptop, but I prefer not to touch the screen of my laptops. The excellent multi touch mouse pad on the Air makes it actually a better touch interface than the touch screen laptops.

Net: once you start using a MacBook Air it's hard going back to anything else. Perhaps the retina MacBook Pro, but that gets you a better display at the cost of 2-4 hours of battery life. I'll take the battery life and better performance of the Air.

For the most part it does a good job and is fun to interact with stuff just by voice. Overall i think Microsoft has a wonderful idea of being able to control all your entertainment stuff from the XB1 but right now they just need to work out all the kinks.

title: Excellent!!!
comment:
Apple products are full of awe. I have all apple products and even though they are expensive, i will continue to purchase them. I had the 2011 macbook pro originally. it is a great computer but after awhile its weight started to become an issue. I wanted something lighter, with great battery life and great specifications so it was between the retina macbook pro and the macbook air. I decided on the air because its the lightest and the battery life is superb. The retina display is great on the macbook pro but it is not a necessity for me. The screen on the macbook air is still great without it being retina.

I have had the problem of the macbook air going into sleep mode and then not waking up needing a hard reset in order for it to be usable again. It doesn't happen often tho and i know there will be a patch out soon enough to fix this issue so no worries there. Thats the only issue i have had with this monster of a machine.

Overall, the macbook air is GREAT... by the way, i opted for the 4GB memory and 128GB hard drive model. I am good with that much memory, plus i have the new 3TB Airport Time Capsule that i store everything on. My onboard memory is hardly used.

GREAT LAPTOP and having a Airport Time Capsule with it is a KILLER addition. You can back up everything on your Time Capsule using time machine and with file sharing you can have access to ALL your files ANYWHERE you go. You should need nothing more.

title: Big Xbox fan, very disappointed.
comment: I am a very big xbox fan so it pains me to say that I do no like this console. I was extremely excited to buy it and it was nice for the first couple days. After the initial first run or two when you wanted to play with your friends is where the pain began. They try to force you into using kinect for snap and almost seem to make it a pain to open snap without. There are other little problems. For example, when you try to play two players on one xbox the controllers will swap profiles for no reason. When I would pass certain menus it would pass control to my brother as my profile... EXTREMELY frustrating. Those are just a couple things and on top of all that my mic died when it was not even a month old. Over all I am not happy with my Xbox one. Most of my issues are software and do have a chance at being fixed but as the console stands right now, would not recommend.

title: Not impressed!

First off it's huge and weighs a ton. Voice commands work about 35% of the time. The graphics are not worth a $500 purchase. It doesn't connect to your computer media like the 360. It really has nothing special to offer that works correctly.
You must install your games to the hard drive and that takes close to 30 minutes. It will control your tv and cable box but doesn't work correctly at all. It will power up your tv but wont switch the inputs of the tv in case you have multiple systems hooked up. Most time giving the command to shut off power leaves the tv power on. For the price a gaming computer would be a better investment.

title: Great for video games Not so great as media center
comment: Games will play great, and they do look next gen; however, the selling point of the xbox one was its ability to unify your tv/cable/dish in a seamless user controlled voice/gesture interface. Kinect does not always 'hear' you correctly, sometimes it just does not respond at all. In the age of Siri, Dragon, and other voice recognition software, Kinect takes a step backward and disappoints. For instance, to turn the device on via voice command you have to be standing less than a foot away from Kinect so that it can recognize your voice and turn the system on. Gesture commands are sometimes cumbersome and perhaps the system is too sensitive to your movements so any gestures that require specific screen locations are hard to achieve.

title: Excellent Gaming System
comment:
I got my Xbox One on release day so I've used it quite a bit before making this review. Overall Im very happy with my choice to get an Xbox One. Set up was easy, only took a minute or two to conect all the cables and fire it up.

There are a few minor issues, maily related to games being fine tuned, as well as Kinnect not always responding correctly to voice commands. If you were an Xbox 360 user and your still on the fence I would definetly recomend the Xbox One and give it the full five stars.

Being a new systems, there are only a handful of games out

title: XBOX ONE - Great Potential, lacking features
comment:
Let me preface this by stating I own both the XBOX ONE and PS4. In my opinion, both consoles were rushed to the market and the software is lacking. Both do not let you play and music/videos off a USB drive. This is a major downfall when the console is supposed to be an all-in-one media center. Also, the TV aspect with Kinect command did not work great for me. The lack of LOW POWER passthrough killed this for me and I've since removed the Cable Box from the XBOX. The Kinect Voice commands are spotty at best for me. I feel that this console would be great for a bachelor that does not care about screaming at his video game console. If you have kids that sleep, some of these features may not be utilized that well if for some reason their bedrooms are close.

Overall, I think the console has the potential to be GREAT, but just felt rushed initially. The games are good though, Dead Rising 3 is a really fun game to accompany the console.

title: Xbox Live is broken...and kinect is annoying
comment:
I'll start with my first issue (xbox live) which was my initial reason for choosing the Xbox one over the PS4. In the previous generation the online party system and overall friends list was far superior on the 360 when compared to the PS3 (I owned both). However the "new" xbox live on the xbox one is so broken that party voice chat still to this day does not work at all (December 28th)...so it's been out for over a month with no fixes. I've used the skype app as a work around, but overall the online experience has been horrific. My second issue is how Microsoft has clearly built the xbox one to be used with voice command. Which in some circumstances is fine, but when it's 2:30 am and all I want to do is check my friends list, I'd prefer to not wake my roomate up yelling "xbox go to friends" in the living room. What they've done is baried simple things like the friends list and other simple things to force you to ask the kinect to direct you to it. Half the time the kinect can't figure out what your asking for, and about 90 percent of the time your left pretty upset. Don't get me wrong, the first day it was pretty cool to say "xbox on" and have it boot up on its own, but after that it only goes down hill. The tv integrated thing is fine, but I can see an obvious delay when trying to change channels which is annoying (I have comcast).

To sum it up if what you want is an easy, faster, and more user friendly gaming experience then I suggest you go with the PS4 this time around (and that's coming from someone who normally leaned towards xbox in terms of gaming). Now in days things are normally patched and fixed over time, but I feel stupid for paying $100 dollars more for something that is clearly broken in many areas. I'll wait and hope that these things are fixed over time, but I can't recommend this console to anyone as it stands. (Also Microsoft, if you are reading this, please don't send a hit man to silence me.)

title: New console, not without some flaws
comment:
I bought the console so that I could play games and chat with my kids while they are in Florida and I'm in New York. I love the voice communication and the early indications of the updated Kinect capability are that it is considerably more responsive and sensitive than its predecessor. I had none of the issues that plagued a small percentage of the new systems and neither did the sister unit in Florida. Skype connections were established fairly quickly and while all my Skype contacts migrated adding new connections was a bit more involved as I learned the button functionality. Switching back and forth between games and settings while on Skype was a bit dodgy as well. I had two lock ups where the unit just ceased to respond; once while updating a game (it was stuck for over an hour at the same download percentage) and once when attempting to read a blue ray disc after installing the blue ray disc app (it just sat on the Blue Ray screen for ten minutes before I tired of waiting and switched it off). In both cases the unit came back up and responded properly after the restart.
Initial lack of X-Box Live multiplay on the family game bought (Legos Marvel Superheroes) have us waiting to play a game together.
Overall, the speed, functionality and capability tied with the current and anticipated game titles make this the best selection for my needs.

I was able to hook it up to my entire home theater system and now all I have to do is say "Xbox on" and it turns everything on, then I can say "watch TV, what's on HBO" and it'll bring up the guide for my DirecTV and I can watch whatever I want without needing a remote. It is pretty awesome until it hiccups and decides it doesn't hear you or see your hand for using hand gestures. It mostly works pretty well other than a hiccup here or there, I'm very glad we got this over the PS4 even if I wanted a PS4, but couldn't find one.

title: Perfect Entertainment Center
comment: I was a proud owner of an Xbox 360 and a PS3 - my PS3 was pretty much used exclusively as a bluray player because there were very few games that intrigued me that were PS3 exclusives and I preferred xbox live. When they announced the Xbox One, I thought my prayers had been answered - xbox live + bluray drive. I snagged my Day 1 edition with a couple of assorted games and I have to say I am impressed. I didn't buy a kinect sensor for my 360 because from toying with it in store and at a friends house it seemed glitchy and in some cases really irritating. The Kinect that came with the Xbox One seems like what they were shooting for when they first released Kinect - solid motion capture, fairly impressive voice recognition and controls that actually improve the overall user experience. Don't get me wrong, there are still going to be moments when you think about taking it for a dip in the bathtub, but all in all it gets the job done. Not having to turn on a controller just to watch Netflix is excellent. As far as gaming is concerned, the video quality is beautiful - Forza, in particular, is impressive because of the attention to detail - not only do the cars and tracks look gorgeously life-like, but the physics required to constantly render the effects and allow for rewind capability are excellent. Dead Rising 3 is probably my favorite - the story isn't fantastic, the voice acting and some of the bit part characters are pretty terrible but the gameplay is a blast. The Boom Bear in particular has become my new BFF - like having your own personal death squad plush toy. If they ever make a deal with the major cable providers to allow the XB1 to act as a DVR instead of as a go-between for voice control of your cable box I think Sony will have to pull up their tent pegs. Impressive product, Microsoft - keeping tweaking the OS to make all the functions of the 360 cleaner.

title: The lynchpin of my living room
comment:
I'm sure most gamers are either firmly in the Sony or Microsoft camps already, so I will avoid comparisons with the Playstation 4.

Here's what I love about the Xbox One. It really does everything they claim-- it is the lynchpin of my living room. It is a single source for video games, streaming video services (Netflix, Amazon, etc.), and my cable TV provider (DISH). As the father of two small children, being able to switch between these entertainment sources seamlessly, using nothing but my voice, is a win. Also the Skype app is unparalleled and made Christmas day apart from my family very special. It really does feel like the future.

title: pluses and minuses
comment: Had to get away from sprint and the spotty service and message delivery so I was glad to get back to Verizon as their coverage is so much better. They had a great promo on the Samsung s3 so I got it. Less than 3 weeks later they put the same promo on the s4 which really irritated me. I just got the phone set up to suit me and spent $20 some dollars on ringtones and didn't want to go through it again. The s3 has some good features and some bad ones. If your not real careful you'll go to use it and find all your pages have changed, more steps to pull up a contact and the auto suggest in messaging really sucks, it refuses to let me use things like ty nor will it learn it. I have to reread everything so I ended up turning it off which means I now have to manually do my punctuation which sucks but better than sending garbled unintelligible messages. The only 2 features better than the evo are the camera quality although every time I try to send photos it won't convert to msm and I get the red exclamation mark and it says all videos even 20 second ones are too large to send. The second great feature is the microphone, I love it for memos, sending bulk personal happy holiday texts. I'll live with the phone to get the better service.

title: Best investment ever!
comment: I love Apple products but became a committed Windows user, out of necessity, during law school. Out in practice, I was still using my 2007 Sony Vaio which must have weighed 10 pounds, had about 5-6 minutes of battery life, and worst of all needed updates every 8 minutes. I finally took the dive when the MacBook Air went on sale right before Thanksgiving. I was able to get the 13" for less than the cost of an 11" so it was hard to pass up. Well, I can honestly say, aside from my car, this has been my best work related purchase ever! I charge it every two days or so, I take it everywhere! All you have to do is open it and it's ready to go which is amazing. The screen clarity and sound are amazing, and I love all the keyboard controls for sound, brightness, etc. I also love the seamless operating with my iPhone and iPad Mini; literally, you do X on your phone and it's immediately available on the computer and iPad. The built in camera is nice since we are facing a switch to video conferences and depositions. The speed is great and it never ever freezes up or makes me wait. Just overall, a very pleasant experience. Oh, and I bought a great snap on cover on Amazon for like $12, and it works like a charm!

title: to me its just another box
comment:
i think its hilarious microsoft would make a play for the cable industry.. when over the last couple of years the cable companys have seen 1.5 million subscribers drop per year cutting the cord and just paying for netflix, hulu ect.. so personally i dont enjoy more than half of this new software they've installed.. i've always have had an xbox in the house and use it daily, but its predecessor the 360 was very refined, you knew where everything was and comparing this new one there's really a big difference..
plus the the way it excepts disc is aweful. ive noticed light scratches on my new games already just from loading them.. the did away with the tray and now you have to slip them into a what reminds of a car cd player... as matter of fact im taking another star away.. i noticed people were so quick to give it five stars the day they picked it up.. i waited to do this review now from about a months worth use..
i will say its quieter than my other xboxs but it still come with a brick on the plug end so id say give it 10-12 months and i bet it will have a loud humm to it after awhile of collecting some dust..
over-all im actually hardly impressed.. for 500 bucks i could have done allot with that money this christmas season.. oh well..
one laast thing, i bought call of duty ghosts a few days ago and thought i was buying the new xbox one version, didn't realize it waas for the older 360, you think they would have done a better job of changing the color of the cases.. really just not happy with that.. people might think im an itiot for buying it, but having a four year old tugging on my sleeve and my wife wanting to get going, i just didnt even think, but i think when your a consumer of a particular product from a particular company the products should be more easily identified when selecting something on the go.. well thats my review, i could actually go on for another couple paragraphs but ill digress.. thanks for reading..

comment: I was recently in the market for a new laptop and was initially planning on getting another windows laptop as they are much cheaper. However, everyone I know that made the switch from Windows to Apple was very pleased with the decision & would not go back to the Windows laptop. It was at least twice as twice as much to buy the Mac Air. I'm glad I made the switch. I use the laptop for work and personal and just find that it is easier to use and less buggy than Windows. My windows machines always seem to get buggy and slow unless you really stay on top of it with the virus software. I don't hear about these virus problems as much from Apple users and so far that has been my experience as well after about a month of use. I don't get the the "Windows is searching for a solution" message (Windows never finds a solution in my experience). Also, you can now exchange Microsoft Office files between the Apple and Window machines which is great for work. In summary, great synchronization between the iPhone, iPad & Macbook Air, thin, lightweight, stable & great battery life. It's worth the extra money. I'd buy it again.

Downsizing from a MacBook Pro 15" to the MacBook Air 13" was a great decision since I no longer wanted a heavy product to tote around. Although this computer has a lot of great things about it, I don't like that the power cable detaches a lot easier than my MacBook Pro. comment:
The MacBook Air, with office installed and wifi available has everything I need when working outside the office. The without an Ethernet port, I had to purchase an adaptor that I only use on the rare occasion where I stay at a hotel without wifi. Additionally, the design of the MacBook Air doesn't permit the inclusion of disc drive. Like an Ethernet port, it's rarely used now. However, when it is, unless you have the portable disc drive (additional $70-80), you have to go through the pain of transferring files to a portable hard drive or via email to the computer.
Don't get me wrong; minor gripes aside, the MacBook Air is a highly capable computer that can do everything work related that I need it too. It has a phenomenal battery life and all the bells and whistles i could want without the additional costs and extraneous options on the MacBook Pro.

title: Not bad, for starters
comment:
So I bought both the PS4 and X1... I'm a game fan, not a fan-boy. Both machines had a glitch or two at launch (and still have some), seemingly more than any other console(s) at launch that I recall. This is probably due to the extensive dependency on hooks to web content, or maybe the complexity of the OS (or both).

Overall I like the X1 well enough, but it seems to lack personality (so to speak). The controller is very nice, but the W8 GUI just doesn't excite me, and the Kinect is a major annoyance to me in a number of respects. I have it mostly disabled, which addresses some of my annoyance, but using that setting I have to sign in every time I turn on the machine - PIA.

OK, I'm sure I will like this Xbox just as much as I've enjoyed the first two, in due time. Hopefully MS addressed the QC/design issues this time around and we don't all start seeing unit failures. For now, I can't help but feel that the PS4 will ultimately be the better 'game' machine, long-term. Not hatin'... just sayin'.

title: Perfect
comment: If you liked xbox 360 you will like xbox one just as much if not more.

title: Not perfect, but very good. Time will improve it.
comment:
What I like:
+ The dashboard is integrated WAY better than the Xbox 360 and PS3. There is no longer the feeling of "in a game" or "in the dashboard". You are ALWAYS in both. Say you are in the middle of a game but want to spontaneously change a system setting or launch another app etc. Both the 360 and PS3 had some semi-dashboard functionality built into the dashboard/home button, but most everything required you to first exit the game and go to the dashboard (aside from some shortcuts to go straight to a different game). Now, you press the dashboard button and without interrupting your game in any way, you now have access to the full dashboard and settings, etc. There is really no such thing as being required to "quit" a game anymore, which is awesome.

+ Speed. I always was surprised that through the entire life of the Xbox 360 (including the 360 S and 360 E), there was an unacceptable amount of lag on many core dashboard functions. Something as basic as showing your list of games, or list of gamerpics to change to, or achievement lists, or loading marketplace screens, would often take several seconds of waiting to populate. The Xbox One's startup is acceptably fast, but could still be improved on, but basic things like loading marketplace content or my list of installed apps, achievements, etc, is very quick. Switching between game and dashboard is no longer the slow annoyance it used to be, but rather is nearly instantaneous.

+ The controller. Controller design has come a long way since the old Atari joysticks or uncomfortable NES gamepads. I have used Sony's Dual Shock 3, Nintendo's Wii U Pro controller, Xbox 360 controller and Xbox One controller. They are all fantastic. But I must say I always liked the 360 controller the best. The Xbox One controller is simply an improvement upon that one. The only downside to the 360 controller was the mediocre D-pad, which has definitely experienced a massive improvement in the XBO update. They also moved the guide/dashboard button higher, which I like since I used to accidentally hit that when I meant to hit Start/Back. I even like how they redesigned the battery to go inside the controller. It takes slightly longer to swap a battery out, but since I use the USB cable to charge instead of swapping batteries (no Quick Charge Kit yet exists for the One like the 360 has), that doesn't matter at this point. The only thing I don't like is renaming the Start and Back buttons. "Press Menu" sounds way less cool than "Press Start" you're used to on any game's splash screen.

+ Noise levels and cooling/reliability. Anyone who had a launch Xbox 360 or launch PlayStation 3 (I have both) knows what I'm talking about. Those things were LOUD. Distractingly loud. Even over my high-end surround speakers. The Xbox One's internal fan is very large compared to the launch 360 (google photos if its internals). Large fans can move more air and are not as loud as small fans. This also helps with its reliability, as the Xbox 360's biggest launch issues were overheating problems. Microsoft learned from this and I guarantee that will not be an issue here. I wanted to make sure of this, so I have literally had my Xbox One powered on almost 24 hours a day for the last week since launch day. This is because if it's going to overheat, I want to know now rather than down the line after the warranty is up. And I'm killing two birds with one stone because Killer Instinct has some goals related to how long you are in practice mode, so I leave it idling in practice mode while at work. Yeah, call me crazy. But anyway, so far, it has handled being constantly on for days at a time with not a single issue.

+ I obviously can't speak for everyone else, but my Xbox One console, disc drive, controller, and Kinect, all function flawlessly and had absolutely no issues.

What I'm not thrilled about:
- Launch line-up. If you are on the fence about buying the console and you're not immediately sure what game(s) to even get for it, you could easily wait it out a while longer. Forza 5 and some of the multi-platform releases are pretty cool (like Need for Speed Rivals), but I'm not sure they're $60 cool. If you are buying the Xbox One now, you're doing it for the novelty of being among the first to have a cutting-edge system. This is true with the PS4 as well. Anybody who swears by any of the launch game is just a fanboy drone. There are a handful of *pretty good* games for both systems, but I see them as more of $30-40 titles. Honestly, I've enjoyed the downloadable Xbox One games the most, such as Killer Instinct, or the free Kinect Sports trial. A big disappointment is that digital versions of full retail games (like Call of Duty Ghosts) cost MSRP. Until Microsoft shares some of the cost reduction from going all-digital (no marketing, manufacturing, shipping, middle-man retailers, etc), I will ALWAYS buy my games in the form of the retail disc version. A $60 retail game should be $40-50 tops from the Xbox Live Store. It's so backwards that all the retail games are a flat $60 at all times via the Xbox Store, when already Amazon has had various sales that have at some point put them at $39 (Lego Marvel Superheroes) to $49 (almost every launch game). Have some digital sales and permanent price drops and I might actually buy some of them!

- No backwards compatibility. This would have been an even more important feature now than it was on the Xbox 360. We've now had eight years to build up a game library on our Xbox 360s. Mine is quite large. Not being able to use that collection as a buffer between Xbox One launch, and when all the great XBO exclusives hit, is very disappointing. The original Xbox only had four years to amass its game library, and since it was the first of Microsoft's consoles, there were far less owners with far less games than now exists with the Xbox 360. A lot of the same sentiments apply to the PlayStation 4. Both consoles could have benefited greatly from a backwards compatibility feature, since neither of their game libraries will be very expansive for at least a year or so. It's also disappointing that I need to keep both consoles connected to my TV. When I bought my Wii U (and PS3, Xbox 360, PS2, Wii), I could give a nostalgic farewell to my Wii (and PS2, Xbox, PS1, GameCube) and disconnect them from my AV setup entirely, while still playing all my games.

- USB Ports. All three versions of the Xbox 360, including the launch version, had 2 USB ports in the front of the console. My 360 S also has 3 in the back. I like never running out of USB ports. But the Xbox One has zero USB ports in the front, and only one on the side. So my Play and Charge cable has to plug into the side of the Xbox, meaning the cable can't reach as far, and someone tripping over the cable is more likely to result in damage to the console and/or cable. I also can't comfortably connect two controllers at once since one would have to be connected to the back. I'm also disappointed that external storage via USB isn't supported at launch, though it sounds like that is coming later on. But even when that feature is added, what if I want to charge a controller while also connecting a flash drive with some video files on them? I'd have to use the back ports, which I think should only ever be used for semi-permanent devices, like connecting a very large external hard drive. But those back USB ports may have to be used a lot more often than I'd like. Perhaps in 4 or so years, an Xbox One redesign will bring back more and better-placed USB ports.

- No 3D Blu-ray support. Even last-generation had this feature on the PS3. The PS4 and Xbox One *both* don't support these. Why the step backwards?

What I'm neutral about:
* The console's physical design: It actually looks very nice to me. But it does have a small amount of boring-ness to it. It's just a big black box, basically. The key will be to keep the glossy part free of scratches and dust. Glossy consoles are notorious for aging much worse than matte consoles. It's also quite a bit bigger than the Xbox 360 redesigns (but on par with the launch Xbox & Xbox 360 sizes). But I do have to say, I am very glad they are taking precautions to avoid the overheating issues of the launch 360s. The giant cooling heatsink/fan inside, and ample ventilation room inside this ominous monolith, will make it much more reliable and less susceptible to failure; an acceptable trade-off in my mind. I'm sure down the line there will be a smaller version of it. But I didn't want to wait 3-4 years to get it.

The bottom line is this: It's a great console with great potential, but as with most launch consoles, the games just aren't quite there to back it up, YET. If you are on the fence over the console because of the 360's launch reliability, I would honestly not let that hold you back on this one since Microsoft learned a very painful & expensive lesson from that, and designed a much more reliable console this time around. But if you are waiting because you're unsure of the game library, you are probably justified in continuing to wait. I honestly just got it because I knew for sure I would eventually get it anyway when Halo 5 comes out. But it the price is holding you back, you may have to wait YEARS for this to become affordable. So if you are okay waiting that long, great. But otherwise you might as well get it now so you can actually use it while you wait for the game library to improve. Chances are, there won't be any price cuts on it for at least a couple years, and the price cuts aren't usually anything significant until around 4-5 years after launch. So if you have the patience (I didn't), definitely wait. But since I am 98.4% sure the price will still be $499 when Halo 5 comes out, I figured I may as well get it now along with the extra pre-order perks.

A solid system; I definitely do not regret my purchase. 4.5 stars.

title: Decent Gaming System
comment:
Xbox One is great for people that aren't just concerned with playing games but want an overall multimedia hub and gaming platform.

A few things that prevented a 5 star rating: Skype app stopped working after a week. App starts clocking but won't open up. Deleted and reloaded app, with same results. Can't figure out how the gesture control works. The voice controls only work in a room without any ambient noise. So, if you're running a movie and try to make it pause, you have to wait until the movie soundtrack is quiet. If there's any noise, the console can't differentiate between you and the sounds of the movie or game. I have a huge number of games for the 360 that won't work on this console, and there's a definite lack of RPG games available for this console.

title: Great system with room to grow
comment:
Comparing XBox One to PS4 is comparing apples to oranges, so there's no point in doing so. They're different systems that do different things.

XBox One aims to integrate all of the entertainment you consume in the house into one device. It plays great games like the PS4, but also controls your Cable/Satellite TV and leverages the stable of apps that Microsoft has invested in, such as Skype for video calls to friends and family. The split-screen snapping of TV, game, web browser, Skype, NFL app and others is a great feature.

Microsoft aims very high in their goals for this system. Like the last system, it's built in a way to constantly evolve - the XBox One you use today will be different and better next year, the year after, and on and on, because it's designed for every part of it's software and functionality to be expanded upon and regularly updated.

Bottom line: it's cutting-edge in what it tries to do in bringing together apps, web browsing, TV and gaming. Like most cutting-edge products, it has its rough edges, but the ceiling of its potential is so high that it's hard to see. Impressive technology.
