title: Innovative and transformative
comment:
I've been using the XBOX since introduction, always wind up owning both major systems and favor online play which typically pushes me towards XBOX a little bit more as I simply favor XBL over PSN. With this launch I was terribly disappointed by the lack of Quality Control and was one of those users impacted by the optical drive issue, but once remediated was extremely satisfied. I will say MS did right by me eventually with games and XBL once I worked through my issues with customer service.

One of those games was Dead Rising 3 which truly showcases the innovative approach MS is taking with it's alternative interfaces to gaming, smart glass and Kinect are so tightly integrated to this experience that it truly opened my eyes to what is possible on the XB1 if the developers only take the time to do so. Worthwhile checking out as your smart device with smart glass app becomes an extension of the in-game phone of the character with maps, items, exclusive side quests, and even freaking air strikes being controlled via it. Kinect is used for a more immersive style of play and often I find myself playing in dead silence so as to not lure zombies to me when running low on health. READ: I whisper to those next to be to be quiet as they are luring the zombies to me when they are loud!

To me, NG gaming isn't just about speeds and feeds as 4K/8K are still a ways away and even then a cruddy game in higher res is just a sharper piece of crud. The XB1 has done an excellent job of integrating the Kinect and ensuring to developers that all users will have it and develop to it unlike that of the move. This makes me believe that the higher probability lie with XB1 to introduce more "interesting" and immersive games certainly I believe that after having had a dose of it within DR3. This isn't to say the other games aren't great but TBH those titles on both systems are just sharper and smoother FPS performing titles, even Forza 5 which is a fantastic racer in it's own right but lacks that same thrill as DR3 because of it's traditional approach. They tried to use Kinect in it, but it's accuracy and usability is in question for me.

All in all, I am extremely happy with the XB1 and would recommend it as a purchase again, still getting used to it being the hub of my living room and have chosen to give it some time as I see where MS is going with it and like what I see them trying to accomplish.

title: A great start
comment: The XBox One looks to be a great central player in you entertainment center someday, but that day isn't here yet. Control of other devices works through the Kinect device (mine broke after three weeks). The options for configuring that control are very limited at this time. It won't do anything with a Tivo Mini, but controlled the awful cable company box well. I was hoping for a Logitech Harmony on streroids and got the equivalent of the universal remotes you see at drug store registers instead.

title: Xbox One not fully baked?
comment: I bought ($500.00) into the idea of the Xbox "One" as being the only box you need in your living room this weekend. In theory it sounded great to control all your stuff from one box with voice commands but it did not work for me. Usually I live by the philosophy "If it's too good to be true, it probably is" and this proves true with my experience. I have an electronic engineering background and I really did give it a fair try. I moved and calibrated the Kinect sensor in many different locations around my living room for hours. In the end I was just plain frustrated and felt stupid yelling XBOX ON with nothing but a dead box looking back at me. If you are looking for the next generation gaming system then I'm sure the Xbox One is the next best thing, but if your an occasional gamer and want it for controlling your living room by voice, look else where.

The XBOX One needs to be on every minute you are watching TV if you choose to take advantage of the TV features. I used to watch TV to give my 360 a break and believe taking care of it in this manner contributed to its longevity. Early 360 adopters will recall overheating was an issue leading to a "red ring of death." This system has EIGHT processors and runs so hot, I know it is consuming plenty of power. You have the option not to take advantage of the ability to route/control your TV with the unit. I wanted to like/use the interactive features with my TV, but do not like another very hot entertainment appliance running every minute my TV is on and will probably re-route my TV around the XBOX One.

title: Potential exists but lacking in some areas.
comment:
First of all I do like the design of the One. Some may complain that it is too large and fills up too much space but to me the cooling aspect of the design makes it well worth it. I do like that you can pin things to your first screen to make them quick to access, plus your most recently used apps/games are on the main home screen along the bottom.

At this point my biggest complain is the party system. Unless you do things just right the party won't work. Between having a 30 second window for accepting a party invitation to sometimes the chat just not working.... There have been times that my group has spent as much time making the party work as we did actually gaming. Once things get going at least the party sticks together.

The potential is there and once Titanfall comes out I think things are going to be incredibly amazing.

title: Can Only get Better from Here
comment:
I'm not one to be obsessed with anything, but man can this thing do it all. I find myself using my Xbox one for everything because that is what it was built for. I play video games with great graphics, watch TV (Football usually) even while playing a game, and using Xbox fitness to get in shape while having fun. That's generally speaking; now let’s get into more detail.

[Downloading] So the first thing right off the bat that you will notice is having to download many things including the update, apps, and video games to the hard drive. Luckily my internet speed is above average and I was able to download the update within 8 minutes, but the game downloads take closer to 25 minutes due to size. Fortunately the Xbox allows you to start playing once the game is half way done downloading, but not all features are ready by that point. Considering that you will not be downloading multitudes of games at once except for the very first time, it is not too much of a hassle. You can explore other features of the Xbox while you wait. 4.5/5

[Graphics] Whoa whoa.. whoa.. whoa.... whoa.... Louis this ain't my Batman cup.Alright but seriously, the graphics have blown my mind into a million little pixels of mixtures of RGB colors that create a satisfying sensation in my brain that increase my levels of serotonin. In translation, THESE GRAPHICS ARE FREAKING AWESOME! I currently own Madden, FIFA, and Battlefield. Battlefield showed an amazing difference in graphics that left my jaw dropping to the floor. The details in every inch, the vivid and accurate colors, the mass destruction, all brought the battlefield to life. Given that Battlefield is along with the very first Xbox one games, the road ahead is very long and the capabilities the Xbox has is sometimes hard to believe what is possible in the future. There is not much difference between the graphics of PS4 and Xbox one so that should not make you choose one or the other. But compared to the last generation, this is a huge improvement that is worth the money just for the graphics. 4.9/5

[Features] Well this is where the Xbox goes passed the PS4. Some things like Netflix and Amazon video are still there, it is the things like the ability to Skype, watch cable TV, do Xbox Fitness, and watch NFL games, and using snap, that really had me go towards the Xbox. There is almost no lag when watching TV through the Xbox which is something that was very well done. But the main feature that I find the most helpful is Xbox Fitness. There are not as many workouts as I had hoped but I think as time goes on they will continue to integrate more videos to work with the Fitness app. I was very surprised with how well the kinect was able to register my body movements. It was very fun how they would set a multiplier for doing to the move correctly and setting challenges in order to get achievements. This really makes exercising fun, which is something I REALLY need. The snap feature was also one of my favorites. I am able to play video games while another family member can be watching some TV, kind of like a PIP. A lot can be done with the Xbox, and I'm expecting many more apps to come out. 4.7/5

[Controller] Xbox 360 had the best controller by far. There was nothing better that I could ask for. Guess what, it got better. Xbox has been making a big deal out of the D-pad. It is true that it functions much better, but it wasn't worth making such a big deal about. The Bumpers on the controller are a little bit annoying. They take some getting used to because they are positioned slightly differently and make a very loud and annoying sound. The thumbsticks are smaller which is somewhat better and also have the edges a little tighter which keeps it from tearing like it did on my 360 controller. The positioning of the home button is much better in that it doesn't get in the way of the buttons. When my Dad plays, he might hit the center of the 360 button in the middle of the game, but this controller helps avoid that from happening. Overall it is similar to the 360 controller and I believe it is easy to get use to the new layout within a day or two. 4.6/5

[Design] Now this is an ugly Xbox, but that was kind of expected now wasn't it. The upside to this is that we will not have to go through the horrible red ring of death. It is capable of keeping cool and will not overheat even if on for 24 hours straight for every day, I would know. I'm sure within 2 or 3 years we will have a redesigned Xbox that is smaller, just like how the Xbox slim was released. Another upside is that the Xbox is very quiet which is quite surprising given the size and consumption of it. But until then, just be content with the fact that there is no more red ring. 3.5/5 (The 3.5 is mostly due to the upsides)

[Xbox, Record That] Well the Xbox is constantly recording the last 5 minutes of gameplay so you can easily record anything, either automatically or with a voice command. Unfortunately I have been having trouble with the voice command so I have been stuck having to do it manually. Sharing videos with friends is very easy thanks to this. Hopefully people will reduce the uploads of there uninteresting videos and keep it restricted to only the ones worth watching. 3.9/5

[Movies] Finally a blu-ray player, I have been wanting this for many years. Although I already had one in my living room, I could really use one in my basement. Sometimes you just want to watch a movie by yourself without being disturbed or by disturbing others, this is why this came in handy. Now that I get almost all my movies either streaming or Blu-ray, the Xbox is my number 1 movie player. It is true that you have to download an app to play the blu-ray, but it's free and easy. 5/5

[Kinect] Well, well, well, so you add a Kinect Microsoft and you bump up the cost 100 bucks more than the PS4?... NO PROBLEM! I am not disappointed at all. The Kinect is amazing; 10 times better than the old kinect. I can say anything and the kinect will do it with ease. Also, almost all games have at least some kinect functionality. Battlefield lets you turn your head in order to turn your head in battlefield when in a vehicle which is really cool. FIFA allows subs to be made just by saying it which is also cool. As time goes on, I feel that the kinect will be more and more useful in these games. In the end, this is a great addition to the Xbox. 4.6/5

[Overall] With everything the Xbox has to offer, there is no other thing I would rather have. I give it a 4.46/5 for now, but I think I will rank it higher as time goes by. It has been great for everything, mainly gaming with revolutionary graphics. And remember, it can only get better from here.

title: Not worth the money
comment:
I am gamer and prefer Microsoft over Sony and needless to say I was completely disappointed with this new console. I got it 2 days ago and am returning it because it is pretty much the same as the 360 but a few new looks and picture quality is a little better. My first and biggest disappointment is the controller and headset. When I opened it and took it out I thought it was fake. The controller is a little bigger then the 360 and the sticks are smaller on the new controller. I thought if I pressed too hard on the controller I would break it because it felt so cheap IMO. The D pad looks like it shouldn't even be on there and the head set hookup looks like a chat pad and is really bulky. Another thing is I couldn't hook up an old set of Turtles to the new controller and I don't want to shell out another $100 when mine work perfectly fine. I am not of fan of the new controller at all and hope that they come out with a new one that closer resembles the 360 controller.

The other thing I was disappointed in was the Kinect. It did not respond to my commands like I saw when they had the reveal of the xbox one. I told it multiple commands and it didn't even get close to what I was saying, it was very frustrating. I don't know if the Kinect needs to be in a super large room to work better but the room it was in was pretty decent sized. The face recognizing is good though. The hand controls were terrible as well and took multiple tries to do anything. And lastly and most disappointing was the supposedly seamless switch from game to TV and back. I switched from a movie to live TV and back to a movie and one, it wasn't as fast as shown in the reveal and two, it restarted the movie?!?! Maybe I am wrong but I thought it was supposed to go back to where it left off and be pretty much an instant change but it wasn't and took awhile to even recognize my voice.

The one good thing is the picture quality on the blu ray player. I can not complain about that but I don't want to pay $500 for a blu ray player. So I will be taking it back and will wait for it to work out the kinks or drop drastically in price before I even think about buying this again. And I have even thought about going to PS4 and forgetting this waste of a system. So all in all it is not worth $500 at all and am perfectly happy with my 360 and a blu ray player. The only way I would recommend this to someone is if they had $500 to blow and like to have the latest in gaming consoles because that's honestly all it is, is something to say you have.

As for you Microsoft I am disappointed you would release such an average system at that price.

title: Great console, needs more support
comment: I purchased the Xbox One to replace my aging Xbox 360. I'm disappointed that it is not backward-compatible with games for the 360, but the games that are designed specifically for the One are truly amazing, from a graphical standpoint. I used to use my 360 as a Media Center Extender for my HTPC, however, the One does not have this functionality. Rather, it uses an HDMI-passthrough that allows you to display video from your cable box or HDMI cable box. You can use your voice to turn everything in your system on or off and even change channels. It's truly amazing. I do wish that there were more apps available at launch. One of the most glaring omissions is the lack of an Xfinity On-Demand app like on the 360. The Verizon FiOS app just became available, so I remain hopeful that the Xfinity app isn't far behind.

title: Pricey, but every aspect is fine-tuned
comment:
As far as the Maverick OS experience goes, this laptop is probably at the top for just about anyone's needs except gamers/game developers.

Since I was already emptying my wallet for this, I decided to upgrade the processor to an i7 and get the 8 gigs of ram. While I can't say I've noticed the processor making a difference, the 8 gigs of ram has certainly come in handy for my multitasking.

I've primarily been a Microsoft guy my whole life, and I don't plan on changing that even after this purchase. However, hardware aside, the Maverick OS does make the mundane tasks on a computer fun and relatively easy. Unfortunately, Apple decided it was worth hundreds of extra dollars, and that irritates me.

The difference is the Haswell processor. Whatever Intel did with their 4th generation i-core processors - it works. The power management is solid. Especially on the less-taxing Maverick OS. You can expect as much battery life as an iPad in some situations.

The design of the Macbook Air becomes a perfect bow on top of a nice package. I am definitely one that believes the aesthetics of a machine can make all the difference in the world when it comes to your experience. I routinely wield this laptop one handed with ease. I barely feel it in my bag.

Also, the metal casing is one that many companies that produce Windows laptops should take note of. I understand that plastic is cheaper, but I feel much more secure using the Macbook Air all day because of its sturdiness.

I can't leave out the track pad either. While this may seem like a minor detail, it truly is unrivaled. Browsing through anything on the computer is incredibly easy with the pad. It has perfect positioning, and great responsiveness. All of the motions work without err as far as my experience has reached.

Downsides:

Now, there are a couple notable kickers here. First, the laptop costs a fortune. I believe I paid close to 1400 dollars for mine. This is the point where you have to really ask yourself, is this worth it? For many, it is. This Macbook Air will certainly last you for quite awhile. But if you really aren't sold or too concerned with the fanciness of a machine, you really should look far away from Apple products.

Second, while you can get Office, you can only get the 2011 version. Microsoft does this on purpose. Microsoft and Apple are not friends. And as such, you can expect that there will be some discrepancies in cross-platform support for some applications. Don't think you can do everything on a Macbook that you can on a Windows laptop...I assure you that you can't. Even so, most people probably won't notice, and that's important to notice. Apple may have come out with alternatives to the things they're lacking, but the truth is the standard is Microsoft for most professional software.

Summary:

All of that being said, you probably aren't going to buy a Mac for its Microsoft support. You definitely won't buy it for the deal value. For what this laptop accomplishes, it's at the top in my book. You can run just about everything the majority of people need to run, and it does it all with extraordinary battery life and an attractive interface. That's why you buy this laptop.

NOTE: I think in retrospect, I would've gone with the 11 inch version. It kind of maximizes the portability aspects that the MacAir is good for. Also saves you a little cash.

NOTE 2: Don't listen to these people who worry about storage. 128GB is plenty of on-board storage currently, and if you truly need more you can save a lot of money just by grabbing flash drives or using the cloud.

NOTE 3: The whole thunderbolt business is absurd. You have to buy seemingly millions of adapters to plug this machine into anything. Just give me an HDMI port.

title: Best laptop out there
comment:
This is easily the best laptop that I have ever owned. I spent months trying out various PC laptops and none of them could deliver what I was looking for.

Ultimately, I just decided to go ahead and spend the money and buy a Macbook Air. I sprung for the 13" as it was on sale at the time. Best decision I could have made. While more expensive, this computer is light (~2 lbs), fast, reliable (have had no lock ups in the time that i have had it - unlike some of the other laptops I tried), and the battery life is amazing. I can get up to 15hrs of battery life depending on what I am doing! Add to that the great chiclet-style keyboard, the best laptop trackpad out there, backlighting on the keyboard, and a great/bright display. It is worth the price of admission in my opinion.

OSX may not be for everyone. I've used it in the past and find it intuitive. It also helps that there are OSX versions of Office, and knowing that Windows could even run on this if need be. On top of that, I use Citrix Web Access for work, and it actually runs more reliably through Safari on my MacBook than it does on the other PCs we have around the house. I also consider myself a photography enthusiast, and to me there are so many more options for various photography editing applications on Mac (whether it be an app, or a full-fledged program).

I would say this is a perfect laptop for someone who wants a solid, reliable, portable, easy to use laptop. Yes, it is a little more expensive than a comparable PC laptop, but you are also getting a more stable OS and the support that Apple throws behind their products.

title: Good, with significant potential.
comment:
The highly anticipated Xbox One certainly met the standard, but did not excel with excellence. While it has significant potential and in the coming months will undoubtedly be the industry leading console with the best tech., at launch it did not show this. There are some kinks to fix, like with the Kinect verbal commands. All of which will be fixed in time with use and updates.

In simple terms, the hardware is most certainly there and will meet expectations. However, the launch software will take time to catch up. This was shown with Battlefield 4, a launch title for the console. It has taken months for the game to catch up and be a stable game on this platform. This being said, the ability to have head tracking and verbal commands is only the beginning. As game developers and software updates progress, the true ability of the Xbox One and Kinect will be discovered.

Be patient with the software, understand the significance of the hardware, and get your hands on this must own console at your leisure.

title: Great upgrade from the 360.
comment:
I have been an Xbox fan since the beginning and just like the 360 launch, my wife was out there trying to score a One for me for Christmas. Turns out she was able to and a nice surprise to open her up Christmas morning.

Setup was a little on the difficult side. I don't mean figuring out how to set it up, that was easy, I mean getting everything to work correctly. It took some doing to get my X1 passing through the One. Also, I have calibrated and re-calibrated my Kinect several times. It is working much better but still sometimes won't sign me in or doesn't hear my commands. Meanwhile, my wife and son were in the kitchen this morning and said "juice box" and the One came to life waiting for a command? It would be nice if it was that sensitive when I spoke to it.

The launch line up is light yes, but so is every launch lineup. Still, Ryse: Son of Rome looks and plays great. Assassins's Creed: Black Flag, even though a port, looks and plays beautifully.

The OS is just great, intuitive and much better than the 360. Basically it is the Windows 8 shell wrapped around Xbox OS. Cannot complain at all. It has everything I want and use right on my main screen. It really did take over my living room. I have everything controlled by the One. Powers up all my gear and then down at the end of the night with ease.

Just to even out my review, I will say one bad thing. I have had to hard boot it twice since Christmas. It seems the X1 got frozen in the main window. I couldn't get it to respond without a cold boot. Something to keep an eye on but I also have the extended warranty.

So that's it. This is leaps and bounds ahead of the 360 in every single conceivable way. Graphics, hardware capability, software improvements. I cannot stress enough just how great of a system this is.

comment: The Xbox One is your all-in-one media center. Navigating the Xbox One's menus is simple and convenient; just a swipe of your hand, speak commands or use the included wireless controller.

title: Almost OK
comment: First Xbox One the Gpu failed, red dots and lines while gaming. Only six cores are assigned for gaming while two are for backround processes. 768 steam units while 128 are locked due to software. While the xbox one has gcn2.0 vs ps4 which has gcn1.0 gpu units its not a real advantage just a more efficient design. Not twice as effective which people seem to think it is, more like 10-23% better with a driver support which there is no support for it at this time. Would be a better idea to unlock all the gpu steam units and up the gpu to 900mhz or even just unlock them and run at the standard 853mhz. Its in dire need of software fixes. While the party chat mode and jumping in a friends game was great in the Xbox 360 its a hassle in the Xbox One. You think it would have improved from that but its more or less like the Xbox 360 was at lanuch. To sum it up, its not worth the 500.00 price tag. Even the main board pcb has some cheap diode's and coils that we used, these types were used one the Xbox 360 and after time leak or explode. Disappointing compared to the Ps4 layout while uses all quality components. Also the hard drive is only 500gb, 320gb reserved for games, its not replaceable, you would have to purchase an external hard drive. Supports usb 3.0 hard drives. Installing a portion of a game in mandatory to play it, takes a good 30min too 2hrs and multiplayer does not work until its installed. Kct is over hyped, and not worth it imo.No support for 1080i just 1080p, 720p and 480p. One plus is that is quite, even while gaming. Microsoft plans on offloading more to the cloud servers in a year or two and more in the future so gaming will be more or streaming based. While the bandwidth won't be supported by most residents for 10yrs plus which means this is a concept ahead of its time. Last thing is while the Xbox 360 and PS3 were ahead of its time, the newer Xbox One is a mere low entry level system and PS4 is closer to mid range. While microsoft swears by esram its much more of a hassle to program for vs a unified memory pool which is used on newer apu's by amd and the PS4.

title: A great entry into this generation's console wars
comment:
The Xbox One is admittedly the more expensive of the two major entries into this generation's console wars. Let's be honest. PS4 is $100 cheaper. But what are you getting for that $100? The Kinect: This edition's Kinect plays better it shorter spaces (a totally deal stopper for me before) and voice use is so much better than before. Whereas before I'd often simply use the controller to do simple system navigation, now I can honestly use voice to navigate the tiles and move through the interface.

The best and ... not so great experience is live TV (in my case cable) integration with the XBOX. In my case, the cable comes from the wall, directly to the Xbox one, Xbox One into the TV. So how does it work? The TV comes on when you say "Xbox On (for the Xbox), Xbox Watch TV (to bring up the TV)." Channel navigation can be ordered up by voice, but finding your HD channels may be a problem. Using the "Xbox Select" command can highlight the selections you can make, but if you have some 500+ channels, remembering names can be a little bit of a chore.

Yes, that's my complaint (had to make one). Remember folks, this is Microsoft. They may not get it right the first time, but they'll iterate until they do. It is how software folks think. I went with the XBOX because of that thinking as PS4 / Sony may not have that drive to iterate and get better... admittedly I don't have direct experience with that however.

But back to that $100 difference, remember, the games will likely be cross platform, but what else are you doing with that console. At my house? It gets used for the various video services, fitness classes and Xbox One only iterates on that and makes it better. So would I recommend it? Yes I would. YMMV.

title: Don't sell your blu-ray player....
comment: This is a powerful and very attractive console. Unfortunately, Microsoft's plan for a completely integrated entertainment experience is flawed by an unbelievably terrible DVD/Blu-ray experience. It's annoying enough that you have to download an app to play disks, but it's infuriating that the movie experience is completely ruined by audio/video sync problems that no amount of pausing/stopping/re-starting can resolve. The lag between the video an sound grows to ridiculous lengths - I've witnessed 2-3 seconds! I've seen old dubbed kung-fu movies that sync up better than the Xbox One. If Microsoft would fix this, they'd have a near-perfect console on their hands.

Also if you want to have music playing you have to have it in snap mode which takes up a fourth of the screen and you also have to go through Microsoft's music store and spend your hard earned cash. On the 360 you could plug in your ipod or even rip cd's onto the hard drive and play music in the background. It even replaced the game's music with the sound effects still there. If you wanted to change the song you would just press the middle button and you could pause, mute, change the song, etc. This with many other features have been stripped for the X Box One and I have no clue as to why. Graphics are a slight upgrade and it will only get better I'm sure. One cool thing is how you can seamlessly switch between all your apps and pick right up where you left off in your game. title: Great Entertainment Center
comment:
I ended up getting both the PS4 and Xbox One, and I have to say that overall they have a lot of similarities. The big difference, in my opinion, is that the Xbox One is more of an Entertainment Center and the PS4 is more of a Gaming Center. As far as gaming goes, I see a slight improvement in graphics, but overall the game play has not changed much other than adding voice commands through the kinect. This is a cool feature, and I love being able to shout out commands as I am running and gunning, but it is minimal, and wouldn't think twice if it was removed. Where the Xbox shines is how it interfaces with your TV. I love being able to switch quickly between my Xbox and TV without effort. Being able to pull up Amazon Prime, Netflix, or HuluPlus vocally without having to switch between multiple devices feels like I am in the future. I used to use my PS for watching blurays, but I have switched to using my Xbox so I do not have to switch between TV video inputs. Also, I'm someone that gets distracted easily and will pause a movie during the boring parts and do something else or watch something else and come back, so this fits perfectly for me. I switch to something else, and when I get bored with that, I switch back. As far as the PS4, that is more of a gaming console. When I play a game on the PS4, the graphics are stunning and easy to contrast to last gen. With the needed improvement to its controller to align more to Xbox's design, I do not feel as hampered playing FPSs. Also the PS controller has a speaker within the controller, so when I picked up an audiolog and heard it through my controller for the first time while hearing the game from my TV, it was an absolutely amazing experience. I can not wait for the next Dead Space iteration as I can only imagine how awesome the audio experience will be. So after about a month, I've fallen into a habit of gaming with my PS4, but since I'm a casual gamer, I end up spending majority of my time on my Xbox as I tend to relax most watching TV and movies. So depending on your preferences for entertainment and relaxation, either console is great, but if I could only select one option, I would prefer the Xbox over the PS as it aligns more to my personal preferences for entertainment.
As far as the controller using AA batteries, I know this has been a contested complaint between many users with a lot of people finding it a frivolous complaint. For me, with the money spent and the next gen advertising that went on, I expected the power source of my controller to be more akin to my smartphone than my flashlight. If Microsoft wants to make money off of add-on products, they should have followed Sony's lead and gave one short cord for multiple controllers and sell charging stations or additional charging cords separately.

title: Great product but a pain to setup!
comment:
Let me start off by saying I have never owned a previous Xbox, my last gaming console was the Nintendo Wii and before that was the PS2. With that being said, WOW what a console! Things have really changed over the last eight years and before then (referring to the PS2)!

I will start off with my only negative experience. SETUP WAS A PAIN! When I first plugged in my new Xbox One, it would not power up. I had to unplug the cord from the surge protector and the unit, waited about one minute then plugged it back in and it powered up! That should not have happened to begin with. Then I tried to connect it to my wireless network. It would not pick up either SSID that I was broadcasting (5ghz and 2.4ghz). I tried to manually configure it and that would not work. I verified everything was working on the network side and it was. All my other devices within a few feet were working just fine and had a strong signal. (Keep in mind I have a four year degree in Networking, I have multiple wireless routers configured to extend my range, etc... So it wasn't a networking issue) I could not reboot the Xbox One, so my only choice was to pull the power cord. I was worried to do this due to the device was trying to do the initial setup. I had no other choice, so I pulled the power cord and waited a minute (with my fingers crossed that it would boot back up properly). Well it did and then it found my wireless network, I was able to connect it to the network and move forward. Then it came to the mandatory update. I waited for a half hour and no progress was made on the update. I then verified my 15mbps download speed was still active and it was. I waited a little longer, just to be on the safe side. Finally after a total of 45 minutes and the update not starting the download, I did the only thing I could do. PULL THE POWER CORD AGAIN!!!! With my fingers crossed I waited another minute, plugged it back in and booted up the Xbox One. It did pick up where it left off stating it needed to download and install the update. I clicked accept and instantly it started to download. Within a matter of minutes the download was complete and the update was being installed.

So after all this headache and well over 2 hours I had my new Xbox One up and running! This is my only complaint.

Now, onto what I like about the console! The kinect is great for my little girl! She loves it and enjoys playing Zoo Tycoon on the Xbox One. The graphics are AWESOME! Call of Duty Ghosts looks and plays amazing, although I currently stink at online play.

Whats just OK with the Xbox One? Well the TV integration to begin with. You must have the Xbox One on to watch TV. The console cannot be in standby mode or off to watch TV. To me that is not a true HDMI passthrough setup as Microsoft claims. This is annoying for people who visit (such as family) who want to go downstairs and watch TV, there is the extra step of turning on the Xbox One. I hope this gets fixed with a future update. I wish you didn't have to buy Xbox Live Gold just to use some of the features such as, Netflix or Amazon Video. For online gaming I can understand the requirement, but not for these third party applications. The voice and hand controls do not always work, but them seem to be OK. I'm sure this will get better over time with patches and updates. I also wish there was some sort of stand or mount for the Kinect! I had to purchase one for it to sit on top of my TV. Without it, the Kinect would not be in the recommended height range (2-6 feet off the floor).

I would highly recommend this console to anyone looking to buy the current generation video game console or looking to upgrade! Now I wish my friends who have Xbox 360's would upgrade so we can play online against each other!

title: Great hardware, OS could be better
comment: As a piece of hardware I really like the xbox one, it has a great baseline of specs. I especially like that it reduces the amount of controllers I need by doing a pretty good job of being an all in one machine. It is now my bluray player and cable box, both work well. I do have gripes about the efficiency of the OS but I have to remind myself that this is what i should expect with the first generation of a new platform. title: A Good System
comment:
I would recommend Xbox One to any big gamer. I think any big gamer should have the Wii U and Xbox One or PS4.

The Xbox One is a great system and has found a way to appeal to the masses. It works well most of the time and the games are very enjoyable The launch line up leaves a lot to be desired, like most launch games on a new system. A better future is coming for it though. It will be great to see Titanfall later this year and also Halo.

Xbox 360 owners will be pleased, but disappointed in what is lacking from the prior system.

Ryse: Son of Rome is Microsoft's almost hit it answer to God of War. Battlefield 4 and Call of Duty: Ghosts both deliver better graphics, but same gameplay. Dead Rising 3 is pretty much Grand Theft Auto with zombies. Killer Instinct is a reimagined version of the original, but does not touch new territory.

I loved how the Xbox 360 had you press the middle button on the controller and you could see who was online, also how much battery left on your controller. All that has gone out the door with the weird new Windows 8 set up.

There are also many glitches within the system, although they happen 5% of the time. I've had games and apps suddenly close. Killer Instinct, I get out of matchmaking and the game is still looking for players somehow. Also, the system loads sometimes, kind of like a PC.

It will be interesting to see how the system home screen and glitches are improved. I am looking forward to a game that puts the Kinect to good use like on the Xbox 360. Also, will be interesting to see how Microsoft decides to keep finding ways to make more money within games and apps.

title: a good start
comment:
i'm a pretty big gamer so i was really excited when XBOX 360 started getting more into multimedia. When I heard the the XBOX ONE was going to be a multimedia "hub" I signed on right away. I got my XBOX ONE hooked it all up and..... played Killer Instinct, a 25 year old game. Don't get me wrong, I was really excited to play it again after all this time but it seemed sort of anti-climatic. there was little else to do on the XBOX ONE right out of the box. No XBOX live arcade. No demos. No video content except for the subscription apps like Netflix. I really lacks the sense of community that the XBOX 360 has gotten me used to.

the Kinect interface is good. seems more responsive than the 360. that said I still used and play my 360 a lot and having 2 Kinects seems like a waste. I would like a way to chain the 2 systems together.

So basically the XB1 is a good start. I'm excited to see what Microsoft will add to it. Hopefully there'll be a way to download XBL arcade games and 360 games eventually.

title: Very Cool, But Not as Good as the 360.
comment:
The Xbox One is a good gaming console. It's fast and sleek, but lacks key features that the Xbox 360 had for the streamlined social experience. While it's a good system, I feel it doesn't touch on the greatness of the 360. The Xbox One is missing key features like sending invites to friends to join games, on-screen friend and message notifications. Sometimes the voice activation doesn't work properly. Sometimes, the console picks up your voice while you're playing a game - the Xbox will listen to what you're saying and hijack your game by pausing or even exiting completely. The controller is worst of all. Without ANY WARNING what-so-ever, the controller will lose battery power (very quickly, I might add). At least the 360 would give you the blinking light show and say "Hey, your batteries are dying - get a new set" Surely, the Xbox One has a feature like that too, it's much better, and newer, of course!" But, you'd be severely mistaken.The controller just dies and that's it.
Overall, it's a pretty buggy system and I hope Microsoft will iron the kinks out soon.
That being said, the games are fun, the system is very fast, and there are a lot of cool features to give you, the player, a very enjoyable and fun social gaming experience.

title: Sit and wait
comment:
I feel I should have waited to get this product. The first night I brought it home I had one game with it, and it wouldn't load. After 1hr it still was at 0% so I looked online and it said to disconect from Live. Once I did that the game loaded to 3% which was enough to play. Once I was playing everything seemed fine.

I like the idea that you can watch tv while you play however it seems you need to have a cable box. I tried to set mine up with just antenna use and thus far no luck, though Xbox does seem to know how to talk to my tv such as volume and turning it off.

I am sure once more games come out I will enjoy it more, but the loading is a real pain. Even the demos I tried to download take forever, I could blame it on my internet connection but that isn't the only issue.

Oh about that game that I had issues loading, well it stalled at 92% never has reached 100% and when I reconnect to the internet it says I need an update for the game and again it just stalls out and I can't play while it is updating, so I have to keep uninstalling it and unplugging to let it build back up to that magical 3%. xbox support has been no help they keep telling me to do what I am doing and still no luck getting to 100%.

If you haven't gotten it yet WAIT. With the lack of games that are out right now I find myself using my 360 more because I only have the one game and I am almost done with it, since I can't get to 100% I can't do the online so I am trying to space it out till I have more things other then demos to play.

If you plan to use it as your multimedia hub it might be worth it to get it now.

Id still recommend it, if you are patient

title: Great Gaming Console
comment: Xbox One is a great console. That being said, I would have loved if Microsoft had kept the requirements that it had before. One, being that it had to always be connected to the internet. In this day, most people are not unplugged from the internet for more than hours at a time. The potential for games with this requirement were high! I also loved the ability to share my library with a friend. I'm a halo fan but most of my buddies tend to play call of duty. If they kept the system intact, I would be able to play his digital copy from my xbox while he plays his "Physical" copy. But this is the console we have, might as well get used to it.

title: I love my Xbox One
comment: The Xbox One is a great console. It is very fast with the loading times as with the multitasking. Voice commands are good, and the Kinect is better than expected... free P90x, Insanity and other work outs available for those with Xbox Live Gold, and the workouts really are great. The game can tell u when u arent doing the move as the instuctor as properly, and once u do it right it will tell u... or if u are workin out a little slower it will tell u to try to pick up your speed... it tells u how many calories u lost and everything... its amazing. Gaming aspect is as great as the PS4 graphic wise because I have the PS4 as well, but for me I think Xbox has more of the games I want to play (Call of Duty, Battlefield, Titanfall, Halo, Destiny, Forza, etc...). Plus the network on Xbox Live is much better than the PSN (PlayStation Network). I haven't really experienced lags on my 10meg internet speed. The controller is incredible once u get used to it, and it is perfectly shaped in your hand. The downfall I can say is that the software on its operating system needs an update where it is easier to use party chat like on the 360, it needs to update where it shows how much battery life your controller has, how much space u have on your hard drive, etc... BUT like I said they will have an update so I'm alright. I'm still using my turtle beach headsets from 360 but really u can use any headsets because the Kinect has a built in mic that u can use for chat. Great console overall and highly recommended... My brother has an Xbox One as well so when I get to play on his Xbox, I can sign under my account and everything loads just as the one on my Xbox. My Xbox Gold is usable as well as the digital games I have as well, which is only Killer Instinct at the moment because my other games are discs. If you decide to get the Xbox over the PS4, you won't regret it!

title: Xbox One Review
comment:
However, the Xbox One really drew me in because of all the "next-gen" feeling features that it included. I'll go through each of those features and my thoughts on them now. I should say that I've owned the Xbox One for a few days now and put in about 40 hours using nearly off of it's available features.

Games: This is the main reason people get the new consoles right? Ok, so maybe that's not totally true for the Xbox One because of all the media features it includes, but gaming is still at the center of what this console is meant to do. So far I have Dead Rising 3, Forza 5, and Just Dance as my games. None of these games is far and away better than the previous gen, but it is noticeably better. I expected this though, because it's not like we are going from standard def to high def like we did the previous generation. What really impresses me is the amount of content (e.g. zombies) on the screen at once the Xbox One can handle. I'm easily steam rolling hundreds of zombies at once with no slow downs. This is definitely in my opinion the best launch exclusive game. Forza 5 looks great and feels next gen, but the game itself doesn't really draw me in other than just for 15 minute burst racing sessions. Just Dance is a bit disappointing, but that is more a dock on the game itself. The Kinect portion works fantastically from what I can tell. Which leads me to,

Kinect 2.0: Wow, what an improvement. The precision is fantastic for both motion and speech recognition. I honestly don't think it's misinterpreted any command that I've given yet which blows my mind compared to where the previous Kinect was at. I can't wait till more games tap into this feature more. This might be the biggest surprise of the new Xbox One yet. I'm glad they made it such an integrated experience and bundled them together. It truly improves the experience. Yes, they could have made the Xbox One cheaper by not including it, but then it wouldn't be nearly as great of a product.

Interface: This is the part that I think needs the most work. I'm familiar with Windows 8, so overall I think it looks great and navigation is usually straight forward. There are just some things that standout. First would be the friends list and messages. It's much harder to look at your friends online and read messages than the 360. I'm hoping this is fixed soon as it seems a lot of people are complaining about it. Also I think the "pins" could be done a bit better. Make it easier to arrange them. Sometimes it takes too many actions to get to popular games/apps. This is made drastically easier by voice commands though which I've started doing every time.

TV Integration: This is the feature that I'm still getting used to the most. It takes a bit of time to relearn a new interface and way to navigation TV, but so far I think it's a big improvement over my normal cable box interface. Navigation is super simple with voice commands and it's a lot more customizable for getting to my favorite channels and looking at the TV guide. My favorite part of this is probably the "snap" feature where I can watch TV, but split the screen with something else. This has worked really great for me so far. I do think it can get even better though with better content to snap to the side. I also think the audio streams need to be able to get controlled. Right now they just play over each other which can be a mess. Should have voice commands to turn some on/off up/down. My wife also hasn't had much difficultly transitioning to watching TV through the Xbox. She's to the point now where she likes it more because it removes a lot of steps we use to have to do with remotes and she likes the voice commands.

Design: I'll admit that I don't really care about this that much. Is it big? Ya, it's bigger than my slim 360, but it fits on my TV stand no problem and I don't expect to move it. I like the look too. It's simple which I like. It's super quiet which is the most important thing in my book after my airplane engine original 360. The power brick is on the outside, but I don't care. That's hidden from view behind my stand. It keeps the Xbox One really low temperature which I hope increases its lifespan.

Controller: The 360's controller was my favorite of all time. It felt amazing in my hand and it was extremely durable (I only broke one, and that's saying something considering I'm a notorious controller thrower). The Xbox One? I'd say parts of it are better and parts of it are worse. It feels a bit more like a toy than the 360. It's lighter and feels a bit more flimsy. Maybe it's not, time will tell. The triggers feel amazing, but the best upgrade is the thumbsticks. They feel great and are easy to use. I don't expect any thumb fatigue from these. Lots of people say d-pad is upgraded which I'd agree with, but I didn't really have any troubles with the one on the 360. My biggest gripe about the controller is piece of plastic that seals in the battery at the back of the controller. I don't think it seals tight enough and wiggles around slightly which bugs me. I also don't like having to pay extra for a battery pack and charger. The battery charge lasts a long time so far, but it better with the price that I paid for it. Better have a long shelf life or I'll be pretty disappointed. The controller is extremely responsive, but so was the 360's controller. I'd say overall I like the controller a bit less than the 360, but who knows if that'll change overtime.

Other apps: The selection of apps for the Xbox One is good, but not great. It has all the standard ones like Netflix, Hulu, but is missing my personal favorite from the 360, HBO Go. They said they'll get that eventually and it can't come soon enough (the main reason my 360 is still plugged into my primary TV). Yes, you have to have XBL gold to use these which is a bit awkward. But my question would be why would you have an Xbox One and not have gold? If you just wanted to stream then a roku is way cheaper and smaller. Xbox One is mainly for gaming and XBL gold is super integrated into gaming and is one of the best features about the Xbox brand. Like I said earlier I'm not that sold on "sharing" features so I don't really plan on using like the Twitch app. Overall, the current selection is OK and what's there works well. It just needs more. I will mention that I'm a big NFL fan and like all the NFL app integration into the Xbox One.

title: Great System For Everything
comment:
Got my system for Christmas was a little iffy at first coming from a ps world back to Xbox but very impressed with everything and haven't used all the features yet.

Pros:
Looks great
Controller fits nicely in hand
Kinect sensor
Controller battery life
Voice controls
Xbox live
Online play

Cons:
Kinect mic doesn't always hear voice controls the first time.
The mic can be a little to sensitive to different voices, playing madden picks up my kids voice or a cough and sometimes selects plays etc..automatically.

Having pretty experienced games since the Atari impressed with how far video games have come and what the future holds for this xbox and the next one.

Once hook everything up and use all the features with the one. I don't know if I would go back to a playstation other than to see if any difference.

You can't go wrong with either system I'm sure, but the one is worth it and any updates would make it a better experience.

title: Xboxone review from a PC Gamer
comment: I am a high end PC gamer and here is my review of the xbox one.First of all I have to say I am ah struck by the graphics of this console. When I first fired up Ryse son of Rome I was impressed by the realistic facial anamations ,refective armor on the soldiers and fluid movement.When I played Dead Rising 3 the numbers of zombies on screen at the same time was incredible! I did not experience any frame rate problems at all. Forza 5 looked awesome and ran smoothly with good competitive AI. I know some of the games are upscaled to 1080 p but I really had a hard time telling the difference. As for the kinect the voice commands worked good most the time.I used it alot when watching movies. The only gripe I have is the long install and loading times.As a PC gamer I am impressed with this console.By the way I dont think the PS4 is that much more powerful than the XBOX ONE.

Microsoft decided to bring it's widely successful (no not really) windows 8 menu function into it's Xbox one gaming console. This makes for frustrating window surfing often forcing you to just use the voice commands to allow for any fluidity. But if your like me, shouting at your xbox just seems weird.

title: Good system, lots of options.
comment: My son wanted the Xbox One for Christmas and was extremely excited once he opened the gift. However, since owning the new system, he plays the Xbox 360 more than the One. Not many games are available that he enjoys right now but I expect his play time to increase as new games are introduced. I enjoyed the many options available such as Skype, Blue-ray player, and internet browsing. The Xbox One also allows you to directly connect your cable box to the system so you can "snap" between the game or cable but I found this severely weakened or interrupted the signal so I had to connect the cable box back to the television again. No need to elaborate on the graphics since everyone knows it is better than the 360. One other problem I found is when my son and I are watching each other play (we only have one controller), the Xbox will disconnect the controller because it recognizes another person in the room. This becomes annoying after a while and my son quits out of frustration. If you primarily play video games, I will suggest the PS4; If you want more than just a video game system, try out the Xbox One first and compare the two systems since you will invest a good amount of money on your purchase. Overall, you can't go wrong with this purchase.

title: Great game but allow time for set-up
comment:
Overall, once set-up is complete, this is a great gaming device for the entire family.
Pros: Advanced games, Great Picture and movements
Cons: Lengthy set-up and support was poor via chat.

There is no description in directions related to wireless set-up, probably considering is tool all day to download. Even on chat, they couldn't help me. I went to a Gamestop and they helped us figure things out. It would be best to bring game and tv near your router to do it but I didn't want to take my tv off the wall. Microsoft could at least mention that wireless will work but will take hours of download time.

The only other complaint is, I wish the system came with some sort of mount for the Kinect bar.

title: Should have waited...
comment:
Let me first start off by saying I'm a huge XBOX fan and I'm disappointed that I can't leave a better review. I should have waited until next Christmas to buy the XBOX ONE. The only games really available are XBOX 360 games and I'm not able to play those games with my friends that are still using the 360 (different servers for the ONE). The XBOX menu is complicated and you pretty much need a user manual to get a private chat started with a friend. The controller feels great until you have to plug in the microphone, the connector basically doubles the size of the controller. I tried running my satellite TV through the XBOX but you lose clarity and it's no longer high definition. I figured any of the apps available on the 360 would for sure be available on the ONE, if not more, but that is not the case (where is the HBO app?!). Microsoft needs to get some software updates going to improve this and make it worth the money.

All in all, I haven't had any "problems" with the ONE, I'm just disappointed. I actually hooked back up my 360 so I could play COD Ghosts with my friends that don't have the ONE. So now my $600 console is collecting dust...

The graphics look nice... but I hate that I spent $600 for graphics that are a little better than the 360.

title: xbox one
comment: What can I add about the Xbox that hasn't already been said? The system is quite a bit bigger than the 360, both in size and weight. I would say it is close to the original Xbox in size. Setup is simple, but the device still revolves around using the Kinect. I personally don't have mine hooked up (I don't have room in my living room to use it, even though they say that the focal length is less than Kinect 1). This leads to extra steps at startup because the system uses the Kinect to log in profiles instead of allowing the user to select a primary profile and logging that in. You would think, if there is only one profile on the system, it would be logged in as default, but that does not happen. As a result of not using the Kinect, there is a little symbol of a crossed out Kinect in the corner of the screen while on the menus, reminding you that you are using the system in a way not intended by Micro$oft. If I can say there is one great improvement, it is the controller. Even with batteries installed, it is lighter than the 360 controller. The shoulder buttons and triggers are redesigned and more comfortable to use. The controller rests easily in the hand. Biggest downside for me right now is the game lineup. I am not impressed by the launch lineups for either system. I chose the Xbox over the PS4 because there were more launch titles coming out for the Xbox in which I was interested. Unfortunately, so far that number is two. Both games (Forza and Ryse) look great and I would recommend both. Time will tell which system gets the better games.

title: Good console with great potential
comment:
The console is a great leap from the original Xbox, but only a minor leap from the Xbox 360. The graphics, interaction with Kinect, and controller got beneficial upgrades, but the interface, achievement system, friends system, and communications have either remained stagnant, or suffer from being rushed to market too soon.

Overall I'm very happy that I own the Xbox One. I would recommend it if you love Xbox as a brand, enjoy the Xbox exclusives, and don't mind waiting for the library to fill out. If you're still happy with your Xbox 360, you can afford to wait a while, the Xbox One will only get better with age.

My only minor complaint is that the voice recognition has won my wife over but I have friends and family over sometimes and it would be nice if they could use the remote to turn on the xbox and not have to use voice commands since most of them are not familiar with the xbox controller.
Again, overall I love the apps, especially amazon prime. This system is only going to get better as new games and apps come out. There is a ton of potential for the product to become even better.

title: Known issue with this mac.
comment:
When system is idle long enough to dim the display/go to sleep, the screen fades to black. Trying to wake up the computer causes the system hangs with a black screen. Only a hard boot will bring system back. Any unsaved documents/code files are lost.

Case numbers:

524999600 - Repair No: R107528152
#15550585 - Black screen if attempting to prevent sleep

title: No where to go but up!
comment:
I actually purchased the ps 4 first, as it was a less expensive next gen machine. I am not knocking Sony - it's an excellent product. But I have owned the other 2 Xbox's and I am a fan of the Microsoft gaming platform. So I returned he ps 4 and paid the extra for the XB1. It's not backwards compatible - I wish I could benefit from the library of the 360, so I could use my existing games and purchase used games while waiting for new XB1 content. Yes, I know I can use the HDMI pass through and keep a 360, but I don't want to maintain 2 systems, 2 controllers, etc.

But the graphics are excellent, I am enjoying the free content with Killer Instinct, Kinect Sports Rivals, and the demo games, and Forza 5 is excellent. As time goes on the library will increase, there will be updates to make Live better, and soon we'll be able to buy used games and not go bankrupt!

title: A good console that has a LONG way to go.
comment:
I have mix feelings about this console but it is indeed a good console none the less. There a lot of strange things with the Xbox One going on and I see this console is going to need a lot of updates to really show what future this system holds. The Xbox 360 have many features that makes it simple that this console does not. I'm just going to break this down as quickly as possible:

TV and Video apps : I do enjoy the video and TV features very much. The voice commands makes it much easier to get to switch video apps. Sometimes voice picks up and sometimes it doesn't; often times you have to repeat yourself but when it works...it works pretty well. I like having HDMI IN and watching cable TV on it but if you ask me it would have been so much better just to put a cox input in the back of the device and work with cable providers in areas. Apps pretty much needs Xbox live so you have to pay a monthly or yearly sub to use things you already pay for like Netflix and Hulu, This absolutely makes no sense when their competitors like Wii U and PS4 doesn't have these apps behind a paywall. Why do I need to pay to use You-Tube? So far app apps work without a hitch, but there are some Apps on Xbox 360 that missing from here. Also I don't even know why DLNA is missing from this console. That is something they should add back in.

OS: Its pretty much Windows 8 on a console. Some will hate it and some will love it. that depends on the person. I really don't mind it but the OS really feels like its still suck in a "BETA" stage at this time of writing. Everything is in deep layers and its not very intuitive. There have to be a better way to organize this console OS. Once Microsoft fix this it will be an awesome. I would like a way to organize my pins better personally so I can have games and apps from each other.

Games: Games looks great but I'm a PC gamer and have already been spoiled by finer graphics. That's not to say the Xbox One doesn't hold its own and the games looks awesome for what it does. Enjoyed Killer Instinct and I have to say one of my favorite on the console; pulling off combos on this game is very satisfying. Forza Motorsport 5 is a beautiful game and pretty much a great racer in my eyes. My girlfriend enjoys playing COD and Dead Rising 3.

Every game I have tried have to be installed to the hard drive, There is no way around it. You will simply have to wait until the game is ready to play. For me this is not an issue because I use Steam but I pretty much can see how console gamers would be annoyed at the wait. But then again with games like GTA V and COD Ghost on PS3 and Xbox 360 had to be installed on the HDD. That's pretty much what the future is now so you have to get use to it going into the new consoles.

Here is where my problem comes in...The Digital games in XBL marketplace is still the same price as when you buy it in stores. Amazon has Forza 5 pretty much for $50 while on Xbox Live is still sitting at $60. For them to expect us to go all Digital with out games why not have some weekly sales already? if you want to be like Steam show some promise to the gamers that you can pull this off Microsoft. Otherwise Digital will always be dead in the water.

Design: Its a black box and yes it looks like a VCR. Which doesn't bother me at all because at-lease now this console is well ventilated from the Original Xbox 360. What bothers me is the glossy shiny black on this console and its really annoying. It baffles me why they didn't go with a Matte color all the way around. This thing is a massive dust collector and after 2 days of use it already collecting dust upon it.

Kinect 2.0: I like using it to be honest. When it works...it works well. My girlfriend and I often find ourself using the voice commands the most. Like I said before sometimes a repeat is necessary but I do see updates coming in the future to fix these problems. None of the games I tried that used Kinect 2.0 really work that well with motion controls but the one app that did work perfectly was Xbox Fitness which I love using. Kinect Sports Rivals was not a good example and it was more frustrating then fun.

Overall: Yes, The Xbox One is a good console and its really solid. I have to hand Microsoft that even after all the terrible PR they are going through. You really get a lot for your money....but to me this console isn't worth the price tag of $500. I would wait until the Xbox One is $400 or less because truthfully the Xbox 360 and PS3 would still tie you over for at-lease 2-3 years. While the Graphics are great they are nothing earth-shattering that you would need to have RIGHT NOW. This console needs A LOT more updates and I do mean a lot before it can really shine but I believe once it receives that treatment this will be one of the best consoles out there even with the negativity surrounding it at this moment. I will not be returning my Xbox One because I see there is a pretty big future and promise as long as Microsoft stick with it.

title: Migration from previous Macs very Slow
comment:
Great Machine if this is your first Mac, otherwise....
Don't expect to use this computer the same day if you are upgrading from a previous Mac, Upgrade takes hours and hours. Apple has stripped away all the useful ports (to save a few pennies) so wireless (or a TimeMachine drive you have to buy) are the only options. Wireless has to search every possible IP address to find the other Mac, takes *forever*. Apple needs to consider hiring engineers who can use USB to connect 2 Macs to the same USB hub and allow fast upgrade without needing *any* network. Very disappointing. Apple forces you to buy several accessories to upgrade at all. Very, very disappointing. Real poor quality.

title: So Far....Very Good...
comment:
I have had my Xbox 1 for just over a month. While the game selection isn't great yet overall I am impressed. The graphics truly do "wow" you at first much like the 1st time you saw a 360 after playing an original Xbox. It took me about 20 mins to get everything set up. If you have set up a computer and harmony remote I don't think you'll have an issue setting up XB1. I have it set up to control my TV and AV receiver. I was impressed when I went to set up my AV system that all my equipment was already loaded with their ir codes and I just had to find the model # for each (much like setting up an Harmony Remote). One other suggestion if you use Surround Sound and have your cable/sat box running through the XB1, make sure you enable the Beta box for digital surround sound. Another nice addition to XB1 is the addition of 5Ghz N wireless, it's nice to be able to separate video to the 5Ghz channel and leave other devices on 2.4Ghz.

The only negative(s) I have found are:
1) voice changing channels-for whatever reason just about every channel I request sounds like E!HD to XB1. A channel I never watch so using the voice to change channels is about a 50/50 proposition for me. It also has a hard time figuring out what Comcast Sportsnet Bay Area is...so keep your remote handy.
2) NFL App-in the small print to use most of the great features of the NFL App you need to authenticate. I have accounts with DirecTV, Comcast, and Suddenlink none of which have a deal with The NFL to authenticate the NFL App on XB1 (or iOS).
3) there is a known issue that as of this writing causes freezing issues with 1080i pictures sometimes. This happens after the machine has been left on for an extended time. Rumor is Microsoft will soon be pushing through a firmware upgrade to help resolve this.
If you run into this problem put your finger over the power button on XB1 this will have the machine do a full reboot and should fix it.

title: Total entertainment system
comment:
Got the console in early January. Initial set up can take some time. Thought I had the green screen of death, but if you leave it (can take up to 15m) the update will finish. Also had to finish set up before it would connect to recognize my profile...after that no problem.
I do run my cable through the xbox and it recognized my system and had no problems with set up. The xbox version of a tv guide is clunky at best. Does not recognize the names of all channels like HGTV off the top of my head.
Overall voice commands are OK, hope they improve. Biggest issue is volume drowning out voice commands. My kinect is right under my TV so after a certain point the xbox can't hear me.
The snap feature is pretty sweet, but when you snap TV while playing a game it seems to lag..i've seen other people report the same thing.
Seems like I have a lot of negatives, but I see it as stuff that can improve but doesn't take away from my enjoyment. I own 2 games, COD and Assassins creed. Enjoy both very much. Overall I like it a lot, and would love it if they improve voice commands. Price is high, but that's what gaming systems are coming to.

It has great potential. It is fantastic when it does work which is 70% of the time .

title: More than a gaming machine
comment:
This is so much more than a gaming machine. To me, one of the best, and lessor known features, is Xbox Fitness. This alone is worth the price I paid for the Xbox One. There is so much free content you could literally do a different work out each day.
Another nice feature is the interface. I know there has been some negative press about the interface but it's really well done. I believe most of the negative press is user error rather than a bad interface. The Xbox One is very specific and the quicker you learn the commands the better it responds. For example, if you say, "Xbox On", the unit turns on and sends a command to turn your TV on. But you have to say it exactly like that...Xbox on. To turn the unit and your TV off you simply say, "Xbox Turn Off". See the difference? I'm guessing some people say, "Xbox Off" and it doesn't respond. Trust me, the interface works as long as you use the correct command.
If you are on the fence between the PS4 and the Xbox One give the Xbox One a try. Xbox has more titles and it's far more than a gaming machine. It's very cool to talk to the Xbox versus reaching for a remote. An perfect example is telling Xbox to "Mute" or "Turn up/Turn Down" the volume on your TV. With Sony, you have to have your remote close by. Both consoles are in need of more games. And both do streaming and blu-ray playback.
I've been using my Xbox since launch day and I'm very pleased with it.

title: Nice system so far...
comment: The setup was easy. The new kinect is nice, need less space and works smooth. Connecting the TV through it cool too. Using the snap feature for split screen is nice. Cannot wait for more games to come out. Wish there was more.

title: Excellent platform
comment: The Xbone is a great platform for all types of TV entertainment. I use it for gaming, Netflix, TV, and DVD playback. The interface is east to use and you can switch platforms very easily. The major downfall is the lack of installed Dolby sound and the inability to use my 360 headphones for gaming. I have to run sound through my TV directly to headphones and does not have the same sound experience as the 360. Chat feature only works with inferior headset provided by microsoft. After market headphones are not fully capable until microsoft releases a patch cable. As of today, no news when that cable will be released. I am amazed why Microsoft did not do a better job with the gaming sound on such an expensive device. Once the sound issue gets updated, the Xbone will deserve 5 stars.

title: Bad system, 360 was better
comment: It's very glitchy. I already had to exchange it because the first one froze up. The online party system is a joke. Having to install games, etc. the graphics are the same as old gen. The controller is better, everything else is worse.

title: Great ambition but a work in progress
comment:
The Xbox One makes a convincing argument as an entertainment centerpiece. The Wii U brought a universal remote capacity to consoles but the One feeds the television directly through the device. The Kinect voice commands mostly work once you learn the cadences except the one time out of 10 it frustratingly doesn't. "Xbox on" is usually the biggest culprit for me (a bad one to not work 100% of the time, huh?). TNT, CBS, and other three letter networks can be sketchy in voice commands too. Hopefully the March update will enhance voice recognition. Despite the occasional frustrations, I already can't imagine my living room without it. The One easily found my receiver and television in setup and I added my Vizio 2.1 soundbar through settings later. This has drastically limited the growing number of remotes I use.

Currently the One lacks HBOGO and a few other streaming services. ESPN, Netflix, Fox, and others show great potential for the device in streaming user experience. I still use my Apple TV on occasion as we await these companies releasing their app.

Games are not a console mover right now but that should change in 2014. Most feel like slightly better 360 games or near exact rips. With time developers will start pushing the console's power. The Kinect 2.0 has been a treat for my girlfriend with Just Dance and other games of that variety.

Overall, the system has a great deal of utility but Microsoft needs to work out the kinks. Also, 3rd parties need to get their services and games transitioned into this generation. I can see the one being a great purchase today for techies but a better purchase this Fall for pure gamers.

title: I love this thing !!
comment: Honestly I was pretty hesitant to purchase the XB1 after reading hundreds of reviews lots of negatives it seemed but I gave in and I'm glad I did this thing rocks ! Once it's setup and the settings are where they should be it moves along with ease voice commands are sweet especially adjusting the volume and turning it on and off the voice commands work about 95% of the time I suggest watching the tutorial for the voice commands I feel like most people complain about it because they're not using the commands it was built to hear and it's pretty specific once you get used to it it's a breeze. Gaming wise it's def an upgrade at graphics and the framerate is silky smooth. There aren't many games out right now but remember its a brand new system the games will come in time. I did have some bugs and hiccups along the way with some of its features but Microsoft customer service cleared it right up and haven't had an issue since Microsoft will be addressing the issues as they develop with patches once again this things only a couple months old. I'm impressed and would recommend to anyone that enjoys a sweet lil piece of entertainment tech

title: Great laptop for those willing to make the switch
comment:
I have been looking for a laptop for sometime because I was not happy with my Windows RT tablet. I got so frustrated with it I decided as an early graduation present for myself, I'd go out and buy myself a descent laptop I could use for college and beyond. I was going to go with a Windows 7 laptop, but my sister has a Mac and says she loves it. My cousin is an Apple guru and highly recommended Mac to me. So after a few days of thinking about it and what I'd use it for, I decided to make the plunge and bought my Mac.

I have to say, once I bit Apple's fruit, I never want to go back to Windows, (even though I still know how to use it and all.) I LOVE practically everything about it and have virtually no complaints about it! The only thing I have against it is that it is a bit on the pricy side. But other than that, I love every aspect of my Mac and would HIGHLY recommend it to anyone looking for a good, thin, lightweight laptop from a tried and true name.

10/10 Love it!

title: Great next-gen gaming console
comment: I switched from the Xbox 360 to the new Xbox One. I really enjoy the games available and the performance of this new unit. Voice commands are very responsive. Xbox Live is as good as it gets for online multiplayer gaming. Kinect works great for recognizing me and signing me in automatically. The unit is quiet, powers up fast and has worked very well for me. Proprietary chat port on the controller is a bummer. Microsoft knew they were changing the port and should have gotten this info to gaming headset manufacturers so they could have shipped an adapter. Microsoft says they are going to release an adapter but still have not 3 months into launch. Additionally, they need to update the Xbox software so that the output for headsets allows Dolby 5.1 and Dolby 7.1. Another obvious option that should have been shipped with the console at launch. Other than that, it's a great unit.

title: Best gaming console on the market today
comment: Xbox One is the latest generation of Microsoft's console gaming system, and it's better in every way than the Xbox 360. This time around the Kinect is included so no need to purchase it separately. The new system is much more powerful and gives you the best possible gaming experience. In my opinion it's superior to the old Xbox 360, as well as the PS3 and PS4. One killer feature is the ability to pass your cable or satellite signal through the X1 using the HDMI cable, then use voice commands to change channels. Speaking of voice control, the X1 continues to build on what was started with the 360, it's much easier and more flexible to control with voice commands.

title: Worth It
comment: I had an Xbox 360 and wasn't sure I wanted the new system. How much better can the graphics be? I had Battlefield 4 and FIFA 14 for both systems and can tell a difference between the two systems. For Battlefield 4 the detail is better, especially the shadows. FIFA ran better and looked better too. Honestly, the games are only part of why I like the system. I have Comcast and my cable box is routed through it. Now I can change channels, view the guide, and more via voice command. My Xbox will automatically turn on the cable box, surround sound receiver, and TV when I turn on the Xbox. Voice controls allow you to turn it on or off without pressing a button. I used the Xbox to Skype with a friend this week which was awesome. I use it to watch Netflix and Bluray movies. My Xbox Live Gold account transferred from my Xbox 360 so I can still quickly parry up with friends. The voice quality is better than the 360. Definitely get the play and charge kit for the controller so you aren't putting batteries in all the time.
