title: Masterpiece
comment:
As I am writing this review I just notcied the date. I bought this beautiful beast in june, picked it up in November. I had my original X1 returned to Microsoft because the face plate was just a tinny bit lose. Yes I know that seems very picky, but this is a 500.00 piece of hardware I want it perfect. I'd return it if there was a faint scratch on the bottom, I want it perfect.
Never the less, my new X1 runs like a dream. Visually stunning with Ryse and Forza, quick on ghost, and the controller is comfortable with hours of Dead rising 3 under my belt. I've tried to burn my console out but it's handled everything ive thrown at it.
On a real note, the kinect has issues. Its fantastic for chating and when people say " when it works its a dream" its a true statement. Skype is a beautiful thing on the X1. Although I dont use it a whole lot. The thing is "Xbox On" works 25-50% of the time. Most of the other commands even if the xbox is listening you need to say "xbox" first. "Xbox volume up" works okay it only brings my TV volume up by 2, then 3. All of these issues will be fixed with a patch coming in March. Plus Microsoft is giving it a 10% power boost so all games will run native 1080p. 60fps.
Anyway get an X1 you wont be disappointed as long as you give it a real try. Go through the ropes with it, set it up. Play your 360, PS3, PS4, Wii, Wii U on it. There is a lot of promise to this console the future is bright and big for the X1. SO! Thank you for reading, I hope you enjoyed my review please hit the "Helpful" button!

PS: The rechargeable battery pack really saves time, I use this for my X42 and my controllers.

title: My favorite notebook yet!
comment:
I've been a dedicated Mac user since 2003, and a fan of Mac notebooks for that entire time. I've owned a Titanium, a G4 PowerBook, and a few Intel PowerBooks, but this is my first foray into the modern portable Mac; all my others are desktop systems. I bought a MacBook Pro principally for its weight (or lack thereof) as my intended use for the system was to augment my iPad and iPhone with a good data entry and content creation platform, and to keep it light enough to travel with the Wintel piece of junk work forces me to carry. The system is speedy enough for any task I've thrown at it, and has unbelievable battery life! It has been everything I thought I wanted and more.

Some insight into my product selection: I considered both the MacBook Air 11 inch and the MacBook Pro 13 inch. I rejected the 11 inch because the screen was so small, and it was a non-standard aspect ratio. However, now that I've been using my 13 inch MacBook Air for a while, I have to say it looks gargantuan! I frequently wonder if the even smaller 11 inch system could have done the same job. My gut says I made the right call, but it's questionable enough that it's worth noting. The hardest rejection to make was the Retina display on the MacBook Pro. It is simply stunning in every regard, and if I thought I would be doing a lot of photo editing (unlikely, probably just arranging collections for me) then I would have spent the extra money to buy it. In the end, I intend to use my MacBook Air for word processing/text entry, some presentations, and the occasional application or web site I can't use on my iPad. The Retina display just wasn't a necessity for my needs.

Having said all that, if the rumors are true and a 12inch MBA comes out this year (or a 12 inch MB Pro) I may well trade up. That form factor would address my size/weight concerns in all likelihood (my MBA is as heavy as I will go) and I can't imagine any future Apple product without a Retina display.

title: Great but some flaws
comment:
The Microsoft Xbox One is great for some people but some people they may not enjoy it as much. Let me begin by saying that when I opened the box my first reaction was that it is massive. The console its self weighs over 12 pounds, and the power brick is also very bulky. When I plugged it in it felt like an amazing machine that runs so fluid, so fast, it was wonderful. But the one thing I love most about the Xbox is its remote. The remote is so responsive, so fast, it feels so comfortable in your hands, and the weight is so perfect. And from what i heard if your racing in Forza and you crash on the left side the remote will vibrate on the left, not just the whole remote. Nothing can be done to make the controller even better! The programming in the Xbox is also amazing i love how you can switch from one game to another with out even pausing it! And if your in a middle of a race on Forza and you want to hop on something else really quick. When you go back on Forza it will automatically continue the game from where you were. And depending on what type of person you are you may or may not like the features on the Xbox, I personally don't like the features. Here are some of them: when you walk in the room the xbox turns on by itself, you can talk to the xbox to turn on and off, if you go to a friends house it will automatically know your face and download your profile. It almost seems like they have taken it to far with the kinect. All that stuff may be great but when I wanted to start playing game I put in Forza 5 and it just wouldn't work. I waited for a few min and still nothing. Then I put it in again and nothing again. I put in gta 5 and nothing again. And so for me not worth it. And also the price is outrageous! $500 for the console, one remote, and the kinect! Madness! And for most people they are going to buy another remote and some games. Well I did, it piled up to about $700. So for me $700 on a console that doesn't work isn't right. I would give it 5 stars if my Xbox worked, but since it doesn't I would give if 3.5 if i could.
I would buy it but not everything at once. If I were to go back I would get the bundle its self and one game. Then over time another remote and some more games! Now just be careful! When your out there picking out your Xbox make sure you pick a lucky one!

title: Latest and greatest gaming console, plus more!

title: Great gaming console but does more...
comment:
First I have to admit I was pretty much split down the middle when it came to picking the Xbox One or PS4. Obviously I went with the Xbox One but I will get the PS4 later for sure. So if you are in the same boat and trying to make the same decision, perhaps this review may help you a bit.

Pros:

To The Point:
Easy out of the box setup. If you're looking to just use the Xbox for purely gaming, setup is very quick. There is a 500mb mandatory update right at the beginning. After the update, everything else is pretty simple and you can get right into playing your game disc or downloading games to play (Live is required.) Personally, I watch tv, mainly sports so my setup also included using my Xbox to control my TV, A/V Receiver, and cable box (comcast). There is a super user friendly walkthrough for this entire process, so don't be nervous about not getting it right. Just be patient, follow the steps, and you'll be good to go.

You're in Control:
While the HDMI in featuer is really cool, what I love most is the fact that Xbox allows me to control my television with voice commands via the Kinect. I can even control DVR functionality with voice commands as well. This is very intuitive and pretty cool to use. I've heard of some people having trouble with the Kinect understanding their commands but I haven't run into this issue yet.

Hidden Gems:
Another feature I kind of discovered since it wasn't really advertised, at least to my knowledge is the fact that I can seamlessly resume a game or app I was last playing before I turned off my Xbox. For example, if I turn off the Xbox in the middle of playing NBA 2k14, when I come back the next day, I resume at the same spot. This is very convenient.

Bells and Whistles:
Other features that are more obvious, like snapping apps, using gestures to expand and collapse apps, etc. work well but I find that I dont use these features too much for now at least.

Cool and Quiet:
The system boots up fairly quickly and is very quiet. And from what I can tell is able to stay pretty cool even after hours of staying on.

Pretty Visuals:
The games look amazing. I have two games that I purchased: NBA 2k14 and Dead Rising 3. Two very different games but both have stunning graphics. I don't know exact frame rates or how to get that info but from what I can tell, both of these games run smoothly. If this is the first generation of games, then I am excited to see what the future holds, which leads us to....

Cons:

Weak Library (for now):
Right now I'm enjoying NBA 2k14 and Dead Rising 3. NBA 2k14, is available on other consoles, even last gen. Dead Rising 3 and a couple of other games are Xbox exclusives. To me, the current exclusives and game library overall is lacking. Watch Dogs, and Project Spark (beta access should be available this month) were delayed. I know a few games are set to come out in spring and summer but the real blockbusters are set for winter 2014 (Watch Dogs, Destiny, etc.). At least we have something to look forward to.

I hope this review was helpful :D

title: Ultraportables don't get any better than this.
comment: I did a lot of shopping for ultrabooks, and had my choices narrowed down to Samsung, Lenovo, or Apple. In the end, I had to go with the Macbook Air. Keep in mind, I plan to install Windows 7 on it, and I saw no need for a touch screen, as was standard in the PC ultrabooks at this price range. I just wanted something well-built, fast, and focused on a long battery life. It doesn't get any better than Apple when it comes to build quality. I almost feel like I could chop wood with this thing. Mac OSX is actually a decent operating system, and I'd keep using it, if not for several key programs I require. But installing Windows is no trouble at all. I chose not to pay extra for the larger SSD, considering it did not include double the RAM at that price. I figure I'll just hand this off and buy myself a new one when I run out of space. For now, an external hard drive was a better investment.

title: Solid!
comment:
I received my Xbox One from Amazon on Friday at 11:30am. I was fortunate enough to get the day one edition. I had a chance to test the Kinect voice commands and Dead Rising 3. When the voice commands work, they are amazing. I was able to say Xbox Snap TV and my roommate could watch his football game while I played Dead Rising 3.

The motion sensor was accurate when I played Kinect Rivals or when I was shaking a zoombie off in Dead Rising. Most new innovative technologies have issues in the beginning. Sometimes the Kinect did not hear me. I think this can be fixed in a few software updates. I look forward to the innovations with Kinect, since it is bundled with every console.

I played Dead Rising 3 and it looks good, but not amazing. I was amazed at the shear number of zoombies the game could get on the screen. Waves and waves of zoombies would be produced. There were frame rate issues and some serious aliasing at times. I hope they add a patch like they did for AC4 and COD:Ghosts for DC3. I have only seen a little NBA 2K14 and it looks gorgeous so far. I have not played Forza 5 or Ryse, but both of those games look like they will show the power of the system.

I enjoyed using the HDMI pass through on the Xbox. I have my gaming PC going into and it works with no lag. I can seamlessly go from my PC to my Xbox, all in the Xbox interface. The Xbox glass app for your phone is really cool! You can use your phone to control TV, Blu-Rays, menus, and everything Xbox One. I downloaded it just to try it and it is a great alternative to use use phone instead of your controller for media apps.

Honestly, the Xbox One is an ambitious piece of technology. It is trying to be the center of your living room. A lot of bets have been placed on the Kinect leading the way. I think it is possible, but the software needs work. I am most excited for the potential innovations of the Xbox One over the PS4. Overall, I like the system and I look forward to the Xbox One future!

title: Very Enjoyable System
comment:
I bought this system on December and I have to admit this system is great! I love all of the games and the graphics are amazing so far as well as the games, while there isn't a lot of them out yet the ones that are; really are amazing. For instance, Battlefield 4 on the Xbox One is one of the BEST FPSs i have ever played! I mean going from 32 players online to 64 is absolutely crazy. When they talk about all out warfare that's exactly what they mean. And if you're a racing fan then Forza 5 is the game for you. That has everything that gear heads could ever want and hope for. And the new controller does take some getting used to but once you do it feel much more comfortable and way better than before with all of the new features that they added. The new overhauled Kinect is also something great. The camera now records in 720p with HD Audio. Overall this is a big step up from the 360, especially if you're a Xbox fan. I'm very happy with my purchase and I'm really excited to see how this system evolves as the new games release and how the community starts to grow.

Now the bad stuff, the really only bad stuff that I have found in my opinion would be the party system as well as the overall UI. While the User Interface isn't bad it's just very different from the 360 and does take some getting used to so you can learn where everything is at (but that's also another reason to use the Kinect, it makes navigating everything much quicker.) But the party system currently is a very big pain in the butt to learn. Microsoft is releasing an update on February 11th to fix and add a lot of stuff that people wanted or didn't like about the UI or anything else. All in all, great system, really fun to play, and something that I really look forward to watching grow.

title: Great Casual Entertainment Center/Gaming System
comment: I am tech savvy and do extensive research before making a choice. At first I was leaning toward a PS4 due to the simple reason of it being priced at $399 and more powerful hardware. I researched on websites including Youtube videos. I was very hesitant about my purchase, but all I can say is WOW. This is a great system. Kinect works about 90% of the time and it amazes me how responsive it is and it is easy to learn with the tutorials it has on Xbox Live. My only gaming purchase thus far is Dead Rising 3 and I must say the graphics look pretty good and its a fun game. Eventually graphics improve over time once gaming developers fully understand the machines capability. Overall, I have no complaints. If this was the "other system" over time it would sit and collect dust due to me being a casual gamer, BUT the Xbox One is in constant use so you really feel like you get your moneys worth regardless the extra $100 for the kinect. You won't be disappointed with this buy!!

title: Solid system with a bright future ahead of it.
comment:
Solid gaming system, easy to setup and the included HDMI cable is appropriately long enough for any normal setup. Kinect voice commands generally work great when properly setup and set a part from speakers (should be at least one foot away from any speaker), gesture commands also work fairly well but take a bit of getting used to. Provides smooth switching between games and apps (especially when using voice commands to jump directly to something else). It's always satisfying to get home, walk in, and simply say "Xbox On" to have the Xbox One, TV, and Audio Receiver all turn on without needing to find, or touch, any remote.

There are a few things that can use some changing; however, they're already addressing many of them with upcoming announced updates (2/11/14 and 3/4/14) so I'll hold off on listing them. Two were no USB keyboard support and no controller battery indicator, but those are being resolved 2/11/14.

Long story of randomly composed thoughts short... I'm quite satisfied with my purchase, and as with the Xbox 360, it will likely get better and better with each update.

title: Great Console
comment: System is very sleek and fits well with the rest of the entertainment system I have. The power of the system is ready for the future and is too advanced for the current technology of most entertainment areas. I don’t pay for TV service so I can’t use the snap feature to watch TV and play a game at the same time, but you can still do other snap features aka Skype. The new Kinect is 18 times better than the previous version and works fantastic. The Kinect even has a 4-40 screw mount on the bottom for attaching to a tripod (which I use). The angle adjustment is manual unlike the previous model, which I think is good, but others my think it is a step back. I like the manual adjustment because it is just easier than fighting the software to get the right angle and you only have to do it once. The controller no longer feels cheap and you can tell the time has been spent to get everything right. The only other problem is that there is only one USB located anywhere near the front. It’s on the left side by the front corner and is a pain to route the charging cable (not included) to charge the controller pack (also not included). The other many USBs are located in the back and who wants to crawl and squeeze behind the entertainment center every time to attach a device. The console its self is VERY heavy and quite a surprise. Be sure to put it in a secure location that won’t fall. Buy the Charge and Play kit the same day you buy the console, it will save you money and time. FYI the XBOX ONE smart glass is a separate app from the 360 smart glass. The XBOX one is a must buy and it feels like it will be a great product for years.

title: Not all it's cracked up to be.
comment:
I've had this system for a few months now so figured I'd right a real review. Not all these five star one sentence reviews saying it's the greatest ever.

Now I've been an Xbox fan since the first system and had my doubts as soon as the press conference was aired and some of the facts and details started emerging about the console and games. It seemed like they were most worried about the connect and watching tv on the system, not actual gaming. I put off getting the system at launch until I could play it and Playstation and read some of the reviews. I finally picked it up since my brother was nagging for me to get one and the games one 360 started going downhill fast. Most of the players submitted to the new system leaving few people left on 360 for games like MW2.

Upon setting up the system and starting to mess around with it I didn't get the hype and supposed cutting edge technology. You could feel it was geared towards trying to be an all in one entertainment system and rushed to meet a deadline. Right off the bat somethings started bugging me. Like no rechargeable controllers, no wireless headsets, etc.
The cable on the headset is really annoying and seems to get tangled and in the way more than a standard cable. I've also had alot of problems with the headset not connecting properly and having to re plug it in several times till it works (several friends and people online have the same problem). The controllers eat through batteries insanely fast and I'm glad I already had rechargeable batteries laying around. Pretty lame not to have a rechargeable controller or wireless headset. I guess so they can sell it to you later and make you buy accessories

The interface and how it's set up is pretty annoying. If your in a game talking to someone in a lobby you have to go back to the home page just to see who's online, which cuts off your mic unless your in party chat. Then when you click on friends you have to wait for the lag as it pops up a feed list telling what people have been doing for the past few hours before you can click on friends. You also have to join a party just to play in a game with someone which is a huge pain. So you have to join your friends, try to get in a lobby together, then for games like Forza, switch off party chat to hear everyone else in the lobby. Also there is no avoided player option now. So get someone who's terrible or team killing or crashing on purpose and you can't do anything about it. Also muting in all the games I've played is a pain and still a pain in the lobbies.

Onto the Kinect sensor. Yeah it's a cool toy and that's about it. The wow factor looses it's luster pretty quickly. The in game commands are neat but I could easily push a button to do it, besides having to mute my mic to yell medic without yelling over the voice chat. Also news flash people. The Kinect still sounds terrible if you use it as a mic unless your tv volume is really low and playing in a tiny room close to it. It still picks up in game noise and sounds like your across the street. The main annoyance is that when you unplug the mic, Kinect automatically starts acting as a mic. So if you don't want to talk or unplug the mic to answer the phone, Kinect still pics it up. I don't know how they thought that was a good idea. No you have people not using the mic and blaring the volume and you have to hear echoes all game.

The graphics aren't that big of a jump for being next gen. I've got a high end 60'' led and good surround sound and don't see what all the hype is about. It is a bit noticeable, but more sound quality than anything. I've seen it at other people's houses and no difference either.

The games are a complete disappointment for the most part. All of them have bugs and can tell were rushed. I'll go more into the games I've played so far. It seems like the days of buying the game and maybe 2 map packs are done. You get a sense after awhile that the game is short on purpose just to sell add ons later. I'd easily be happy playing MW2 and older Project Gotham Racing games.

Battlefield 4-
Wow this game was messed up at launch. Story mode wouldn't save the campaign, so you had to play the whole thing in one sitting. Way to easy on the hardest difficulty too. I'm not the greatest gamer but I could easily walk through the game. You also felt like you had your hand held and with the team the whole time too. No cool solo sniper missions or stuff like that. I still have every once in awhile have it freeze on the black screen in multiplayer and a few times in campaign. I finally broke down and got the premium and can say this game is worthless without it. Between the add ons, maps, they even connect you to games quicker. Unreal. The quality of players is terrible (worse than the average cod player) I see people level 40+ consistently going negative like 4 kills and 20 deaths. Alot more trolling on this system as well, especially if you use claymores. I keep having people team kill me cause I've set up a claymore and they run into it when I'm off the beaten path. The worst part is you get booted for it and people will do it on purpose as well.

Call of duty- Ghosts
I got suckered into another piece of trash from this franchise. After the initial problems with BF4 I decided to give this a try and the benefit of doubt that it might be good with it being on a new console. WRONG. The story mode was ok but short and eazy. You also have your hand held by your teammates the whole time. No real good characters and they expect you to think a few guys can take on the world and all it's armies. Not like previous games were your against a terrorist cell or a small group. It also ends with the usual "we'll have another game in a year for ya". The online graphics and feel are a joke. It's like black ops with new guns that all feel the same and numb. Some of the maps make zero sense with the story of the game too. The maps feel like they started with a box and saw what they could stuff into it. Again they tried to make flowing maps to keep the gameplay quick but all it does like before is make a haven for campers. A few of the maps you could literally stand still against some backgrounds and blend in too good.

Forza 5-
Probably my favorite game for this system, partially because they've ruined FPS games. There are less cars but it doesn't seem to have that big of an affect. It's just lacking in tracks, especially F1 and larger circuits for the higher class cars. I can't believe they released this game with out the Nurburgring. That is ridiculous! But I'm sure they'll improve with updates the price of the game..... Another aspect I hate is parts of the track that bring you to a dead stop. I know it's to keep cheaters from cutting turns but they've seemed to do it on parts where the slightest mistake and the race is over, then on other tracks you can cut entire turns and take them wide all the way to the wall with no problem. Once again, trying to stop cheaters has made others suffer.

The quality of gamers is pretty low until late at night. You get alot of people flying into turns with no brakes, waiting for the leaders to crash into them, sitting in tight parts of the track and going just fast enough to turn off the ghosts settings. You should be a ghost if your a lap or two down. Basically wait till the kiddies go to bed to jump on.

Apparently muscle cars and Jeeps are super cars in this game too. I don't care how much work you put into a 5000 lead sled, it won't brake, turn, and handle like a sports car. That brings me to the tuning aspect of this game, which is out of hand. This game takes alot of skill out of actual racing. I've had guys blow by me smacking into walls and making mistakes in the same car and pull away with huge leads. It's a war of how much time you have or what's the best tune you can find. I mean a new GTR in c class? C'mon.

Now I've always considered my self a pretty good gamer. Usually top 3 in most races, positive k/d ratio and on the top of the teams. This game just takes alot of the skill out of the equation.

assassins creed black flag-
Can't say much about this game in detail as I only played it for a bit. I actually really liked it compared to the previous ones I played. I can't imagine the online being great.

My only hope for this system in the near future is Titanfall and the supposed next Project Gotham Racing game (if that ever happens). I'm sure Halo will be another let down and waste of money. If your going to pick this system up and sick of the last few COD games, don;t get ghosts, nothing has changed and their just milking that franchise.
If your new to Battlefield, it's way different than COD (possibly why I see so many people going negative). The first few guns you get will make the game very stressful.

All and all, thanks Microsoft for dropping the ball. This system had so much hype and potential and you guys failed. I can turn on my tv and switch to games without you and the Kinect.

title: Great Potential
comment:
Disclaimer: I own both a PS4 and Xbox One.

I picked this console up on launch day, and so I've had some time to use it in various ways. This console has some great potential once Microsoft gets the bugs worked out of it. Both the PS4 and this console were rushed to market as it is apparent by the issues both console's have seen. I've used the TV function and it works great when it is able to load. I've contacted Microsoft about the random apps not loading and crashing, and they mentioned that many of these issue will be fixed in the next software update, so stay tuned.

After the overhaul that the 360 saw in it's long lifespan, I know if Microsoft doesn't drop the ball, this console could do some great things.

I will say I love the new controller, it is much more comfortable than the 360 controller, but in my opinion, still a better controller than even the Dual-Shock 4 from Sony, even though that is an improvement.

I like the hardware design. It blends in very nicely with my home theater gear, and I don't even notice it. I also like that the console detects how much ambient light there is, and dims the logos on the Kinect, console and controller appropriately.

title: Pricy, but All in One
comment:
Was definitely torn between the Xbox One and a PS4 for a while. Went back and forth comparing the two, and when it came down to it I ended up picking the Xbox One, and so far I have not been disappointed. Been a bit over a month now and I have had very few issues.

First and foremost, the new graphics engine is great. Having used the Xbox 360 for many years, you can see a noticeable difference with every aspect of game details. Switching between games/apps/tv, etc. is quick and seemless (most times negotiating with a simple voice command).

The ability to stream my TV through the Xbox and watch a show while playing a game is pretty sweet. Also, all I have to do is walk into the room, say 'Xbox, On', and it turns on the TV, Cable box and Xbox (though I will say you are borderline shouting commands at times to get it to register). The audible commands extend to TV as well, with the ability to say 'Xbox, watch ESPN', etc.

The price was a bit of a wallet-stretcher, but the Kinect is much improved, including a HD camera, facial recognition and audible commands. XboxOne will sign users into profiles when they walk into the room, and it will automatically assign a user profile to a controller by reading facial patterns and their relation to the IR signal from each controller.

All this being said, the incredible graphics engine, the advanced improvements to Kinect (both visual and audible commands), multitasking ability, and the complete All-in-one system capability led me to the Xbox and it has not disappointed at all to this point.

Pretty much only use for my 500 dollar xbox one is to play blue ray and that's about it unless I spend 60 bucks on a limited selection of games to play. All in I say xbox one really missed the mark and isn't all it was hyped up to be. Don't waste your money it's not worth it.

title: Great console with some drawbacks
comment:
I picked this up about a month ago and I have to say I've been pretty pleased with the console so far. I'm sure you've read plenty of reviews detailing the great features the X1 has so this review will shed some light on some of the things I don't like about it. First off, this has terrible install times. You must install every single game to the console, there is no way to get around it. When I brought it home I spend a couple hours messing around with the voice and gesture controls. After that I put in a game and found out I couldn't play it right away. It took almost 4 hours to install COD: Ghosts. To be fair, you can play the game after it installs enough but the features of the game are extremely limited. I could play the story mode but I couldn't access any other part of the game until it finished installing. To be fair, I've read that COD takes the most time to install. I was able to install Tomb Raider completely in an hour and a half.
Download times are really slow. I could download an update for a game or a new app on my 360 in a couple of minutes it takes at least an hour on the X1, which makes no sense. I have a pretty good internet connection and I've never had long wait times on my 360.
The X1 also boots slower than the 360. I don't leave mine in standby mode because I don't want it eating up my electric bill so when I turn in on it takes a couple minutes to boot.

These are the only drawbacks that I've found. I hope Microsoft pushes an update and fixes these long wait times because these are the only things that make it feel like this isn't next gen gaming.

title: Game Changer
comment: I bought both this and PS4, and returned the PS4. The XBOX One is a game changer. The interaction with the system from games, to Skype to just watching TV is outstanding. Love the voice commands and the personalization of each user in my house. Microsoft finally got XBOX Live accounts right where we just have to pay for one account and the whole house has access. Forza is ridiculous, Ryse was fun, and got on the Titan Fall Beta...FPS games won't be the same, its that good. From the 360 the Kinect in the XBOX One is so much more sensitive and doesn't' have as much of the distance form the device issues that I had with the 360. Kids love Zoo Tycoon. I love walking into the room saying XBOX On, Go To TV, watch NBC all while I am just sitting down. Watch live OTA TV and hooked into my TV and Stereo with no issue. The Skype interaction will zoom in and out, pan as people come into view automatically. Just really cool. This is just so much more then just a game system, not even a comparison....

title: Far exceeded my expectations, great system!!!
comment: I was originally going to get a ps4(I still am soon enough) but decided to check out the xbox one since it was much more readily available. I bought Ryse and Forza motorsport. Since then I have bought battlefield 4 and still continue to be blown away with how great the graphics are and how fast the gaming is and being able to go back to watching tv or netflix and vise versa within a tap of a button or voice command. Speaking of voice command, I had a great time playing ryse with the kinect. I never thought I would be the multiplayer type gamer but the xbox one incorporates it in such a fun way that even the shyest person could have fun or at least see the fun in it. I can't even think about using an xbox without a kinect after having used it. If your still thinking about it and CAN afford it, I would say go for it. Titanfall is coming out soon and let me tell you, the beta was so much fun to play. I can't wait to get the full game and also Thief is coming out next week. I'm being an optimist for both systems but I am glad to be on board with the xbox one and not be biased towards any system. From what I've experienced with the xbox one, so far, so good. I dig it and I'm the last dude you would have thought to have said that.

title: This system has promise!
comment: Now that I have a teenager and my son is about to turn 11 years of age, we decided to graduate from the Wii and purchase this gaming system. It is my intention to STOP with this one, it is very expensive and it will be that last one that I buy. The clerk in the store persuaded me to 'upgrade' to the XBOX one; as it will have all of the newest/ best games... with many to be launched in March. It has already been a long two months waiting for these games to come out. We are not traditional "gamers", whose interest is peaked by the delay in releasing a new product. We are a family who would like to be able to utilize this system to play games among a group of friends/ teens who want to 'hang out.' As of this point, XBOX one is not at all marketed to this type of consumer: the games are all extremely violent or sophisticated, with the exception of the LEGO game, that holds zero interest for us. I hope that in March, I will be able to purchase some of the successful Disney games that the standard XBOX can handle. As I said early, the graphics are fantastic and the features of membership are nice; however, this gaming system remains primarily unusable until some variety of family friendly games is released. It is a frustrating place to be in and I am regretting not purchasing the older model.

comment: I bought the Wii U, PS4, and then the Xbox One. The Xbox One has the best graphics out of the three. If you want to see what the Xbox One is capable of with respect to graphics I'd suggest playing Tomb Raiders. I was somewhat skeptical about the Kinetic and have to say that I was surprised. It does a very good job at recognizing voice commands and the gesture function works fairly well. The only thing that really ticked me off was having to purchase Xbox Gold to watch Netflix. What is worse is that their apps are not as good as the PS4 and unlike the PS4 you need to pay to use most of the apps.. I must say that I was also very impressed with the Wii U and think this is possibly the best all around system for everything except playing blu-ray movies. The PS4 was the most unstable of all three systems and the graphics are only fair. If your a serious gamer I'd say get the Xbox and if your looking for an all in in one system get the Wii.

When this happens, you lose any game progress you haven't saved. I don't want to hate on Microsoft but this One really isn't worth the money.

title: Missing key features
comment: This review is for those with projectors and 3D TVs. I'm writing this while setting up the Xbox. A few things that are absolutely ridiculous for a new gaming console or even an old one for that fact. 1) The Kinect only has a 9' cord and NO extender available. This means that most people with a projector will have a Very hard time using the Kinect. You know, the reason why you're paying $100 more than Ps4. I have the xbox on a box in the middle of my room so the hdmi can reach my receiver and the Kinect can be under the projector. 2) No 3D blue-ray support. That's right. You can't play 3D blue-ray movies. Even the PS3 and a $40 player can do that. The Xbox one gets you no closer to one media device than the xbox 360 did. But at least the 360 has a Kinect extension cable. Heck, even the original Wii sensor had one. Save your money and buy a PS4 or plan on not using the Kinect or watching 3D Movies on the Xbox.

title: Great for games, not for TV and the multitasking.

The graphics are not as good as a PC obviously because if they were the console would cost over a thousand bucks. The Xbox One is trying to be ahead of it's time.
Watching TV on the Xbox One is not the way to do it. It's very slow when you're trying run the TV and a game at once, and switch back and forth. Also, the audio of peoples voices is cut out in TV shows when it have my cable box plugged into my Xbox. When I have my cable going straight to my tv, sound is fine.

title: Not bad so far but not really ready for prime time
comment:
I originally had a PS4 but I returned it after a couple of weeks because it doesn't even play CD's!!! How ridiculous is that? But so far I only like the Xbox marginally better. I'm not a fan of the Xbox controller but that's probably just because I'm used to the Playstation controller. I list Kinect as both a pro and a con because when it works it's pretty cool. The problem is that it only works about 70% of the time. Games load quickly and I like being able to pin apps I use most often to the home screen. My wife likes Xbox Fitness so that's a plus. Also being able to watch TV through the Xbox is very cool. No more switching between my gaming system and the TV. Very convenient.

Overall I'd say the Xbox is OK. Not really worth $500 though. We'll see how it improves once more games come out.

title: At the last minute picked Xbox, over PS4.I LOVE IT
comment: First let me start by saying: I used to be a playstation kind of girl. I talked so much mess about the xbox(but secretly wanted to try it), and advocated for the PS4. I really don't know what made me decide to go with the xbox at the last minute but im SO GLAD I DID! What a way to get introduced to the xbox platform? The graphics are AMAZING, I love the voice command features, I love the Kinect, I love everything about it. im also a windows 8 user so I get to sync my xbox and computer to each other. I also have my xbox hooked up to my cable box and TV so I can shut it all off and on just by saying 2 or three words no remotes needed anymore. Only downside is the limited number of games out for the xbox one right now, and I had an issue with the black screen of death but luckily I had already googled any known issues with the xbox one before it happened so I was aready prepared in how to deal with it. overall??? I LOVE THIS SYSTEM!

title: Should have waited
comment:
I am a loyal Xbox user and have had my 360 since it first came out. I should have learned my lesson back then when it comes to buying next gen consoles too soon. The Xbox One feels like it was rushed to get to the consumers (which it was) and as a result operations feel very clunky.

The voice recognition is frustrating to use. The kinnect camera only recognizes me 50% of the time, and I now have unplugged it as to avoid the frustration. One night I noticed a "buzzing" sound when I was trying to sleep and discovered the power brick has a internal fan and when you have your xbox in stand-bye mode the brick light and fan run 24/7. As you can imagine, a fan running non-stop is not going to last forever so I turned the "voice on" feature off.

The user interface also feels clunky and frankly is a major step back from the current 360 UI. Bottom line is, like the 360, I'm guessing the One will go through some drastic hardware and software updates over the next couple years and I am kicking myself for not being smart and waiting at least a year to pick one up. They won't have any decent games for at least a year anyway.

Lastly, the plastic used for the console and the controller feel very cheap compared to the 360. I'm not sure if they did this to reduce heat or what, but hard to imagine why the 360 should look and feel more expensive than the next gen model.

title: Love the new features
comment:
What's especially neat about the Xbox one is the way you can make it a media center that basically handles everything all in one place. You can connect it to your tv, cable box, etc and control everything in one place. If you turn on the Xbox, it will turn on the tv and cable box as well.

The biggest annoyance is the voice control. It tends to pick up men's voices okay, but my girlfriend only has 60% accuracy of the Xbox even acknowledging her existence. Changing channels with voice commands is neat except it often mixes up TBS, CBS, PBS and others. Volume control moves volume up of down only 3 clicks at a time. If need to move it a lot, you have to repeat yourself several times and it takes awhile. Also, fast forward and rewind are a bit off. It doesn't have a delay where it rewinds a few second after you say stop like my cable box does. That coupled with the fact that it takes the Xbox a moment to recognize my speech, I often fast forward or rewind too much.

title: Next Gen. In just about every sense.
comment:
The pro column is the victor in this decision. But only by an ounce, at a price tag of $500 it would be enough to sway none gamers to opt out. If you do/can spend those kinds of bucks then the xbox one is the console for you.
The only minor surprises for me were
- games HAVE to be installed on the console. Can't just pop in a disc and start shooting.
- for gamers whom like to have a large library of games. Storage space will be an issue. Not a question of if but when it affects you.
- not all headsets will work. Not until adapters are made and released.
-controller buttons click. Rather loudly actually

What I love
- kinect is awesome. Facial recognition and voice commands are top notch but there is a learning curve. Both for you and the console.
-graphics
- system speed and responsiveness
-games so far
-The oneguide
- bluray player (finally!)
-app selection is steadily increasing but will take time to be a decent assortment.

Bottom line. If you can spend that kind of money. Spend it. The xbox one is worth it.

title: Commuting computer
comment:
This computer is great for anyone especially students who just need a computer to take to class for notes or some minor tasks like spreadsheets or word processing. Its quick enough to start up and hibernate if you are just closing the lid and opening the lid. The microphone is one the best I have used when compared to the microsoft surface for a similar tasks. I can go through the entire school day ~ 5 hours of school use i.e taking notes or web surfing on the battery.
The cons are you can't have a lot of media files i.e music or video stored on the actual device. Any other software that is processor or ram intensive i.e matlab, photoshop, etc you might want to look at a more powerful computer

I love being able to walk into the living room and say "Xbox on" and all of the components turn on. (Xbox, TV, Receiver, Satellite). Graphics are also amazing. It's a big leap forward for Xbox and I am very happy with my purchase. Now MORE GAMES!

I don't pay for Hulu or Netflix as I have Comcast and all movie channels and it was nice to have HBO to go and Comcast on demand as I had access to hundreds of free movies as I paid separately for Comcast. I also didn't hook up xbox to cable box as I have X1 though Comcast and pay enough for it not to use xbox for it and x1 has Pandora and facebook and xbox does not. There is a lot of room for improvement and I hope xbox makes changes for the good like adding apps and games to xbox so members have access to them. My old xbox I had a lot of apps and games like pinball and other good games in market that were inexpensive but fun to play, I would expect to pay for membership to have access to a lot as the xbox one was 200 more then previous xbox and it would be nice to think of xbox one as an upgrade, but cant say that yet. If friend wanted this system would say to wait a few months for improvement.

title: XboxOne:Year One
comment:
I'm giving it a lot of slack, as it hasn't been a year yet, and that's usually a rough period where the device is really put through the trials of general consumer use. I think future software updates will definitely make remarkable improvements, but the hardware, at least to date, hasn't given me any trouble.

The voice-activation features is a lot of fun. Being able to just talk to my TV and tell it to pause feels like I'm in the future. There are some games that take advantage of the voice activation to mixed results, though. Need For Speed will occasionally pick a random word you say (either to a friend or to yourself) and think you're asking it to change the view, or go to the map. That's frustrating. I blame the game maker though for providing FAR too many keywords. I don't need to say "map" (or the myriad other words it thinks are "map"), if I can just press a button on the controller for the map. Being able to say "GPS repair shop" and get directions to the nearest repair shop, though, is fantastic.

On occasion, the voice activation gets a little difficult, though. You might find that it understands you completely one time, and then not at all an hour later. Again, I think this will only improve with future software updates.

Hand Gestures are definitely not there yet. It takes too much effort to get it to even recognize your hands first, while just using the controller instead (or even some voice commands) is far simpler. Microsoft needs to figure out what they're doing here. A hand gesture just needs to work, and won't be useful for everything. For example, I can either raise my hands up, wait a few seconds for the Xbox to recognize them, make fists (grabbing the edges of the screen) and pull them together to go the the Home screen, or I can just say, "Xbox, Go Home". So far all I've wanted to use a gesture for is just to swipe through pages. It's not responsive enough to be even half as efficient as just using the controller, though.

I do love the auto-sign in feature. That it recognizes me and signs me in as I sit down on my couch is as creepy as it is helpful (I expect the creepiness to fade over time). On occasion, though, this doesn't kick in at all, and I have to do it manually. Ridiculous that I would get frustrated with this, considering that I've spent the last decade signing in manually.

There have been a few times (I think four total since I bought it nearly two months ago) where the video output has blanked. This usually happens when a game seems to be busy loading or saving or doing something transitionally (i.e. processor-heavy activity). The only solution then appears to be to turn off the Xbox and unplug it. Simply rebooting doesn't help. I haven't checked forums yet to see why this is happening or if there is a fix coming soon. For all I know, it might just be some weird quirk in the interaction between my Xbox and TV. Seems like the kind of problem that will be fixed in an update soon. Still, it's easily avoidable if you just wait to go to the Home screen until after the game resolves it's activity.

I might have seemed to have had more criticisms than compliments to say, but that I still like my Xbox should say something. I see a great deal of potential in the product, and am looking forward to what they do with it in the future.

Overall the Xbox One is a good console that can be made great over time with some work from Microsoft.

comment:
I'm not going to go into great detail here. I loved the Xbox 360. I also owned a PS3 and ended up preferring the 360. My guess is like the 360, once they've spent enough time on it the Xbox One will be absolutely killer.

All that said......it was a half baked product that probably wasn't ready for prime time. Party chat is terrible. We own two in the house and have to buy the games twice. The system is not ready to run in quick boot mode without all kinds of troubles. It's very frustrating when it's not working.

Also it's a bluray player but it's so large small shelves are a problem, make sure your planned address for it has room behind for cords. No cd tray so be careful not to scratch your discs when putting them in. Large size seems to prevent it from heating up but keep it in an open area with ventilation. Not many games yet but expect that to change in time.

title: A lot of potential
comment:
Deciding what console to purchase at the start of a new hardware generation can be a tough choice. Ultimately, one of the foremost deciding factors should be software exclusives. You can rest assured that juggernaut franchises such as Halo and Gears of War will be exclusive to Microsoft's new console.

But what if you're still on the fence? I've owned my Xbox One for about one month now, and here's my first impressions of it:

The console runs everything very smoothly. The menu interface, media apps, and games run exceedingly well. A noticeable difference from the past generation. Console start up takes only seconds to complete. Voice commands work most of the time, and I've rarely had to repeat a phrase more than once. With voice commands, you can turn on the Xbox and navigate any sequence of menus quickly and easily without ever picking up a controller. The controller itself is an upgrade from the Xbox 360's, which was a very well received controller in its own right, with sturdy construction. Triggers feel great and the d-pad (the 360's biggest weakness) is greatly improved.

You can record game play clips approximately 30 seconds long, edit and save them after your gaming sessions so that those incredible moments you have while gaming can be shared. It's easy to look at a friend's clips and you can upload them to any device that uses the OneDrive app, which really opens up the possibilities for gamers who want to share and broadcast their experiences who don't have nice video capture setups.

Some features taken for granted with the 360 are strangely absent from the Xbox One, such as friend notifications. Being notified when your buddy comes online or starts playing the same game you are have not been implemented yet. Microsoft's goal of the One being the "all-in-one media experience" are only half-realized at this point. Many of the media apps that exist on the Xbox 360 are not present on the One as of yet. The big ones are there, such as Netflix and Hulu. But many others are not. I find the lack of a radio station app such as I Heart Radio particularly disappointing.

This review is the state of the Xbox One's features as of March 2014. A lot of the features and apps I mentioned that are absent will be added in the future. So if you don't mind watching the Xbox One growing from its infancy to its full potential, then this is an excellent buy with a promising future. But if you're looking for a feature-rich experience right out of the gate, you won't find many things truly new that aren't available on the Xbox 360 currently.

title: Great Start for the Next Generation Consoles
comment:
The Xbox One is a great system to own for anyone. The Xbox Live network is far superior to the PSN. I love the achievement and gamer point set up along with many of the new features such as recording your game to share with others. The graphics are great right now and will only get better as the game developers find a way to use this console to it's full potential. The voice commands with the kinect camera is a very nice add on, such as when you want to turn your console off after watching a movie or netflix you can say "Xbox turn off" and just like that it turns off without you turning your controller on. This is on giant step for the next generation and I am really happy with my purchase.

Now my one big complaint is seeing the amount of games that are still being released on the previous generation consoles while the current generation only has a handful, I know its typical but I would really like to see game developers roll out some current gen only games.

title: A Handsome Reward
comment:
Let's get this one out of the way = I love Apple products.

That being said I have lots of non Apple products. My work machine is an HP Elitebook (HP really should have named it EliteAnvil) running Windows 8.1, this MacAir replaced a Gateway running Windows 8, etc

I have an 2006ish iMac that I use as a server at home, still running great, but I digress.

I tried the 11.6 but it was too small, I tried the Macbook Pro with Retina but I run dual screen at home so I did not get the full benefit of the allegedly better screen.

I purchased this laptop because I needed something that will boot up quickly in case I have an idea that I needed to get on the web and also something very light. This MacAir fits both bills perfectly. It's insanely fast to boot up and is very very light.

The drive space is scant (I went with the basic 128gig) but so far I am at less than 30% used and I don't foresee myself adding any more than I have since I use the cloud heavily so it will work out.

On the older iMac, whenever I load my iPhoto library it starts having fainting spells, not so on this MacAir, works very well and very speedy. I don't do photo processing or have Paramount Pictures as a competitor so I don't know how it will work with heavy photo/video usage. But as far as regular Joe surfing web, doing accounting, school work, writing emails, etc it hasn't missed a beat and it ridiculously fast.

I recommend this to you if you need a higher performance light weight rig (i5 processor is very speedy especially when coupled with SSD) and if you want a laptop that you can actually carry with you on the road.

Go ahead, treat yourself.

title: Completely Satisified
comment: I've been running Ubuntu and Fedora on a Macbook Pro for the last three years. When it was time to upgrade the hardware I was intrigued by the MBA's super light chassis and amazing battery life, but concerned because there wasn't yet great support for Linux on the latest model. I've been using OSX exclusively since making the switch and, expect for the lack of an included package manager, the switch has been painless. If you're a solid BASH user you'll find it's the default shell as of OSX Mavericks. The MBA has been highly performant for light scripting and some number crunching in R. Battery life kicks butt and ergonomics "just feel good". It recognized Samba shares on my home server immediately as well as my Seagate GoFlex network drive.

title: Great System

There are some games that offer a graphical leap from the xbox 360. as for features the Kinect 2 and snap/tv add ons are great but its hard to see this going forward for Microsoft due to cable and direct tv slowly dying off. we are in a world of streaming and cable companies are dying off slowly. even tho the snap features works great for those that have cable. the snap and tv features are pointless which makes the xbox one a ps4 with the PlayStation camera. going forth the xbox controller feels great in your hands if you have small hands that is. the xbox 360 controller is still one of the best controllers ever made. even with the new triggers and analog sticks feel and precision. the triggers have a new rumble feel while in use for shooters and driving games for tension. the triggers are more slanted upward giving them a awkward feeling and will take some time getting used to. as for the tile interface that you get from windows 8 is something that 20% of the world knows how to use and is easy to get used to. but for others that are not used to. it can be a bit confusing. the system has its goods and bads and no one needs a new console at lunch expecting a lot out of the system. these nex gen systems need time and work to really make the end user get that this is a new nex gen system feeling. it takes time and great developer's to make that leap and develope only on these next gen systems before we feel that next gen feeling. overall I give the xbox one a 3.5 out of 5

The one thing you can not control is the DVR function on your cable box, I have Comcast. I have read that the control of your DVR along with the ability to record 4 shows at once is coming .
The Kenect is soooo above the old one. It reads your pulse from the vein in your neck and can tell the difference between an open and closed hand. It also comes with many free fitness programs.
The only problems I have had are the controller eats batteries pretty fast and I had a couple of minor lockup problems that required pulling the power plug and doing a cold re-boot. However I have not had a single problem since the last update.

title: Games look cool. Other things are terrible
comment: Where do I start? I got this for my business so when my kids were with me at work they would have something to do. I went with this instead of the PS4 hoping to eliminate the need for TV service and not have a computer. And Xbox One is supposed to be able to do everything. I go the Lego Movie game for it as the first game due to the lack of age appropriate games for my sons. It looks amazing. I go to set up my Netflix, YouTube, etc. and find out that you need an Xbox Live Gold account to access anything online. I do remember hearing about this when the console came out, but didn't pay much attention to it. My bad, I guess, but it's ridiculous. I got the Gold membership. Got online. I couldn't figure out how to go to the App store, or marketplace or whatever it's called. I wanted to see if they had the March Madness Live app so I could watch the tournament while I was at work. After 3 days of searching the internet to try to find out how to download apps, having every kid who came into my barbershop between the ages of 7-16 try to find the apps, I had given up. A nice man from Game Stop came in and after an hour of trying to find it, called his friend and was advised to turn off the console and reset it. Finally, the app store was on the screen! Yay! But boo!...No March Madness app. Really? for the console that can do everything? Yes, really. I checked the CBS website to see if I could watch it online using the Xbox One. Nope! No flash player on the Xbox One. What the heck? What is this, an iPad? Oh wait, the iPad has the March Madness app. So the iPad/iPhone doesn't support flash, but at least on those devices, you can view almost anything on their wide selection of apps. The ESPN app is decent, but not for actually watching games-only highlights and sports center... Someone had to tell me how to back out of the internet, because it has no instruction manual. The online support is horrible... I haven't had a Microsoft/Windows product since 1999 and this thing is not sweetening the deal for me to switch back. It seems to play any game, you have to sign in to at least one thing. To play NBA 2K14, you have to put in your birthdate to play a "quick game", which is anything but quick to start actually playing it. Nobody who has been in age 7-30 can figure out how to play a 2 player 2K14 game. If kids aged 12-18 can't figure this out, how do you think a 39 year old man who rarely plays video games is going to figure it out? And several of said 2K14 players have it for PS4. Both controllers are powered on and able to control the Xbox in some way. Just not as an actual controller for the game you want to play. That being said, the graphics are unbelievable. My kids LOVE Titanfall, they say it's the best game they've ever played, and I was very reluctant to buy it because they are only 9 and 10 and I'm a huge prude when it comes to violent video games. My last complaint is the lack of games appropriate for pre-tweens. I let them play on Xbox Live but only without a headset or mic. I've heard recordings of what kids their age say to each other on these games and it would embarrass Andrew Dice Clay.

The size and weight is extremely portable and it is so comfortable while sitting on your lap, not to mention it's silent. I cannot hear any noise from the computer running what so ever. The battery life is AMAZING, It definitely gets you at least 10 hours, when I have the screen dimmed about half-way it gets the full 11.5-12 hours on one charge, and it only takes about a half hour to charge completely from an empty battery. title: Good System, but some minor gripes
comment:
After waiting it out a few months I finally broke down and purchased an Xbox One. I have also purchased Forza 5, NBA2K14, COD Ghosts , Dead Rising 3,and Titanfall. Out of these games, Forza 5 and NBA2K14 look great, but are just ok otherwise, and COD and Dead Rising don't look or play much different than their current gen counterparts. Titanfall on the other hand hasn't come out of the console since it went in, and is so fun that it may justify the purchase of the console on its own.
As far as the system interface itself, my main gripe is the occasionally over sensitive Kinect functions. It will sometimes tell me the controller is disconnected if I move to a seat that isn't directly in front of it. Or it will think I attempted a motion prompt when I didn't. Minor gripes, and not frequent, but can be annoying at times.
I do like how you can switch between TV, Apps, Games, and so on quickly while keeping them running in the background so that you can go back to them with little to no loading. I also like how I was able to feed my DirecTV DVR box through the console, thereby giving it voice controls and a little more functionality.
Overall, I would recommend the system with the disclaimer that the game library is currently somewhat limited, and that there are some glitches that could potentially be patched with system updates.

title: Latest console looks like a win
comment: We bought this console for my fiancee, who is a veteran Xbox 360 gamer and clan member. I handled the setup, which was fairly straightforward. We have our Comcast cable box hooked through its HDMI IN port, and it set up the channel lineup quickly enough. My fiancee has been playing Call of Duty Ghosts, Battlefield 4, and Titanfall on it, and, in the case of the former two, she can see the added graphic quality over the 360. The voice control seems to respond better to me than to her, though, and sometimes requires me to speak somewhat forcefully. Of course, I have to turn the console on if I want to watch TV, but that's as easy as saying, "Xbox on! Xbox, watch TV! Stop listening!" (And, when done: "Xbox, go home! Xbox, turn off! Yes!") She's quite satisfied with the console, and I look forward to seeing what else Microsoft will do with it.

title: Excellent system-would get 5 stars with 3D support
comment: This is an excellent system. I would give it 5 stars if it supported 3D playback like the PS3. MS mentioned supporting this feature in the future, but we will have to wait for the update if this is true. Games play well and the controller is fantastic. However, like any launch lineup, there needs to be more AAA must-have titles. So far, Titanfall and MGSV Ground Zeroes are great, but games that take full advantage of the system's power are on the horizon, so will have to be patient from that aspect. Backwards compatibility would have been nice to help facilitate the transition to this system, especially when there are several months between the next wave of games in the Fall. However, the platform does well integrating TV and other services to help feature the system as a centerpiece for your living room. So the tradeoff benefits outweigh the shortfalls of backwards compatibility (IMO), just means I have to hold on to my 360 a little longer. Kinect 2.0 is a nice feature as well, but sometimes has issues recognizing voice commands if the room is not totally quiet. I'm sure this will/can be fixed with a future update. Overall, a great system!

title: Just the beginning.
comment:
I have been an Xbox owner since the first Xbox released. I have had no problems at all with the Xbox live service, and of course there was the incident with the Xbox 360 involving the RROD. In time Microsoft has fixed this issue.

For the XboxOne, the Xbox Live is still the great service it is known for. Currently though the 360 is still holding strong to it's life support while there are very few games for the One. And with Microsoft now attempting to take over the entire entertainment aspect of your home, it still has a few issues to fix.

The Kinect works as a voice recognition at the moment and doesn't really utilize much games, only a few. Kinect Sports, Xbox Fitness. And you get the option to use it to maneuver your way through the Home menu. The motion sensor is still (in my opinion) an add-on that should not be required. When the Nintendo Wii utilized the remote sensor to pick up multiple parties on screen, it was best used for those party games. And currently it's not holding up well for this beginning release whilst game developers are still in the process of making a fun game to use with the Kinect. In short, the Kinect should be a stand-alone peripheral. Getting it now, MIGHT be cheaper for the long run, but I wouldn't think so.

As for the One itself, their Windows interface is lacking. The previous Home Menu on the 360 was easier to move through. This feels as if I am trying to use a PC interface with my controller/motin sensor/voice commands. Your settings option is very limited in comparison to the 360 (unable to DELETE demos, NOT just uninstall. Why are you making me KEEP these items on here if I'm only using them once?) You don't have major customization as you did with the 360 (Themes, custom backgrounds. You only get a small palette of color choices for the squares). You can pin and unpin your favorites, which again feels like it's a PC. The home menu/interface feels like a downgrade from the 360. It doesn't feel as welcoming as before.

The console itself is silent, it's a huge beast of a console but it's sleek design is great. It can also be used to display your cable tv. It has multiple outputs in the back that allows you to watch TV so that you have one device/control taking care of it all. I personally have no use for it. If I wanted cable, I have my OWN cable box from the cable company I signed up with.

I use my Xbox One to play games. And that's what I think a console, ALL CONSOLES, should remain as. I am a fan of Xbox Live and I have been a member for over 10 years. I hope the future updates will change all of my issues.

I would recommend... just NOT YET.

title: A dark horse
comment:
The Xbox One is the subject of much debate in the gaming community as of late. Why? From first hand accounts it is all due to either the mere existence of the Kinect, Microsoft's E3 conference, or some strange emotional attachment to the console's competition.

What is the truth throughout all this grandstanding? The Xbox One is a good console, full stop. Is it the greatest? It would be silly to make that assumption for any console. It is good though.

The UI is clean and very reminiscent of Windows 8 (the system does actually run a version of the Windows 8 OS so that is expected), and the Kinect's voice commands really revolutionize the way one interacts with their media devices. The voice commands are very easy to memorize and actually quite versatile in that each option on screen can potentially be controlled by name simply by calling it out in the proper way. This means that for non-gaming use you can get by perfectly without having to turn your controller on.

Of course, there is a certain camp that insists the voice commands are not reliable, but that is simply not true. For example, it works about as well as Apple's Siri. If you speak with a heavy accent, play loud music, or have people talking over you, of course the voice recognition won't recognize you. The Kinect is designed to pick up a specific type of voice and accent; because of this, English(US) and English(UK) are separate options. Everything else is fair game, and if there are any issues, you can re-calibrate the Kinect's microphone within seconds to account for a noisy room.

The exclusive games are quality so far. Dead Rising 3 can simply be described as raunchy, rude fun (and everything that moniker entails with a few shocking extras not safe for work). Ryse is a simple but addictive game with surprisingly deep combat, I highly recommend checking out the co-op multiplayer. Titanfall is probably the cream of the crop concerning modern shooters. The downloadable games are quality as well, with games like Peggle 2 for casual play and Halo Spartan Assault for quick co-op games with your friends.

As for what the future holds for the console, that is anyone's guess but what is already available is nothing to sneeze at. I say do some research first then take the plunge if what you see tickles your fancy.

title: Next Generation of Console Wars Begins

Only time, and eventual updates and exclusive game releases will tell the full story of who wins this next iteration of the console gaming wars; but if you're lucky enough to be able to choose a next gen console and want a fully realized system that consolidates your streaming services, cable television and gaming preferences all in one centralized location, the Xbox One is a good choice as a foray into the next level of gaming devices.

title: Fantastic Home Machine
comment:
Gaming:4/5
Of the games I have played so far (Ryse, Dead Rising 3 and Titanfall) they are pretty good. The first two mentioned make decent and intuitive choices with the voice commands, making integrating them for the average player simple and fun. The multiplayer service is decent but at this time I have seen no evidence to think that the service itself has improved vastly, even with a 6x greater connection than what I had with previous consoles.

Controller: 5/5
Absolutely fantastic. Feels good in the hand, has a faster boot time than the 360 controller (about a second or so) and battery life seems to be excellent.

Kinect: 3.5/5
They did a good job with the Kinect. Better than the last round (360) but still - not perfect. The voice commands work about 95% of the time and the gestures don't really work at all. Have yet to try a Kinect enabled game yet (outside of voice commands), so this score could change.

Xbox Live: 3/5
The service is still as dull and bland as ever. With any new console at launch, especially in the digital age - there isn't a lot of content. Perusing the store is uninteresting as there is really only 10-15 titles to view, with only the corresponding DLC to mix things up. I find little drive to connect with friends on-line, even in multiplayer games. The achievement system with rewards is interesting, but ultimately has been under-promoted and not been utilized by me, despite my 60,000+ gamerscore.

Other: 5/5
Funnily enough, this is where the Xbox One really shines. It does many thing very well. The streaming from PC to Xbox is pretty good (videos), and the smartglass features are truly a good addition to the consoles already very accessible functionality. Netflix and Hulu Plus perform better and with more reliability (plus in Ultra HD) on the Xbox One than on any PC I have used. The interface is slick and easy to read. The ability to hook our satellite box to the Xbox (effectively turning my satellite box into a voice-controlled machine) with a more attractive and easier to use channel guide than what Direct TV provides for their own machine is in a word: Awesome.

Overall 20.5/25 (82%)
In many ways the Xbox again is leading the industry in intuitive access, in-home entertainment and aesthetic design. Unfortunately, the Xbox One only receives a B as it's gaming merits really are untested to this point (as far as exclusivity goes) and there are some functions that seem less functional and more frustrating. However, it is a good machine and Titanfall is a fantastically fun game on the One. Here's to hoping it only gets better.

title: I definitely recommend this computer
comment:
This will be a quick review of my personal experiences with the MacBook Air. I have had this laptop for about a year and still love it. It has 4th Gen Intel Core processors, Intel HD Graphics 5000, Wi-Fi support, Thunderbolt and USB 3 ports, a 720p HD webcam, and operates using OS X. The MacBook Air has a high-resolution 13.3” screen that possesses excellent brightness even in direct sunlight. This is all wrapped up into a good looking, thin, and lightweight platform.
Although I like this laptop a lot, there are a few minor flaws to note. Battery life is not the best. Apple claims up to twelve hours of battery life on the 13.3” screen model but I have yet to get anywhere close to that. While in use I average around five or six hours of battery life. Another drawback to the MacBook Air is the lack of an internal disk drive. I do have the external disk drive from Apple that works great but it can be a bit of a hassle to have to carry around as well. The final flaw I have to note is the fact that there is only one USB port. I do not consider this a major problem as you can just plug in a USB splitter, but once again that is something you will have to tote around.
Now I will mention the upsides of the MacBook Air. There are a lot of great features that the Air possesses so I will just hit what I believe to be the highlights. First off, as with any Apple product, it is extremely easy to use. The interface is very well laid out, straight forward, and easy to use. Also, if you have an iPod, iPhone, or any other Apple device it is easy to sync them together. The MacBook Air is loaded with standard features and gives you the ability to adapt it to fit your personal needs.
As I mentioned above, the screen is excellent. Even if you are in direct sunlight, the screen is still very visible. The backlit keyboard is great if you are working in a dark environment. Apple did an outstanding job of packing so much into such a small package. The whole computer is only about a half of an inch thick at the widest point with the length and width not being much larger than the screen itself. The computer also has a durable metal exterior but still retains being lightweight.
This computer is the total package. There are a few minor drawbacks to the MacBook Air as I mentioned earlier, but nothing that would prevent me from recommending it to a friend. By no means is this a cheap computer, but you would be hard pressed to find a better one for the money. I would recommend this laptop to anyone looking for high quality, easy to use, and dependable computer. My rating for the MacBook Air is a solid five stars.
